Browser lacks capabilities required to play.

Upgrade or switch to another browser.

You will use the output from this game to build the weekly role play assignment due in Canvas.</p> <p>If you're already done with this week's role play assignment, you can check out what everyone else has written at [[Our History Rewrite]]. We will discuss these in class. (Note: You need a password to open the Rewrite portals. You will receive the weekly password in Canvas after submitting the role play response.)</p> <h2>Tutorial</h2> <p>This brief video will show you how to play the game and use the output to complete the weekly role play assignments in Canvas.</p> <p>(embed video tutorial here)</p> <h2 class="center">Role Play Game Learning Objectives</h2> <p>Wondering, "Why am I doing this? What's the point?" Well, here's the official run-down on the purpose of these weekly activities. You will achieve the following learning objectives, which align with the History Department's student learning outcomes:</p> <ul> <li>Identify primary and secondary sources.</li> <li>Analyze the significance of primary and secondary sources as historical evidence.</li> <li>Apply discipline-specific concepts and vocabulary to evaluate various interpretations of history.</li> <li>Construct valid interpretations of history using evidence from primary and secondary sources with appropriate references to historical context.</li> </ul> <h2 class="center">Time Travel Portals</h2> <div class="container center"> <div class="row portals"> <h3>[[In the Beginning |Beginning]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/pyramids_leonardo-ramos_unsplash.jpg" alt="pyramids in the desert" width="50%">' "Beginning">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Iron Age Empires |Iron]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/ironage.jpg" alt="archer in chariot" width="50%">' "Iron">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Ancient Greece |Greece]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/greece1.jpg" alt="hoplite warriors fighting with spears and shields" width="50%">' "Greece">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[The Hellenistic World |Hellenistic]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/greece1b.jpg" alt="ruins of circular, columned temple" width="50%">' "Hellenistic">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Rome: From Republic to Empre |Rome1]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/rome1.jpg" alt="statue of human babies nursing from wolf" width="50%">' "Rome1">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/darkages.jpg" alt="helmet with face plate and engraving" width="50%">' "Rome2">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[The Viking Age |Viking]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/viking-module.jpg" alt="viking ship with warriors" width="50%">' "Viking">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Medieval Knights |Knights]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/hma.jpg" alt="mounted knight receiving shield and helmet from two women" width="50%">' "Knights">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/peasants.jpg" alt="people shearing sheep and reaping wheat with castle in background" width="50%">' "Peasants">><</link>> </div> <div class="portals"> <h3>[[Renaissance]]</h3> <<link '<img src="images/newworlds.jpg" alt="Queen Elizabeth I wearing ornate royal regalia" width="50%">' "Renaissance">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> </div> <<set $gtExplore1 to "">> <<set $gtExplore2 to "">> <<set $babylonExplore1 to "">> <<set $babylonExplore2 to "">> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row beginhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>In the Beginning, there was Beer...</h1> <p>So many firsts here: first beer, first wheel, first cities, first texts, first metallurgy, first empire. It begins in Mesopotamia with the Sumerians and Babylonians.</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-sumer.jpg" alt="stylized mythological figure wielding weapons" width="80%">' "begin-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenarios"> <div class="row transbox"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[Forager at Göbekli Tepe |GT]]</p> <p class="big">[[Scribe at Babylon |Babylon]]</p> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $assyriaExplore1 to "">> <<set $assyriaExplore2 to "">> <<set $lachishExplore1 to "">> <<set $lachishExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="ironhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Iron Age Empires</h1> <p>We're spending another week in Mesopotamia, but we'll also venture south into Egypt (pyramids!), and forge ahead through time into the Iron Age with the Hebrews, the Assyrian, and more of Babylon.</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-assyria.jpg" alt="cavalry attacking with spears" width="80%">' "iron-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[With the Assyrian army |Assyria]]</p> <p class="big">[[The siege of Lachish |Lachish]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><<set $helotExplore1 to "">> <<set $helotExplore2 to "">> <<set $periclesExplore1 to "">> <<set $periclesExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="greecehero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Ancient Greece: Hoplite & Polis</h1> <p>Turning from Mesopotamia, we lauch out west across "the wine-dark sea", as Homer calls it. Arriving on the shores of Ancient Greece, we find ourselves surrounded by wonders: fabulous creatures like centaurs, legendary heroes like Achilles and Hector, the crafty and cantankerous Olympian gods, and ranks of hoplite warriors. The struggles between the superpowers of the ancient Greek world echo quite uncannily the global conflicts of our own twenty and twenty-first centuries: diplomatic failures, incompatible enemies, strained truces, impossibly complex alliances, the influence of popular opinion on the tides of war ... blood, in short, is what this week is all about.</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/greek-combat.jpg" alt="black figure pottery illustration of ancient Greek warriors fighting with shield and spear" width="80%">' "greece-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[A rebel slave in Sparta |Helot]]</p> <p class="big">[[Pericles in Athens |Pericles]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><<set $spartacusExplore1 to "">> <<set $spartacusExplore2 to "">> <<set $pompeiiExplore1 to "">> <<set $pompeiiExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="rome1hero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Rome I: From Republic to Empire</h1> <p>Fighting its way to dominance in the Hellenistic World and transforming from a republic to an empire, Rome developed a culture of contradictions - venerating tradition but embracing innovation, idolizing the citizen soldier but pauperizing him, elaborately superstitious but immanently pragmatic. Driven by the engine of the unstoppable legions, Rome spread across Europe to become the largest and longest-lasting empire in history.</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="row title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a forager at Gobekli Tepe</h1> <p>Anatolia, c. 11,000 BCE</p> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "gt-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "gt-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row scenario"> <p>It's almost springtime in the hills of Anatolia when your migratory forager clan happens upon an interesting community. They have a permanent settlement with walls and homes and irrigated gardens. They have beer!</p> <p>They seem very busy with their livestock and crops and buildings. There's just so much <span class="em">stuff.</span> Junk everywhere. It all looks exhausting. And when they do have free time, they like to spend it working on an <<linkappend "insanely huge thing.">><<include gt-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> Massive walls and pillars, carved and painted with animals and human figures. You've never seen <<linkappend "anything like this.">><<include gt-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Over the next few days, other forager groups like your own start drifting into the area. They work together on the big buildings. Everyone seems to have a job - making ropes, preparing food, carrying rock, fetching water and firewood, carving stone, repairing tools, digging ditches. There's a powerful energy you enjoy, but also, people get bossy, pointing and commanding. Fights break out. Your group is invited to form a team and work on transporting the big stones. That evening, your band gathers around a fire and considers this decision. When it's your turn to speak, what do you say?</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>In the Middle Ages, people wondered about Stonehenge: Who built it? Why? Sometimes, they imagined explanations. For instance, in some French and English stories about the legends of King Arthur and his knights, the wizard Merlin built Stonehenge as a memorial for a battle in the Brittons' war with the Saxon invaders. Merlin used his magic to transport the stones from Ireland, and a friendly giant set them in place. Basically the same as <em>Ancient Aliens</em> today.</p> <p><img src="images/stonehenge-wace.jpg" alt="manuscript illlustration of giant building stonehenge" width="50%"></p> <p>Here's a construction scene from a 14th-century manuscript (from <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/10486/merlin-constructs-stonehenge-roman-de-brut/" target="blank">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <div class="row"> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>Do you want to stay and get involved because this is kind of amazing (plus, the beer)? Or do you want to pack up and head for the hills because following orders and doing manual labor is just not your style. Analyze the factors that determine your choice. What fears, desires, relationships, realities motivated you?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>Your group agrees with you and follows your advice. Predict some short term and long term outcomes of this choice for you as an individual, and for your community.</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li> Your gender, age, relationships, family situation </li> <li> Your skills, talents, strengths or disabilities </li> </ul> </div> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Primary Sources</h3> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pillars of Gobekli Tepe |Pillars]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h3>Secondary Sources</h3> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A model of Gobekli Tepe |GT Model]]</li> <li>[[Foragers and agriculturalists at Gobekli Tepe |GT Curry]]</li> <li>[[Building monoliths and pyramids |Rocks]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-gt]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a young scribe in Babylon</h1> <p>Mesopotamia, c. 1700 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "babylon-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "babylon-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>It's c. 1700 BCE in Babylon during the reign of Hammurabi. You are a young scribe in the <<linkappend "palace complex.">> <<include "babylon-link1">> <</linkappend>> Life is miserable. You are bored and angry, exhausted from doing chores and trying to learn this impossible script while dodging beatings from your teachers and hazing from the older boys. Everyone tells you how lucky you are, how great your city's gods and king are. They love stories like the <<linkappend "Epic of Gilgamesh.">> <<include "babylon-link2">> <</linkappend>></p> <p>You don't buy it. Gilgamesh is an idiotic thug, like basically everyone who tells you what to do all day (which is a lot of people). Risking a major beating, you steal some clay tablets from the priests. In the weak light of the quiet, pre-dawn hours, you start writing a new version of that idiotic story about the whole Gilgamesh bromance. You hide the tablets in a niche under your sleeping mat. In your story, Gilgamesh gets what he deserves.</p> <p>One morning when you reach for your tablets, your heart freezes and time stops as your fingers find only empty space. Wtf who took it they are going to kill me. If I'm lucky. You look around and see a form hunched over in the dim predawn grey. You approach slowly. It's your best friend. He's holding your tablets, and he's crying. He hugs you and begs to join your Gilgamesh rewrite. Soon, others young scribes join, and a genuine conspiracy begins. This isn't a game any more. They all have colorful ideas for revenge on the palace elite. You find yourselves plotting to overthrow the regime and seize power for yourselves.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>With is strategically powerful location between the great Tigris and Euphrates rivers, it's no wonder that the city of Babylon reigned supreme in the region, serving as the administrative and economic hub for numerous empires as they rose and fell through the Bronze and Iron Age epochs. The Hebrew Bible presented Babylon as the epitome worldly vice, sin, greed, and ambition, a den of iniquity standing in stark opposiiton to the upright virtue of the Hebrew followers of Yaweh. Babylon became the original "sin city." This image persisted into the modern age as centuries of Christian writers and artists used Babylon to represent the antipathy of Christian virtue, the antichrist's corrupt foil to Christ's pure promise of eternal life.</p> <p><img src="images/whore-babylon.jpg" alt="woman riding a dragon" width="100%"></p> <p>This image from a sixteenth-century German Bible represents the "Whore of Babylon" with her dragon. In the biblical book of Revelations, she is the mother of the Antichrist of Armageddon. By putting a papal crown on the woman, this Protestant artist has harnessed the old symbolism of Babylon to his own political agenda, creating an image that demonizes the Pope and the Catholic church.</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>Do you want to stay and get involved because this is kind of amazing (plus, the beer)? Or do you want to pack up and head for the hills because following orders and doing manual labor is just not your style. Analyze the factors that determine your choice. What fears, desires, relationships, realities motivated you?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>Your group agrees with you and follows your advice. Predict some short term and long term outcomes of this choice for you as an individual, and for your community.</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your skills, knowledge, economic status</li> <li>The current political and economic situation</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2500 BCE) |Royal Standard]]</li> <li>[[The Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2200 BCE) |Gilgamesh]]</li> <li>[[Advice to a Scribe (c. 1880 BCE) |scribe-egypt]]</li> <li>[[The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1790 BCE) |Hammurabi]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A Scribe's Life |scribe-meso]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: In the Beginning</p> <p><img src="images/pyramids_leonardo-ramos_unsplash.jpg" alt="pyramids" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copygt"> <<if (def $gtgtpe1) and ($gtgtpe1 isnot Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2500 BCE)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>This small chest from ancient Sumer is decorated with precious metals and stone depicting scenes of war and peace. Images are from the <a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/W_1928-1010-3" target="_blank">British Museum.</a></p> <p>The War Side</p> <img src="images/ur-peace.jpg" alt="blue and white stone ornament showing an army" width="100%"> <p>The Peace Side</p> <img src="images/ur-peace.jpg" alt="blue and white stone ornament showing a banquet" width="100%"> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Tools and technology in Sumerian and Akkadian Mesopotamia</li> <li>Symbols of social status or hierarchy</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas.</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea Written c. 2200 BCE in ancient Sumer, the epic poem follows the exploits of Gilgamesh, king of Uruk. Here is a brief summary: <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vRba8D3UWfdCFzYcEGs4bHNqLyVVo5aKCok5oQofGqNR6zYX4uN402AgSA9_8mR5a4qJr5kWYgpeemf/pub" target="_blank">The Epic of Gilgamesh</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Material culture (i.e. technology, tools, materials that define everyday life)</li> <li>Political structure and ideology, especially ideals of justice and kingship</li> <li>Attitudes toward gods and nature</li> <li>Cultural norms relating to friendship and good behavior</li> <li>Beliefs and practices relating to gender and sexuality</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas.</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea BCE) |Royal Standard]]</li> <li>[[The Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2200 BCE) |Gilgamesh]]</li> <li>[[Advice to a Scribe (c. 1880 BCE) |scribe-egypt]]</li> <li>[[The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1790 BCE) |Hammurabi]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A Scribe's Life |scribe-meso]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Babylon Scenario |Babylon]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Papyrus Lansing</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>This papyrus scroll from Egypt c. 1800 BCE tells us a lot about the opportunities and challenges experienced by scribes in the ancient West. Although it is from Egypt, much of these concepts would apply to Mesopotamian scribes as well. Open the translation of the <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1h3A3jdz2ORptbXYUtKf6MqNFiQ_F797N/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Papyrus Lansing</a> here.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Challenges and opportunities facing a young scribe in the ancient West</li> <li>Scribes' position in ancient society and political structures</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bsee1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$bsea1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$bsee2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$bsea2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$bsee3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$bsea3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$bsee4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$bsea4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Royal Standard of Ur (c. 2500 BCE) |Royal Standard]]</li> <li>[[The Epic of Gilgamesh (c. 2200 BCE) |Gilgamesh]]</li> <li>[[Advice to a Scribe (c. 1880 BCE) |scribe-egypt]]</li> <li>[[The Code of Hammurabi (c. 1790 BCE) |Hammurabi]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[A Scribe's Life |scribe-meso]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Babylon Scenario |Babylon]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Advice to a Young Scribe</h1><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> </div> <p>This article from <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/article/2106/a-supervisors-advice-to-a-young-scribe/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a> contains secondary source and primary source material about the life of a scribe in Old Babylon c. 2000 BCE (scroll down to find the primary source - the translation of the ancient text).</p> <p><span class="bi">Primary and secondary source? </span> How can this item be both primary and secondary? Well, it depends on what part you are using. You can use the material written by the World History Encyclopedia contributors as a secondary source (something written in our own times), and use the quotes from the Mesopotamian text as a primary source. This is quite common!</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The social status of scribes</li> <li>The education of scribes</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bsme1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$bsma1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-b]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Babylon Scenario |Babylon]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Code of Hammurabi</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Hammurabi's law code, inscribed on a stele, is the oldest surviving law code. Hammurabi ruled his Amorite empire from Babylon c. 1792 - 1750. Open <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vTuZm-Reo1EN6LYvA6S7p7FuGcWWcvby8POklVHllYDrTUcqNZQZ3u1sHezR49KfxjobmfzhBQq9kcU/pub" target="_blank">Hammurabi's Code</a> here.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Begin-victory-gt]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Portal |Beginning]]</li> <li>[[Back: Göbekli Tepe Scenario |GT]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Building with Big Rocks</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>What do Stonehenge in England and the Pyramids in Egypt have to do with the neolithic site in Turkey? Well, all three were all constructed by neolithic or bronze age people (as in, humans and not aliens) using massive stones and relatively simple tools. There are interesting similarities in terms of construction methods, materials, the technologies, and the group dynamics involved. Here are a couple of interesting and informative (and short!) videos to help provide some wider context and suggest deeper insights into the feel of a neolithic construction project like Göbekli Tepe.</p> <p>Here's one about <a href="https://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/stonehenge/history-and-stories/building-stonehenge/" target="_blank">Building Stonehenge</a>from British Heritage.</p> <p>And here's a wonderful page about quarrying and transporting stones for the Egyptian pyramids from <a href="https://aeraweb.org/great-pyramid-quarry/" target="_blank">Ancient Egypt Research Associates.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>What would it be like to work on a megalithic structure like Göbekli Tepe?</li> <li>What tools and skills would have been valued during the construction?</li> <li>How would this work impact social relationships?</li> <li>Environmental impacts of a project like Göbekli Tepe</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtrockse1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$gtrockse1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second Curry. "The World's Oldest Temple to be Restored." <em>National Geographic</em>. 2016.</a></p> </div> <div class="link"> <p>Pillar 43, Gobekli Tepe</p> <p><img src="images/gobekli-tepe-pillar.jpg" alt="large monolith inscribed with animals" width=60%></p> <p><a href="https://tepetelegrams.wordpress.com/2016/10/14/of-animals-and-a-headless-man-gobekli-tepe-pillar-43/">O. Dietrich. "Of animals and a headless man. Gobekli Tepe, Pillar 43." <em>The Tepe Telegrams.</em> October 14, 2016.</a></p> </div> <div class="link"> <p>An artist's impression of the great ziggurat of Ur. Ziggurats in Old Babylon would have looked like this.</p> <p><img src="images/ziggurat-ur.jpg" alt="ziggurat" width=100%></p> <p><a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/12890/ziggurat-of-ur-artists-impression/">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> </div> <div class="link"> A surviving fragment of the <em>Epic of Gilgamesh</em>, recorded in cuneiform script on a clay tablet <p><img src="images/gilgamesh-clay.jpg" alt="clay tablet inscribed with cuneiform script" height="100%"></p> <p><a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/image/107404001">British Museum</a></p> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you've just joined the Assyrian army</h1> <p>Mesopotamia, c. 800 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "assyria-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "assyria-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>You saw the smoke a day before arriving at the city. Now you see that it doesn’t rise from the city itself, but from the imperial camp coiled around its walls. The road to the camp is broad and well-traveled, busy with camels and horses. A ribbon of thick, riparian growth shows where a small river passes through the camp to skirt the city walls. You remember crossing the Euphrates a few weeks ago, the terror and awe, and then the feeling of relief and even pride. You’d never seen <<linkappend "anything like it.">><<include "Assyrian-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> <p>You’d never seen anything more than your poor, small village with its low, mud huts and its herds of skinny goats until the army came a few months ago.</p> <p>They came to your village looking for taxes and conscripts for the imperial army. Some of the boys had fought and screamed. Some of their families had fought or tried to hide, and the rich ones had given everything they had to keep their sons home. And now here you are - not that you know where “here” is.</p> <p>You’re smart enough to realize that your life has almost no value to your commanders. You don’t necessarily want to go home (after all, it wasn’t much, and the sargeants here make a big show of executing deserters in memorably messy ways). Strangely, you value yourself. You have decided that you are more than meat to be fed into the imperial war machine. You want to survive. Maybe even move up in the world. <<linkappend "Power. Wealth. A future.">> <<include "Assyrian-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> <p>There’s opportunity, as well as horroa and death, all around you here. What do you do?<p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>One of my favorite places is the Assyrian room in the British Museum. It's usually quiet and fairly empty (in contrast to the Egyptian or Roman exhibits, clogged with heaving masses of sweaty tourists). The Assyrian room is a temple. A holy shrine to so many things. Like brutal, hypocritical, racist imperialism? Meet our fellow travelers here in ancient West: nineteenth-century European imperialists.</p> <p><img src="images/stanley.jpg" alt="photo of Victorian-era man holding a rifle with Black servant nearby" width="50%"></p> <p>(Above: Victorian explorer Henry Morton Stanley with African servant in 1872)</p> <p>In their pith helmets and assertive mustaches, these intrepid and entitled explorers risked their lives and their fortunes to pirate ancient artifacts from the farthest reaches of their global empires and bring them back to private or public collections in Europe (like the Louvre in Paris and the British Museum in London).</p> <p><img src="images/denon-temple.jpg" alt="watercolor of ancient monuments" width="100%"></p> <p>The European science of archaeology was born here. It started with Napoleon's invasion of Egypt (British sphere of influence), when artists like Vivant Denon discovered magnificent ruins of an ancient civilization (see Denon's impression of an Egyptian temple in 1807). It seemed to them that the indigenous Egyptians and their Ottoman rulers had no knowledge of or interest in these artifacts. Grave robbers had plundered the low-hanging fruit, the ruins were defaced by graffiti, goats were living in the temples, and nobody seemed to care. So the French began excavating and studying and transported many of these Egyptian treasures back to Paris. To French viewers, they were emblems of Napoleon's power. You can see the 13th-century BCE obelisks from ancient Egypt in the streets of Paris today (below).</p> <p><img src="images/luxor-paris.jpg" alt="obelisks in a city" width="80%"></p> <p>Here's a fun comedy routine about this issue.</p> <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/x73PkUvArJY?si=42C9LWUQJYnlQnCe" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe> <hr> <p>Nowadays, imperialism is out of fashion. Right out. Decolonization is the watchword, and many feel outraged that these ancient artifacts remain in the colonizers' hands. They believe they should be returned, with apologies, to the regimes currently in power in these locations. Do you agree?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Yes, obviously. It's ludicrous that the British museum in London continues to hold artifacts that belong to Syria.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#tespA">>It doesn't seem fair, does it? Western nations should prioritize taking steps to redress and dismantle these legacies of colonial injustice.<</replace>><</link>> <p id="trespB"><<link "I do not agree because this issue is more complex. For instance, the regimes in these parts of the world have little connection to the civilizations that created the artifacts, and they are so unstable that the artifacts would be in real danger of damage or destruction.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Fair points. Also, it's possible that a much smaller and less diverse group of people would go to see them if they were housed in, say, Aleppo or Baghdad?<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>How will you achieve personal success here at this siege, and boost your status within the military?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>In ten years, what will your life be like? If you're still alive? Will you ever go home? Why?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your past experience, skills, physical and intellectual abilities</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian Palace Art |friezes]]</li> <li>[[The Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III |obelisk]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Secondary source |mil-empire]]</li> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |assyrian-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, your city is besieged by the Assyrians</h1> <p>Lachish, c. 800 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "lachish-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "lachish-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>The Assyrian army spreads like a lake of ants around the city of Lachish, smoke from its cooking fires rising up around you like the walls of a cage, wrapping you in a feeling of crushing, hopeless imprisonment. You focus on setting aside panic. The enemy is busy building siege engines and ramps and digging, raiding the countryside and practicing their maneuvers. More seem to arrive <<linkappend "every day.">><<include "Lachish-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>The city of Lachish is strong. But it’s also divided. Backed by the money and military of King Hezekiah at Jerusalem, the local elite have adopted the cult of Yaweh, pushing everyone to conform. Now the seething mass of death and destruction outside the walls has ignited the explosive resentments that divide the city’s population. Nomadic folk who fled into the city from the countryside have never had much good to say about city people - and vice versa. Slaves aren’t sure who’s scarier now - their masters or the Assyrians. Canaanites and Philistines, Egyptians and Hebrews have never trusted each other much (at all).</p> <p>Your family has lived in the area since the Great Flood. You come to the market here every week to trade wool and cheese and wild herbs and honey. You don’t hate the city like some of the other outsiders do, but your home is out there in the hills and your gods are not the great, unknowable Yaweh with his laws and scrolls and <<linkappend "priests and temple.">><<include "Lachish-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>One night, after drifting to sleep with your baby nestled under one arm, and your oldest son on the other side, you’re awakened by whispering voices. Your husband is sitting with a group of friends. One of them has just come back after spending a few days in the Assyrian camp. The city walls are strong, but most folk know how to find a way out when they want to. He’s heard what happens to cities who resist the empire. Wouldn’t it be better to surrender now, he says? It’s not our city, anyway. Silence, and then soft muttering. You can see some of their heads nodding in the dim moonlight. Your grip on the baby tightens, and it squirms, nuzzling for your breast. Your mind is racing.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>feedback<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>According to the Hebrew Bible, the patriarchs (Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob) produced twelve tribes of the Hebrew nation. By the time of the Assyrian siege of Lachish, those tribes had split into two kingdoms: Ten tribes were in the Kingdom of Israel, and two were in the Kingdom of Judah. Israel chose to resist Assyria. Long story short, nobody ever saw them again. They are remembered as "the ten lost tribes of Israel."</p> <p>But this isn't the end of the story. Surprisingly, the ten lost tribes of Isreal figure quite prominently in the history of the United States. It started in New York in the 1820s. Amid the evangelistic fervor of the Second Great Awakening, Joseph Smith experienced a vision. An angel named Moroni appeared and showed him golden tablets inscribed with a script Smith identified as "reformed Egyptian." Miraculously, Smith was able to translate the tablets. (Aside from a single friend of Smith's, nobody else has ever seen the original tablets or any other ancient examples of a "reformed Egyptian" script or language). The tablets contained passages from the King James Bible and foretold the coming of Christ. They also revealed the fate of the ten lost tribes of Israel: These tribes had come to the Americas and become the ancestors of the Native Americans. With these golden tablets, Smith founded Mormonism and the Church of Jesus Christ and the Latter Day Saints (LDS). It is a major world religion today. (Note that the academic community does not accept Smith's theory about the ten lost tribes of Israel.)</p> <hr> <p>Considering the Mormons' belief that the Native Americans were the descendants of the ten lost tribes of Israel, how do you think they treated them while establishing their theocratic state in 19th-century Utah?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "They strove to convert the Native Americans to Mormonism.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Yes, Mormon missionaries actively cultivated positive relationships with neighboring indigenous communities with a focus on conversion. They also fought and violently displaced the tribes at various times.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Nineteenth-century antisemitism and racism disinclined the Mormons to view the Native Americans with any sympathy.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>True enough. For instance, they were fine with falsely blaming Native Americans for the infamous Mountain Meadows Massacre on 9/11, 1857.<</replace>><</link>></p> <hr> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What do you say to your girlfriends the next morning? What do you say to your husband? What will you do?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What happens to you and your family? What happens to Lachish and the Kingdom of Judah? Does the new cult of Yaweh flourish?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your past experience, skills, physical and intellectual abilities</li> <li>Your family and personal relationships and community network</li> <li>Your socio-economic class</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> <li>[[Bible stories |bible-stories]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Archaeological and artistic evidence |lachish-evidence]]</li> <li>[[Ancient Israel and Judah |miller-israel]]</li> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |lachish-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Matty, <em>Sennacherib's Campaign</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dY0W4xaNuurj1Thj1bDyLo1bhNCb6_5R/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This book chapter</a> from Matty, <em>Sennacherib's Campaign Against Judah and Jerusalem in 701 B.C.: A Historical Reconstruction</em> (2016) examines archaeological and artistic evidence about the Assyrian campaign against Judah in 701 BCE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Item</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas.</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachma2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachme3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachma3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <<textarea "$lachme4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <<textarea "$lachma4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> <li>[[Bible stories |bible-stories]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Archaeological and artistic evidence |lachish-evidence]]</li> <li>[[Ancient Israel and Judah |miller-israel]]</li> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |lachish-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Lachish Scenario |Lachish]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Assyrian Friezes of the Siege of Lachish</h1><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> </div> <p>This article from <a href=https://etc.worldhistory.org/photos/siege-lachish-reliefs-british-museum/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a> contains secondary source and primary source material about the Assyrian siege of Lachish.</p> <p><span class="bi">Primary and secondary source? </span> How can this item be both primary and secondary? Well, it depends on what part you are using. You can use the material written by the World History Encyclopedia contributors as a secondary source (something written in our own times), and use details from the Assyrian palace friezes a primary source. It's a two-for-one!</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Assyrian strengths and weaknesses</li> <li>Methods, tools, strategies utilized by Assyria during the siege</li> <li>Motivations and options of the people in Lachish</li> <li>What actually happened to the people when Assyria won</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> <li>[[Bible stories |bible-stories]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Archaeological and artistic evidence |lachish-evidence]]</li> <li>[[Ancient Israel and Judah |miller-israel]]</li> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |lachish-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Lachish Scenario |Lachish]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Miller and Hayes, <em>Ancient Israel and Judah</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1B0ThpyziLnMWirjnCrGuYQ8H1jnCH71K/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This book chapter</a> from Miller and Hayes, <em>A History of Ancient Israel and Judah</em> (2006) examines archaeological and textual evidence about the diverse peoples who lived in and around the kingdom of Judah before and during its inception.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Relationships between different groups of people in the region of Lachish</li> <li>The process of the development of the cult of Yaweh in the region of Lachish</li> <li>Material culture (technology, tools, goods) of everyday life in ancient Judah</li> <li>Challenges and limitations of historical interpretations of evidence from ancient Judah</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas.</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachaa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachaa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> <li>[[Bible stories |bible-stories]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox
