Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Lachish Scenario |Lachish]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a young Helot woman</h1> <p>Sparta, 465 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "helot-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "helot-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>You are a young Helot woman. It’s 465 BCE, and another Helot rebellion is raging <<linkappend "across the Peloponnesus.">><<include "Helot-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Your people do this every couple of generations. It never works, but what the hell. What have you got to lose, really? As usual, Sparta’s allies have come trudging in to help the noble Spartans beat their slaves back into the ground. Again.</p> <p>But this time will be different. This time, the Helots have friends too. The moon looks monstrous as it floats up higher on the horizon - an angry red eye, leering through twisting columns and heavy layers of smoke. The Helots are burning the crops they’ve been growing for their masters. Occasionally the sound of screaming threads through the smoky air. You’re lying in the tall grass, your head resting in the curve of your lover’s arm. You feel so alive. Like you have never been alive before. Like his body is a portal to another world, and you have fallen through it. The world you left wasn’t real. This is the real world. You resist sleep, your eyes tracking the rise of the bloody orb of the moon. When the it reaches its zenith, you will meet with the Athenian rowers in the olive grove at the foot of this hill. Yesterday, Sparta sent Athens home when they came to help their “friends” crush the rebellion: “Thanks for coming, but <<linkappend "we don't want you here.">><<include "Helot-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> So the Athenians sailed off over the horizon … and then looped back around to anchor here in the cove and send runners to find the Helot leaders. Your heart leaps as you think about what might happen now.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Today, if we call something "spartan," we mean it's simple and effective, no-frills, function-over-form. It's the opposite of luxurious or ornate.</p> <hr> <p>Is your current dwelling spartan?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "This is what's known (politely) as euphemism. It is basically a cardboard.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>All part of the halcyon bliss of your undergraduate experience. Enjoy.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Well, no.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Lucky you!<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>We've all heard of Helen of Troy, the most beautiful woman in the world, awarded to Paris, Prince of Troy, in a hilariously cheeky "be careful what you wish for" move by Aphrodite. But she wasn't Helen of Troy at all. She was Helen of Sparta ... and that was the problem, right? The story of Helen is exemplary of a wider trend in the ancient sources representing Spartan women as physically attractive (and, perhaps, dangerous?). Hollywood likes to tell the Paris-Helen story in a way that appeals to our modern tastes for romantic love. But Homer tells it quite differently. In the ancient poems, Helen <em>hates</em> Paris and does her best to make his life miserable - for instance, constantly calling him a coward and flirting <em>hard</em> with his big brother, Hector. Homer's version feels more in line with what we would expect from an abducted Spartan queen.</p> <p>Anyway, the story of Helen and the Trojan War was clearly a beloved and widely retold tale throughout ancient Greece. The most complete Trojan War narrative comes to us in oral-traditional verse composed by the (blind?) poet Homer c. 800 BCE. "Sing, Muse! Sing of the rage of Achilles..." The opening lines of Homer's <em>Iliad</em> are as familiar as the "In the beginning..." of <em>Genesis</em>. Indeed, the great epics of Homer, <em>The Iliad</em> and <em>The Odyssey</em>, are second only to the Bible in the longevity and depth of their influence on artistic and literary genius of the West for the past two millenia (and more). For long centuries, artists and poets and even political figures have drawn inspiration from the story of the Trojan War. The Roman poet Virgil used Homer's epics as a template for his own version a Roman origin story (<em>The Aeneid</em>). Medieval historians traced their own kings' lineages back to the plains of Ilium. (Thus, Britons came from a Brutus who fled Troy, for instance, and Thor was named for his native city of Troy.) Later, Hector, Helen, Achilles, and company appear on Shakespeare's stage, and these days, in Hollywood blockbusters. Probably my personal favorite is Dan Simmons' spec fiction novels <em>Illium</em> and <em>Olympos</em>, in which post-humans are Greek gods playing war games with their nano-engineered pet superhumans on a mockup of the Trojan War on Mars. Thank you, Homer, whoever you were.</p> <p><img src="images/odysseus-sirens.jpg" alt="men in ship, sirens diving" width="100%"></p> <p>Ancient Greek pottery showing Odysseus listening to the sirens' song</p> <p><img src="images/waterhouse-penelope.jpg" alt="men speaking through window as woman weaves" width="100%"></p> <p>Odysseus' wife, Penelope, tricking her suitors by weaving her father's funeral shroud all day (and unraveling it at night), by Pre-Raphaelite painter John William Waterhouse (England, 1912)</p> <hr> <p>The event that earns Paris the dubious "reward" of Helen is known as:</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "The Oedipus Cycle">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Good guess. That's a different Greek thing ... similar though, in its merciless, sardonic surrender to inexorabile Fate.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "The Judgment of Paris">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Quite so. Never, <em>ever</em>, agree to serve as a judge in a beauty contest between Greek goddesses. Useful lesson in life.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>You let yourself fantasize about a home without Spartans. A new polis will rise here. Your polis. What will its constitution be like? Which gods will it honor? What kinds of people will be free, and how free? Do you think about improving the situation of women? How will you repel Spartan attempts to regain control? (You know they’ll flee into the open arms of Persia, where they already have plenty of friends.)</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>The Athenians don’t want women at the meeting. They say they gossip too much and will get everyone killed and should be at home. ("We don't <em>have</em> homes!" you want to scream at them.) What do you do? Do you leave quietly because you need revolution? Or do you stand your ground because you need this revolution?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your past experience, skills, physical and intellectual abilities</li> <li>Your family and personal relationships and community network</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tyrtaeus (c. 625 BCE) |tyrtaeus]]</li> <li>[[Xenophon (c. 380 BCE) |xenophon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Helots in Sparta |cartledge-helots]]</li> <li>[[About women in Sparta |cartledge-women]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Pericles</h1> <p>Athens, 414 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pericles-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pericles-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>You are Pericles, and you didn’t die of plague in 429 BCE. It is now 414, and as <em>strategos,</em> you have kept Athens mostly on top of this conflict with Sparta and her Peloponnesian League. Just barely. But now Persia has built Sparta a navy. Shit. Soooooo predictable. What are we going to do about those knuckle-dragging fascists?</p> <p>So, that’s a problem. But the worst threat is inside the gates. The young men of Athens are going mad, pent up behind the Long Walls, dying of plague and longing for a real fight. They follow Alcibiades like sheep. Glamorous, rich, impossibly beautiful Alcibiades. <<linkappend "Depraved, lecherous, rebellious Alcibiades.">><<include "Pericles-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> He was your student, your protege, once upon a time. But you serve the people, Alcibiades serves himself alone. Along with Socrates and a gaggle of dirty comic playwrights, he is uprooting everything you're fighting for, everything Athens stands for. They mock the gods and the city itself, tearing at the solidarity you've been nurturing during these long, bitter years of war with Sparta, screaching for war while you work for peace.</p> <p>Alcibiades mesmerizes the peope, with his proud aristocratic disdain for democracy, his lavish, fashionable, party life, his rash calls for escalation against Sparta. His latest idea is <<linkappend "an attack on Sicily.">><<include "Pericles-link2">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><</linkappend>> It's beyond idiotic. Utter madness - especially now that Sparta has its Persian-funded navy. But this is a democracy, and Alcibiades says whatever makes the crowd roar. They love him. Frankly, you’re not sure who is in charge any more - him or his worshipers.</p> <p>Tonight the city will gather to hear your annual funeral oration. You want to make this one count. You <em>need</em> to make it count, like that one at the beginning of the war that people still quote at symposia and the theater. What can you say this time to steer your city toward survival, and break the spell of Alcibiades?</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Athens' vibrant community of playwrights and artists worked with a rich common stock of traditional myth and legend, with which their audiences were familiar. These stories, heroes, and names still surround us today. Just look up, and you'll find constellations like Pegasus, Centaurus, and Cassiopeia, just to name a few.</p> <p>Sometimes we find it challenging to understand or appreciate what these myths meant to ancient people. Athens' own patron deity, the mighty Athena, provides a good example of this challenge. Athena was the goddess of war, wisdom, and crafts, protector of heroes like Herakles, Odysseus, Perseus, and Theseus (founder of Athens). So, wait, "crafts?" Like scrapbooking or quilting or basket weaving? Negative. Crafts as in technology. This is probably why Hephaestus, the smith god, had a thing for her. Athena was constantly helping her favorite humans by giving them ingenious tools and weapons or showing them tricks to achieve victory. It's no surprise that her protege, "wily Odysseus," was the guy who came up with the Trojan Horse idea. So, today, Athena's "craftiness" lines up with coding and engineering rather than quilting. She belongs with <em>Wired</em> and <em>Turing Magazine</em>, not <em>Better Homes and Gardens</em>.</p> <p><img src="images/athena-enceladus.jpg" alt="female figure fighting male with spear and shield" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: This scene shows Athena's combat with the giant Enceladus. When he finally took off running, she threw Sicily at him. (Attica, 6th century BCE)</p> <p>It's interesting to compare Athena with the other Greek god of war, Ares. Ares is a total psychopath and his children are all monsters. In some ways, Athena represents a more positive attitud toward war as a space for technological innovation and strategic advances. Ares, on the other hand, represents the bestial savagery of war. Is this a dichotomy we ponder today as well?</p> <hr> <p>The Roman equivalent of Athena was:</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Minerva">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Yes.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Juno">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Nope, this would be the Roman equivalent of Hera, wife of Zeus (or Jove, to the Romans).<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey (score +2).</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Historians have often noted strong parallels between the Peloponnesian War of ancient times and the Cold War of the twentieth century. Both wars formed around the rivalry between two regional superpowers (Sparta vs. Athens, and the US vs. USSR). Both rivalries had ideological as well as economic differences at their core (democracy vs. oligarchy in the ancient world, and liberal democracy and capitalism vs. oligarchic communism in the modern world). Both wars were characterized by alternating periods of peace and tension, proxy wars, repeated diplomatic failures, and by complex networks of alliances linking smaller polities allied to each superpower. Both wars were prolonged by political as well as geopolitical factors. And in both cases, an outside "third power" added complexity to the core opposition between the two great powers (Persia in ancient times, and China in the twentieth century). And in both cases, we 21st-century Americans want to cheer on Team Democracy, but it's hard to do it wholeheartedly, because nobody comes away with clean hands. It's hard to point out the "good guy" in wars like this.</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What will you say in your funeral speech this year? What's your new strategy for dealing with this war that never seems to end? How will you make it all appealing to your Athenian citizens (meaning, of course, the free adult men)?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How will the city react? How will Sparta and Persia respond when they hear about it?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Athens' strengths and weaknesses at this point in the Peloponnesian War</li> <li>Ideals of patriotism and masculinity in Classical Athens</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Pericles' famous "Funeral Oration" |funeral-oration]]</li> <li>[[A popular, bawdy comedy about the Peloponnesian War |lysistrata]]</li> <li>[[Socrates' trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="link"> <p>Aristocratic Athenian leader Alcibiades was popular for his personal beauty, wealth, wild lifestyle, and defiance of traditional authority. He destroyed Athenian democracy, ensured Athens' deafeat in the Peloponnesian War, betrayed Athens to fight for Sparta, betrayed Sparta and slept with the Spartan king's wife, and fought for Persia. He was a student and close friend of the controversial philosopher Socrates. Like Socrates, Alcibiades was tried and sentenced to death for basically desecrating the gods. While Socrates was convicted of atheism and "corrupting the youth," and famously sentenced to drink poison hemlock, Alcibiades was convicted of vandalizing statues of the gods (in particular, by breaking the phalluses off statues of their statues around the city). Unlike Socrates, however, Alcibiades fled Athens and was not executed.</p> <hr> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-6"> <p>A Roman copy of a Greek statue of Alcibiades</p> <img src="images/alcibiades.jpg" alt="statue of man's shoulders and head" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-6"> <p>A Roman copy of a Greek <em>herma,</em> the type of guardian spirit" statue supposedly vandalized by Alcibiades and his followers on the eve of the ill-fated Sicilian Expedition</p> <img src="images/herma.jpg" alt="statue of man's head, genitals, and rectangular torso" width="100%"> </div> </div> </div> <hr> <p>In his 1787 "The Death of Socrates," Enlightenment painter Jacques-Louis David emphasizes Socrates' righteous defiance and the deep impact of his execution/suicide on the leadership of Athens.</p><img src="images/David-Socrates-1787.jpg" alt="socrates drinking poison, surrounded by grieving men" width="100%"> </div><div class="link"> <p><img src="images/map-peloponnesian-war.jpg" alt="map of Peloponnesian War" width="100%"></p> <p>This map shows the distance between the Greek colonies on Sicily and the main theater of the Peloponnesian War, centered in Greece and the Aegean. From Cole and Symes, <em>Western Civilizations,</em> Brief Fifth Edition (New York: Norton, 2020)</p> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Xenophon, <em>On the Spartan Constitution</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Xenophon was a well-educated mercenary and statesman who led troops in Persia and the Greek city-states, including Sparta. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GA1sXFZYQIl8M9l7FvRA3-bS2fVjUhF8KcLED1hJ3Wc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here are some excerpts</a> from his description of Sparta's laws and political system (written c. 380 BCE).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The situation and role of women in Spartan society</li> <li>The situation and role of Helots</li> <li>Spartan military training</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div The play tells the story of Athenian women who come up with a plot to force the men to end the Peloponnesian War. They barricade themselves in the acropolis and (try to) refuse to have sex until the war is over.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Tastes and expectations of an Athenian audience</li> <li>Popular perspectives on the Peloponnesian War</li> <li>Athenian views on Sparta</li> <li>Gender norms, especially power dynamics and ideals of masculinity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Plato, <em>Apology</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>With <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fAgEueC45hO1bTwueni7wAaivTLitJhf/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank"><em>The Apology</em></a>, Plato purports to reproduce the speech made by Socrates in self-defense during his trial for "impiety" and "corrupting the youth" in 399. Socrates' trial and execution occurred after Athens had lost the Peloponnesian War and was convulsed by violent civil strife as Spartan-supported oligarchic regimes vied for power with Athenian democratic factions. Plato was Socrates' student, and recorded the teachings of Socrates, who did not himself leave a written record. Plato was present at Socrates' trial. Xenophon also wrote a (quite different) account of the trial and speech, but was not present himself.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Key themes of the political, ideological, and cultural conflicts in Athens during the late Peloponnesian Wars</li> <li>Gender norms, especially power dynamics and ideals of masculinity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoce4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclessoca4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Pericles' famous "Funeral Oration" |funeral-oration]]</li> <li>[[A popular, bawdy comedy about the Peloponnesian War |lysistrata]]</li> <li>[[Socrates' trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Pericles, "Funeral Oration"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Thucydides was the second earliest historian (after Herodotus), and an Athenian general during the Peloponnesian War. His <em>History of the Peloponnesian War</em> is our most important primary source for studying that event. It includes Thucydides' reproduction of <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jUWlqTNHqsqotvJKxDg63OWmT0AZ9oCGFpo69N_p-GQ/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Pericles' famous "funeral oration."</a> Athens held an annual funeral ceremony commemorating its soldiers who had died in the war. Pericles' speech at the 431 ceremony had a deep impact.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Key themes of the political, ideological, and cultural conflicts in Athens during the late Peloponnesian Wars</li> <li>Gender norms, especially power dynamics and ideals of masculinity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div "$periclesfoe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesfoa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Pericles' famous "Funeral Oration" |funeral-oration]]</li> <li>[[A popular, bawdy comedy about the Peloponnesian War |lysistrata]]</li> <li>[[Socrates' trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <li>You If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Warry, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/14y7CIKdDLLkfO4USQ27ULgUED5nWpiim/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter </a>of John Warry's <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> focuses on the military history of the Peloponnesian War.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strategies, strengths, and weaknesses of Athens in the Peloponnesian War</li> <li>Features of the political landscape of competing superpowers (Athens, Sparta, Persia)</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswa3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pericleswa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Pericles' famous "Funeral Oration" |funeral-oration]]</li> <li>[[A popular, bawdy comedy about the Peloponnesian War |lysistrata]]</li> <li>[[Socrates' trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Roman slaves did grueling labor on the <em>latifundia</em> of wealthy patricians, producing commodities such as olives, grapes, wheat, cattle, sheep. The experience of enslavement differed widely in Rome. Some slaves lived in appallingly brutal, dehumanizing conditions. While an owner could legally kill their slaves, stoic philosophy made it fashionable for elite Romans to treat their slaves humanely. As the philosopher Seneca wrote to a friend in the first century CE: "You say, 'But I have no master.' You are young. Things change. Perhaps you will have one. Do you not know how old Hecuba was when she became a captive? Or Croesus?..." (In other words, treat others as you wish to be treated because anyone can become a slave at any time.) But Seneca was speaking of a lofty ideal. Reality was often unimaginably brutal, especially in the mines. Bloody revolts broke out frequently. On the other hand, some slaves lived very well (especially the literate and well-educated), and many were freed by owners who realized it was more useful to have a loyal client who could vote and do business, than a slave with no legal identity of his own. People typically fell into slavery through debt, crime, or conquest. It was common for a Gaul to sell one of his countrymen to a Roman in exchange for an amphora of good Italian wine. A human life was (is?) sometimes heartbreakingly cheap.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Thrace's aristocracy had a strong tradition of hunting on horseback. Thracian horsemen had a reputation for excellence on the battlefield, and were sought after by Roman generals for service as auxilliaries. Ancient sources suggest that Spartacus was a Thracian cavalryman who had served in the auxilliaries and fought under Roman command. One story says that Spartacus' passion for horses led him to slaughter his own favorite horse at the beginning of his last desperate battle with Rome, as a symbol of his commitment to victory or death. Nobody's sure about that story ... who knows?. Spartacus did fight on foot in that last battle, and his body was never found.</p> <p><img src="images/thracian.jpg" alt="carving of horseman with spear above dog attacking boar" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Relief of Thracian hunter on horseback with spear and dogs, pursuing boar</p> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a wealthy Roman</h1> <p>Italy, 78 CE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pompeii-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "pompeii-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>The sounds of building ricochet through the air: sawing, hammering, chiseling, digging. In the background, the slow chant of slaves carrying blocks of stone. You edge away from the burning sun, into the shade of the newly-constructed, empty house. Seeing the new <em>domus</em> so complete, with walls and roof and windows, fills you with a delicious sense of contenment. You reach out and touch the nearest wall, then frown as you notice that some of the wet paint has stuck to your fingertips, smudging the foliar border framing a bright red frescoe of <<linkappend "a handsome woman playing a kithara.">><<include pompeii-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> This will be the <em>triclinium</em>. The floor is bare and empty, waiting for a tile mosaic. Maybe a lively Nile River or dockyard scene there? And what about the other walls? You need to decide how to decorate the other walls and floors.</p> <p>You think of the frescoes and mosaics in your neighbor's house: <<linkappend "everything from stories of the gods to exotic African animals to flowers and fruit.">><<include "pompeii-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2">><</linkappend>> They're an old patrician family, though, and your parents were slaves. Well-educated, literate, and highly capable, your father was freed by his owner, an old senator. As a free man, your father prospered wthin the political and financial network of his former owner. You and your children remain fiercely loyal to the old senator's heirs, and you grow richer all the time. Still, your parents were nobody and you'll never have the power or prestige of your patrician neighbors - and they'll never let you forget it. But still, there's no reason a pleb as rich as you should live in a hovel. You sigh, moving slowly back outside and savouring again that feeling of contentment. The <em>domus</em> is all but done. What to paint on these walls?</p> <p>You look out toward Pompeii. Your home clings to the lovely slopes of Mount Vesuvius, just above the bustling town. It's 78 CE. Vespasian sits the imperial throne, carrying on the legacy of the Flavian dynasty. Life could hardly be better - if, of course, a person could live in a decent house... You glance around at the bare What would this world be without the majesty of the empire? There would be no wine, clean water, law and order, schools and plays and libraries and baths, and the <<linkappend "grand colosseum Vespasian has begun building in Rome.">><<include "Pompeii-link3">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>That's it! Your walls will celebrate the beauty and splendor of Rome! Its heritage and power and everything it stands for. Everything <em>you</em> stand for. The patricians can look down their noses at you, but you are a true Roman. That's what will go on these new, blank walls.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>History of the history</p> image <p>Caption</p> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What are some of the scenes you tell the artist to depict on your walls? What will they celebrate or reflect?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>Do you think your remodel will impact your life in any real way? Your social status or economic status or the opportunities you encounter?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>item</li> </ul> <hr> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Romans' favorite legends about themselves |roman-legends]]</li> <li>[[Frescoes and mosaics from Roman villas |villas]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[<em>Romanitas</em> |romanitas]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Rome: Republic to Empire |Rome1]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <h1>Roman Interior Design</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Wealthy Romans loved to decorate their homes with frescoes and tile mosaics and ornate lamps and furniture. I guess when you have slaves to do all the domestic labor, a house crammed full of dust-catching bric-a-brac is ... well, anyway. Suffice it to say that interior decorating was important to the Romans, and their taste was not minimalist.</p> <p>Here is a beautifully curated sample of <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/collection/228/20-frescoes-from-pompeii/" target="_blank">twenty frescoes from Pompeii</a> at the World History Encyclopedia. And here is a wonderful collection of <a href="https://www.theoi.com/Galleries.html" target="_blank">Greco-Roman frescoes and mosaics</a> representing mythological subjects at Theoi.com. In the list of galleries on this page, scroll down and browse through the three "Greco-Roman Mosaics" galleries and the "Greco-Roman Frescoes" gallery.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Themes and aethetics that wealthy Romans enjoyed</li> <li></li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompva2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompva4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pompeii Scenario |Pompeii]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Roman Legends</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The first-century CE Roman historian, Livy, begins his massive (seriously, soooo long) <em>History of Rome</em> with some of the Romans' favorite legends about themselves. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1egA_jzLJLpw8Foc2QeTvZtowYhEDGux_BKdc4HIzNEs/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">You can read some of them here.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The Roman worldview, values, gender norms, political ideology</li> <li>Roman patriotism and national identity</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pomple1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompla1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pomple2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompla2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pomple3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompla3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pomple4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompla4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Romans' favorite legends about themselves |roman-legends]]</li> <li>[[Frescoes and mosaics from Roman villas |villas]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[<em>Romanitas</em> |romanitas]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pompeii Scenario |Pompeii]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Being Roman></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Romans had a strong sense of patriotism and pride in being Roman, or <em>Romanitas</em>. At the core of <em>Romanitas</em> were virtues like patriotism, gravity, piety, courage, fortitude, chastity or sexual virtue, etc. But all this striving for Roman virtue occurred alongside a robust appetite for Roman luxury, opulence, and pleasures. This article on <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rZ6GgqNm2e1vdNuVZxOtkH4oR9bHJX0L/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank"> "Pleasures and Excess in the Roman Empire"</a> explores Roman notions of living the good life.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Lifestyle and leisure of wealthy Romans</li> <li>The practical, social, and symbolic functions of a Roman villa</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompre1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompra1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompre2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompra2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompre3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompra3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompre4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$pompra4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The Romans' favorite legends about themselves |roman-legends]]</li> <li>[[Frescoes and mosaics from Roman villas |villas]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[<em>Romanitas</em> |romanitas]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pompeii Scenario |Pompeii]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><h1>Our History Rewrite</h1> <img src="images/open-book-fantasy.jpg" alt="open book with castle, forest, pegasus growing from pages" width="100%"> <p>Could history have happened differently? Would the present be different? What will the future hold? It's up to you!</p> <p>If you're done with this week's role play assignment, find the portal below and enter to see what everyone else has written. Play around with these alternative histories and be ready to discuss some of the following prompts when we meet in class. (Note: You need a password to open each of these portals. You will receive the weekly password in Canvas after submitting the role play response.)</p> <ul> <li>Compare the choices you and your classmates made. Evaluate similarities and differences.</li> <li>Consider the differences in outcomes for the individual and for their community or society. When did decisions and outcomes have similar impacts for the individual and their society? When were the impacts different? Why?</li> <li>Did you notice any recurring themes in the power dynamics that dictate individuals' choices and shape their interactions? These factors might include knowledge and skills, gender, socio-economic status, political context, ideology and belief, geography, environment and natural resources. Which were most impactful?</li> <li>Overall, explore some comparisons between the kinds of choices individuals faced in history and the kinds of choices we face today. What are some similarities? What are some difference? Why? What do you think the future holds for individuals in the West and for Western Civilization as a whole?</li> </ul> <h2 class="center">History Rewrite Portals</h2> <div class="center"> <div Back to [[Our History Rewrite]]</p> <</if>><<set $beginCombat1 to "">> <<set $ironCombat1 to "">> <<set $greeceCombat1 to "">> <<set $rome1Combat1 to "">> <<set $rome2Combat1 to "">> <<set $vikingCombat1 to "">> <<set $knightsCombat1 to "">> <<set $peasCombat1 to "">> <<set $renCombat1 to "">> /* stats */ .stats { line-height: 1; background-color: #e6f9ff; border: 2px solid #004d66; color: black; align-content: center; text-align: center; border-radius: 15px; margin: 20px; padding: 10px; } <p>As you play, you will:</p> <ul> <li><span class="bi">Save evidence</span> from primary and secondary sources. Paste these notes into your role play assignment in Canvas.</li> <li><span class="bi">Fight</span> fallacious statements about history.</li> <li><span class="bi">Explore </span> curious corners of history</li> </ul> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/codex-manesse_joust.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of knights jousting" width="80%">' "begin-combat2">><</link>> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/14pRTSYsukVY-_n1gP46wMUqavyVNAlHz/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from the book, <em>Moment of Battle</em> provides an in-depth analysis of the Battle of Adrianople, setting it within the broader context of Rome's collapse in the fourth century and its relationship with the advancing barbarian tribes. Overall, the authors argue that the empire's epic loss at Adrianople results from two root causes: 1) the incompetence of the emperor Valens as a military leader, and 2) the fact that by this time, the Roman legions had lost the professionalism, rigorous training, discipline, and resulting tactical maneuverability that had been the foundation of Rome's success in past centuries.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the Romans and the Germans</li> <li>Key decisions and turning-point moments or events</li> <li>Technology, equipment, weapons used by each side</li> <li>Motivations and goals of the leaders on each side of the battle</li> <li>How the battle fits into the broader narrative of "the fall of Rome"</li> </ul> .arches { display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: flex-end; text-align: center; background-image: url("images/hallway.jpg"); background-repeat: no-repeat; background-position: center; background-size: 100%; border: solid 4px black; } function cpyGT() { var copyText = document.getElementById("copygt").innerHTML; copyText.select(); copyText.setSelectionRange(0, 99999); navigator.clipboard.writeText(copyText.value); } <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> &#169; Copyright Abigail Queen. June 2024. .question { background-color: #e6f9ff; border: 2px solid #004d66; color: black; border-radius: 15px; margin: 40px; padding: 10px; } inventory grid <div class="container inv"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <<div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> <div class="col-2 invbox"> </div> </div> </div> old question/explore passage: <div class="container question"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-5 door"> <img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="300px"> </div> <div class="col-2" id="sourcedoorstext"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore and boost your score, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-5 door"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="300px">' "GT3">><</link>> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <h3>Question text</h3> <<linkreplace"Correct response">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<set $win to true>>Correct response feedback<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace"Incorrect response 1">>Incorrect response 1 feedback<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace"Incorrect response 2">>Incorrect response 2 feedback<</linkreplace>> </div> </div> combat passage: <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Presentism Poltergeist!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="row"> <p>It says: "Many neolithic forager societies rejected the new agraran, sedentary lifestyle because they disapproved of the negative environmental impacts resulting from agriculture and urban growth."</p> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this facile nonsense?</p> <label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "A">> This is false. Forager societies eagerly embraced the innovations of the neolithic revolution.</label> <label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "B">> While some forager societies persisted in their traditional lifestyle during the Neolithic Revolution, there is no evidence that they made this choice out of concern for human impacts on the environment.</label> <label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "C">> This seems plausible, since evidence shows that people were concerned about the environmental impacts of rising human population density in neolithic settlements.</label> </div> </div> <<if $beginCombat1 is "B">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Presentism Poltergeist and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <<linkreplace "Longbow">><<run $Inventory.push("Longbow")>>\<</linkreplace>> <<linkreplace "Chain mail">><<run $Inventory.push("Chain mail")>>\<</linkreplace>> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>Continue on. link to begin</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <<else if $beginCombat1 is "A">> <p>You have been defeated by the Presentism Poltergeist. Better luck next time.</p> <p>Continue on. link to begin</p> <</if>> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Presentism Poltergeist!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> <p>It says: "Many neolithic forager societies rejected the new agraran, sedentary lifestyle because they disapproved of the negative environmental impacts resulting from agriculture and urban growth."</p> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this facile nonsense?</p> <ul> <li><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "A">> This is false. Forager societies eagerly embraced the innovations of the neolithic revolution.</label></li> <li><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "B">><<set $Score to $Score + 5>> While some forager societies persisted in their traditional lifestyle during the Neolithic Revolution, there is no evidence that they made this choice out of concern for human impacts on the environment.</label></li> <li><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombat1" "C">> This seems plausible, since evidence shows that people were concerned about the environmental impacts of rising human population density in neolithic settlements.</label></li> </ul> <button to anchor id div spoils below </div> <div class="row" id="spoils"> </div> </div> .combat-box { background-color: #e6f9ff;
