Remember that this assignment requires evidence from at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</p> <div class="container"> <table class="table table-striped table-bordered"> <thead> <tr> <th scope="col" class="top">Source</th> <th scope="col" class="top">Evidence: Detail, quote</th> <th scope="col" class="top">Analysis: Reflections, notes</th> <th scope="col" class="top">Citation</th> </tr> </thead> <tbody> <tr> <th scope="row" class="table-intro">This will show the title of the source</th> <td class="table-intro">This column will show a quote or detail you collected in the "marginalia" panel</td> <td class="table-intro">This column will show the analysis or notes you paired with this qoute or detail in the "marginalia" panel</td> <td class="table-intro">This column shows how you can cite the source at the end of the sentence.</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td><<print $GTP_e1>></td> <td><<print $GTP_a1>></td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row">source var</th> <td>evidence var</td> <td>analysis var</td> <td>citation var</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> </div> <p>These quotes and notes will be displayed for you on the Victory! screen, along with a copy button so that you can drop them directly into your Canvas assignment as the foundation of this week's Role Play response.</p> <<if ($beginCombat1 is "done") and ($beginCombat1 isnot "")>> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Beginning]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-md"> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h1>Combat!</h1> <p>This creature throws some hysterical history at you. It says, "During the Neolithic Revolution, people switched from a forager lifestyle to an agrarian one because farming provided more food, leisure, and safety."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Defeat this creature by choosing the best response to its nonsense:</p> <div class="row scenario"> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ1" "A">> There's so much wrong with this statement. Perhaps most glaring is this conflation of "people" with "a person." It's classic, old fashioned positivism. In an effort to cobble together a grand metanarrative with convenient "lessons" about humanity, it makes unwarranted generalizations about individuals' decisions. It's a teleological mess with very shaky foundations in any actual evidence.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ1" "B">> Honestly, it doesn't sound that wrong. Agrarian societies <em>did</em> have more food than forager societies, and probably more leisure and safety too, in various ways. The statement seems plausible as it stands.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ1" "C">> Based on current scholarship, this statement is simply wrong. First, neolithic agrarian societies were as violent (i.e., dangerous) as forager societies. Second, for a neolithic individual, farming was more laborious than foraging. Food shortages were common. Based on the existing evidence as it is known today, neolithic farmers had <em>less</em> food and leisure than neolithic foragers, not more.</label></p> </div> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "begin-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if $beginCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Beginning]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic about neolithic rev)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$beginCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "begin-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($gtExploreQ1 is "A") and ($gtExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $gtExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Good choice!</p> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |GT]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |GT]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $gtExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |GT]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Based on the evidence available today, it seems most likely that the Egyptian pyramids were built by:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ1" "A">>Ordinary Egyptians</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ1" "B">>Aliens</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ1" "C">>Hebrew slaves</label></p> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "gt-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if $gtExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |GT]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Based on the evidence available today, text was first developed to:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ2" "A">>Record mythology and religious beliefs</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ2" "B">>Preserve historical records</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$gtExploreQ2" "C">>Record business transactions</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "gt-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><div class="container tips"> <div class="row"> <p>Historians works within certain ideological parameters and make use of discipline-specific methodologies and terminology. These tips and suggestions will help you approach this role play assignment as a historian.</p> <p>These same role play prompts might be approached differently in a different class (like an English or Creative Writing class, or Psychology or Sociology) or for a different purpose. This is a History class, so we will be using an approach defined by discipline-specific standards that align with how historians work today.</p> <hr> <h3>Tip 1: Historical Realism</h3> <p>Strive for historical realism by avoiding presentism and anachronism.</p> <ul> <li><span class="bi">Avoid presentism:</span> Your character wouldn't have your foreknowledge of what happened next in history. Try to avoid basing their decisions or feelings on knowledge of the future they would not have had.</li> <li><span class="bi">Avoid anachronism:</span> Your beliefs and values in the 21st-century U.S. are often very different from those of your historical character. (For instance, we tend to have strong beliefs in ideas of social justice, equality, the intrinsic value of a human life, the importance of environmental stewardship. Such ideologies were rare in the past.) Try to avoid basing their decisions or feelings on your own values and beliefs, which may not have existed back then. I know this is basically impossible, but give it a try?</li> </ul> <hr> <h3>Tip 2: Get Creative!</h3> <p>Be creative and authentic! Bring your own genuine personality into this adventure. For instance: "I tend to enjoy working with others, so I would ...", or "I am a good artist, so ...", or "I am physically strong, so I would ...", or "As a cisgender woman, I would probably ..." Alternatively, you could just go wild with role play and completely re-imagine yourself with different skills, personality traits, gender identity, sexuality, age, etc.</p> <p>If you feel drawn in to the world-building aspect of all this, you might want to give your role play character a background that imparts special skills or knowledge, or even a challenge to overcome. For example:</p> <ul> <li>Reading or writing: We tend to take this for granted in our 21st-century text-saturated lives, but in most of human history, these were specialty skills.</li> <li>Second languages: Maybe they were raised at a trading post and picked up a few languages.</li> <li>Hunting or fishing skills</li> <li>Fighting: Maybe they are physically big and agile. Maybe they grew up in a community in which violence was normal, and they're used to physical fights. Maybe they were a mercenary for a while.</li> <li>Metallurgy: Maybe their father was a smith</li> <li>Medicine or poison: Maybe they were raised by their grandmother who was the community's healer.</li> <li>A different ability: Maybe they were born with physical or mental limitations that are unusual.</li> </ul> <hr> <h3>Tip 3: Step-By-Step</h3> <p>Here's a suggested workflow for completing these weekly assignments.</p> <ol> <li>This is the part you've already done: Start playing the Role Play game! Enjoy learning some new things and thinking some thoughts.</li> <li>Next, look through the primary and secondary sources. Use the "maginalia" panels to save evidence and analysis.</li> <li>Copy and paste your marginalia notes into a document or directly into the Canvas assignment text editor. Edit. Proofread and revise. Submit. Celebrate.</li> <li><span class="bi">It doesn't have to be perfect! </span> If you look at the grading rubric in Canvas, you'll notice that you can an ok score on the assignment just by submitting the Victory! page screenshot and your marginalia notes.</li> </ol> </div> </div> <<if ($gtExploreQ2 is "C") and ($gtExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $gtExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Yes. You don't need writing to pass down legends, myths, or history (at least not in ancient times). Oral traditions work fine for that. But you <em>do</em> want a physical record as proof of business transactions. Nice work! Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |GT]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |GT]]</p> <</if>><<set $Score to "">> <<set $sword to false>> <<set $book to false>> <<set $bow to false>> <<set $chalice to false>> <<set $gold to false>> <<set $helmet to false>> <<set $lance to false>> <<set $lyre to false>> <<set $potion to false>> <<set $ring to false>> <<set $shield to false>> <<set $treasure to false>> <<set $armor to false>> <<set $horse to false>> <<if $Password is "Beowulf">> <div class="container"> <div class="row starthero"> <div class="title-sub"> <h1>Welcome, Time Traveler!</h1> <p>Venture into the past. Make some history.</p> <p>To begin your role play adventure, enter the name you would like to use on this journey:</p><<textbox "$PlayerName" "" "Portals">> </div> </div> <hr> <p>If you're already done with this week's role play assignment, open [[Our History Rewrite]] to explore the new history you and your comrades have created. This is where it gets really fun... </p> </div> <<else>> <p>The password is incorrect. [[Go back. |Password]]</p> <</if>> <div class="title-box"> <h1>A forager at Gobekli Tepe</h1> <p>Anatolia, c. 11,000 BCE</p> </div> <p>It's almost springtime in the hills of Anatolia when your migratory forager clan happens upon an interesting community. They have a permanent settlement with walls and homes and irrigated gardens. They have beer!</p> <p>They seem very busy with their livestock and crops and buildings. There's just so much <span class="em">stuff.</span> Junk everywhere. It all looks exhausting. And when they do have free time, they like to spend it working on an <<linkappend "insanely huge thing.">><<include gt-link1>><</linkappend>> Massive walls and pillars, carved and painted with animals and human figures. You've never seen <<linkappend "anything like this.">><<include gt-link2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Over the next few days, other forager groups like your own start drifting into the area. They work together on the big buildings. Everyone seems to have a job - making ropes, preparing food, carrying rock, fetching water and firewood, carving stone, repairing tools, digging ditches. There's a powerful energy you enjoy, but also, people get bossy, pointing and commanding. Fights break out. Your group is invited to form a team and work on transporting the big stones. That evening, your band gathers around a fire and considers this decision. When it's your turn to speak, what do you say?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |gt-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |gt-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |gt-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |gt-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |gt-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: In the Beginning Rewrite |Begin-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>A scribe in Old Babylon</h1> <p>Mesopotamia, c. 1700 BCE</p> </div> <p>It's c. 1700 BCE in Babylon during the reign of Hammurabi. You are a young scribe in the <<linkappend "palace complex.">> <<include "babylon-link1">> <</linkappend>> Life is miserable. You are bored and angry, exhausted from doing chores and trying to learn this impossible script while dodging beatings from your teachers and hazing from the older boys. Everyone tells you how lucky you are, how great your city's gods and king are. They love stories like the <<linkappend "Epic of Gilgamesh.">> <<include "babylon-link2">> <</linkappend>></p> <p>You don't buy it. Gilgamesh is an idiotic thug, like basically everyone who tells you what to do all day (which is a lot of people). Risking a major beating, you steal some clay tablets from the priests. In the weak light of the quiet, pre-dawn hours, you start writing a new version of that idiotic story about the whole Gilgamesh bromance. You hide the tablets in a niche under your sleeping mat. In your story, Gilgamesh gets what he deserves.</p> <p>One morning when you reach for your tablets, your heart freezes and time stops as your fingers find only empty space. Wtf who took it they are going to kill me. If I'm lucky. You look around and see a form hunched over in the dim predawn grey. You approach slowly. It's your best friend. He's holding your tablets, and he's crying. He hugs you and begs to join your Gilgamesh rewrite. Soon, others young scribes join, and a genuine conspiracy begins. This isn't a game any more. They all have colorful ideas for revenge on the palace elite. You find yourselves plotting to overthrow the regime and seize power for yourselves.</p> <p>Do you want to stay and get involved because this is kind of amazing (plus, the beer)? Or do you want to pack up and head for the hills because following orders and doing manual labor is just not your style. Analyze the factors that determine your choice. What fears, desires, relationships, realities motivated you?</p> <p>Your group agrees with you and follows your advice. Predict some short term and long term outcomes of this choice for you as an individual, and for your community.</p> <hr> [[student1 choice |babylon-rewrite1]] [[student2 choice |babylon-rewrite2]] [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Babylon]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The word "Mesopotamia" is:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ1" "A">>from the Greek words for "between" and "rivers."</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ1" "B">>from Akkadian names for flood deities.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$babylonExploreQ1" "C">>based on the Hebrew Bible's negative perspective on the city of Babylon.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "babylon-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($babylonExploreQ1 is "A") and ($babylonExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $babylonExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The Hebrews' religion:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ2" "A">>allowed them to assimilate easily into different societies.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ2" "B">>created a uniquely pacifist society totally averse to warfare.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$assyriaExploreQ2" "C">>created a strong national identity that survived conquest and displacement.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "assyria-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($assyriaExploreQ2 is "C") and ($assyriaExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $assyriaExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Assyria]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <h1>The Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser II</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Around 825 BCE, this massive stone stele is covered with praise for the mighty Assyrian king, Shalmaneser II, and his god, Assur. We are unsurprised that descriptions of conquest and dominion predominate. Also, crossing the Euphrates was a <em>really</em> big deal and is mentioned as frequently as possible.</p> <p><a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/W_1848-1104-1">View the obelisk</a> at the British Museum here.</p> <p><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vQ-FT5C94ih1hN9CexBwH9iE63ekfcXiKTF-kCFjna0YtorBrf0Csavn5VjtecXeo-LdyCGhYiAydRm/pub">Read the inscriptions here.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Leadership in the Assyrian empire and military</li> <li>Typical activities and goals of the Assyrian military</li> <li>Tools and technology used by the Assyrian military</li> <li>Assyrian religious outlook</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. .</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$assyboe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$assyboa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$assyboe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$assyboa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$assyboa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Assyrian Palace Art |friezes]]</li> <li>[[The Black Obelisk of Shalmaneser III |obelisk]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Secondary source |mil-empire]]</li> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |assyrian-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Assyrian Army Scenario |Assyria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Assyrian Palace Friezes</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>When we think of the Assyrians, we tend to think of a brutally harsh regime built on unstoppable military might. And we aren't wrong. But (you knew that was coming, right?) ... <em>but...</em> they had a softer side, reflected in their obvious appreciation of beautiful artwork. Their stone walls of their palaces were alive with vibrantly painted, intricately detailed bas-relief carvings (or friezes). Of course, their favorite themes were grim and gruesome (war, hunting, domination), but still ... they were a little artsy. Given a choice, maybe they'd go for impaling people on spikes and shooting lions, but they were also capable of appreciating beautiful artwork (also, they were enthusiastic bibliophiles with massive libraries! Wow!). Human nature is so complex, eh?</p> <p>Here are some images from the ruins of the great palaces, mostly from Nineveh and Nimrud, c. 800 - 600 BCE.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vR4GLD4fqwhk7xWUtWCUjUN4JiKmC46bMpnXSsrRXi2es39m5IbOHEuZxNcH0NQAYOMxPrN3IXJLEuS/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="569" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Tools, technology, wepons used by the Assyrian military</li> <li>Organization, specialized units, and hierarchy in the Assyrian military and state</li> <li>Assyrian imperialist methods of control</li> <li>Military tactics (battlefield maneuvers) and strategies (big picture things like logistics, communication, finance, international relations)</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. .</p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div |assyrian-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Assyrian Army Scenario |Assyria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Chaliand, The First Military Empire</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href=target="_blank">This book chapter</a> from Chaliand, <em>A Global History of War</em> presents the Assyrian Empire as the first military empire in history.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Leadership in the Assyrian empire and military</li> <li>Typical activities and goals of the Assyrian military</li> <li>Tools and technology used by the Assyrian military</li> <li>Assyrian religious outlook</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. |assyrian-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Assyrian Army Scenario |Assyria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Iron Age Empires</p> <p><img src="images/ironage.jpg" alt="chariot" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Sayce, <em>Babylonian and Assyrian Literature</em>, in Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 110, Instructor: Queen, accessed [date]</p><</if>> <<if (def $assyce1) and ($assyce1 isnot "")>><p>Gérard Chaliand, <em>A Global History of War</em> (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2019)</p><</if>> <<if (def $assyse1) and ($assyse1 isnot "")>><p>Simon Anglim et al., <em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World, 3000 BC - AD 500: Equipment, Combat Skills, and Tactics</em> (New York: St Martin's Press, 2002)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyAssyrs()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Friezes from the Assyrian palaces at Nimrud and Nineveh, c. 800 - 600 BCE (note: originally they were painted)</p> <p>The Assyrian army crossing the Euphrates with the help of some impressive Phoenician galleys</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-galleys" alt="stone carving of double-decker galley ship with shields" width="100%"></p> <p>Here they are on the river again, transporting lumber and surrounded by a wealth of natural resources.<p> <p><img src="images/assyria-river" alt="stone carving of ships towing logs across water full of aquatic creatures" width="100%"></p> <p>And here are some of their enemies fleeing Assyrian archers by crossing the river on flotation devices made of inflated goat skins.</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-goatfloaties" alt="stone carving of men crossing a river to a fort, pursued by archers" width="100%"></p> <p>So: goat floaties or double-decker galleys? Hmmm ... it's pretty clear who has more style on the water. This was a favorite theme for Assyrian artists and authors.</p> <p>You can find these images of the Assyrian palace friezes at the British Museum (if you're ever in London, a visit to the the museum's Assyria gallery is an absolute must).<a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/galleries/assyria-nimrud" target="_blank">The British Museum</p> </div> <div class="link"> <p>Friezes from the Assyrian palaces at Nimrud and Nineveh, c. 800 - 600 BCE (note: originally they were painted)</p> <p>Gore and glory: Ancient art and literature often reflects a keen awareness of the dichotomous nature of victory and death. Success appears alongside failure. One side must lose if another is to win. The Assyrian palace friezes show no concern for whitewashing the grim realities of military success. The gore appears alongside the glory. They are one and the same.</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-vulture-cavalry" alt="chariot with vulture grasping entrils above" width="100%"></p> <p><img src="images/assyria-corpse-margins" alt="chariots fighting with decapitated corpses decorating margins" width="100%"></p> <p>The fruits of victory</p> <p><img src="images/assyria-feast" alt="people reclining and feasting" width="100%"></p> <p><img src="images/assyria-victory" alt="troops presenting captives who kneel before the ruler" width="100%"></p> <p>You can find these images of the Assyrian palace friezes at the British Museum (if you're ever in London, a visit to the the museum's Assyria gallery is an absolute must).<a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/galleries/assyria-nimrud" target="_blank">The British Museum</p> </div> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: In the Beginning</p> <p><img src="images/pyramids_leonardo-ramos_unsplash.jpg" alt="pyramids" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if ($beginCombatQ1 is "A") and ($beginCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $beginCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Quite so! Nice work! Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<elseif ($beginCombatQ1 is "B") and ($beginCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <p>You are right that agrarian societies produced more food than forager societies, overall. However, on an individual basis, farming often offered less food and more work. Current scholarship supports the idea that, "The Agricultural Revolution certainly enlarged the sum total of food at the disposal of humankind, but the extra food did not translate to a better diet or more leisure. Rather, it translated into population explosions and pampered elites. The average farmer worked harder than the average forager, and got a worse diet in return. The Agricultural Revolution was history's biggest fraud." (Harari, <em>Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind</em>). That's a fairly extreme thesis, but even more moderate positions fall short of imagining that daily life for individual neolithic farmers was easier or more bountiful than life for of a neolithic foragers.</p> <p>Better luck next time! [[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<elseif ($beginCombatQ1 is "C") and ($beginCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $beginCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Absolutely. Scholarship on this history changes dramatically and rapidly, so we can expect to hear new theories soon. But, as of today, you are quite correct. Victory has boosted your score by 5. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Beginning]]</p> <</if>> <<if ($beginCombatQ2 is "A") and ($beginCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $beginCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Beginning]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Beginning]]</p> <</if>><<if $ironCombat1 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Iron]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Here's your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to this creature's questionable statements about history.</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says, "Civilizations in environments with the correct amount of environmental stress factors were able to develop new technologies which led to growth and advancement. Civilizations in overly harsh environments (like the Arctic) or overly comfortable environments (like the tropics) failed to innovate and grow. Those in difficult environments had no leisure to take risks or invest resources in innovation; they were struggling to simply survive. Those with too bountiful an envirnoment had no reason to take risks or invest resources in innovation. The correct amount of environmental stress is necessary for civilizations to advance."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>So first, stop laughing. Be serious. Distinguished persons with alphabet soups after their names and ponderous academic titles have written stuff like this in the past. Titanic, towering scholarly figures like Toynbee and von Ranke have written much in this vein. And even though academia has moved on, some folks still carry on mouthing these kinds of happy platitudes today.</p> <p>So, let's keep this civil and simple. Briefly, how would you categorize the fallacy in this creature's thesis?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ1" "A">>Confirmation bias</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ1" "B">>Anachronism</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ1" "C">>Tautology</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "iron-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if $ironCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Iron]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a (some mob)!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (something wrong)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this farcical gibberish?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$ironCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "iron-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($greeceCombatQ1 is "B") and ($greeceCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $greeceCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Presentism Poltergeist and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Greece]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Presentism Poltergeist. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Greece]]</p> <</if>> <<if $greeceCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Greece]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$greeceCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "greece-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Spartan warriors were legendary for their military invincibility. The city of Sparta proudly stood without defensive fortifications - an anomaly in the Greek world - because (the Spartans liked to boast) its army was the only defense it needed. But Sparta depended on the labor of a large class of slaves called Helots. These indigenous inhabitants of the Peloponnesus had been enslaved by the Spartans when they conquered the region during the Archaic Period.</p> <p><img src="images/hoplites-lycia-c390.jpg" alt="frieze of hoplite soldiers in combat" width="100%"></p> <p><a href=https://www.worldhistory.org/image/3012/greek-hoplites-fighting/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Athens was developing a more includive, democratic political culture, while Sparta was staunchly conservative and oligarchic. These differences coincide with the differing military and economic orientation of each city state. Athenian power increasingly depended on maritime trade and naval power - in other words, merchants and rowers whose humble economic status might have barred them from political participation in prevoius generations, but who now demanded an equal say in keeping with their importance to their polis' wellbeing. Spartan power, on the other hand, remained tied to the invincibility of its traditional hoplite phalanxes. Their conservative, oligarchic system produced this unstoppable fighting force. Sparta began to view Athenian democracy as a threat to its survival - especially these ideas about expanding the franchise to people who did not serve in the army. So when Athens showed up to help Sparta crush (yet another) Helot uprising in xx, Spartan leaders thanked them and sent them home immediately, fearing the spread of democratic ideas.</p> <p><img src="images/thebes-vase-ship.jpg" alt="vase painted with trireme" width="100%"></p> <p>A trireme on a ceramic bowl from Thebes, c. 735 BCE (<a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/G_1899-0219-1" target="_blank">British Museum</a>)</p> </div><<if $helotExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Helot]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>As historical sources, Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em> tell us most about:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ1" "A">>Dark Age and Archaic Greece</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ1" "B">>Bronze Age and Mycenaean Greece</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ1" "C">>Persia</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "helot-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($helotExploreQ1 is "A") and ($helotExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $helotExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Helot]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Helot]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $helotExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Helot]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Hoplite culture included:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ2" "A">>an emphasis on the role of cavalry in battle.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ2" "B">>equality for women.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$helotExploreQ2" "C">>citizen soldiers.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "helot-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($helotExploreQ2 is "C") and ($helotExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $helotExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Helot]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Helot]]</p> <</if>><p>This game was created by Abigail Queen using the Twine interactive fiction platform and the SugarCube story format. References:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://twinery.org/" target="_blank">Twinery.org</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.motoslave.net/sugarcube/2/docs/" target="_blank">SugarCube2</a></li> <li><a href="http://www.motoslave.net/tweego/" target="_blank">Tweego Compiler</a></li> <li><a href="https://manonamora.itch.io/twine-sugarcube-guide" target="_blank">SugarCube Guide by ManonAmora</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlXuD3kyVEr5JmCL3GbEAd0jPsDVcuge7" target="_blank">SugarCube2 tutorials by Dan Cox</a></li> </ul> <p>Images are open source educational files or free downloads from the following creators:</p> <ul> <li>From <a href="https://pixaby.com" target="_blank">Pixaby.com: </a>Momentmal, lunar-sea-art, AlanFrijns, ELG21, FaceGuy</li> <li>From <a href="https://unsplash.com" target="_blank">Unsplash.com: </a>annie-spratt, Max Tcvetkov, Sabina Sturzu, Leonardo Ramos, Jason Hogan</li> <li>Others to be posted...</li> </ul> [[About]]<div class="container"> <h1>Cartledge, <em>The Spartans</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1aoC5XmlKl6jql0Od_si9b5AT0widOKEV/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from Paul Cartledge's wonderful book, <em>The Spartans: An Epic History,</em> examines the situation of women in Sparta.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Forces of oppression faced by Helots</li> <li>Methods of resistance the Helots employed</li> <li>The role of the Helots in Spartan society</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div in Sparta |cartledge-women]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal|Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Helot Scenario |Helot]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1><em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1B0ThpyziLnMWirjnCrGuYQ8H1jnCH71K/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This section</a> of Anglim et al., <em>Fighting Techniques of the Ancient World, 3000 BC - AD 500: Equipment, Combat Skills, and Tactics</em> focuses on Assyrian siege warfare, with a case study of Lachish.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Coming just after Herodotus, his is the earliest surviving written history in the world. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dq0xwM2O57VbyoZ-T6NYLyVtMveG9Ei8/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this chapter </a> of her book about Thucydides' <em>History of the Peloponnesian War,</em> historian Mary Nichols examines Thucydides' treatment of Alcibiades and the Sicilian Expedition.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Details of the military, political, and ideological conflicts in Athens at this time</li> <li>Limits and uncertainties in our knowledge of Alcibiades' character, motives, and actions</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnte1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnta1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnte2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnta2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnte3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnta3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnte4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$periclesnta4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Pericles' famous "Funeral Oration" |funeral-oration]]</li> <li>[[A popular, bawdy comedy about the Peloponnesian War |lysistrata]]</li> <li>[[Socrates' trial and execution |apology]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Military history of the Peloponnesian War |warry-sicily]]</li> <li>[[About Thucydides' account of Sicily and Alcibiades |nichols-thucydides]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Greece-victory-p]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> <li>[[Back: Pericles Scenario |Pericles]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Ancient Greece</p> <p><img src="images/greece1.jpg" alt="warriors with spear and shield" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copypericles"> <<if (def $pericleslyse1) and ($pericleslyse1 isnot "")>><p><<print $pericleslyse1>> (Aristophanes, <em>Lysistrata</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $pericleslysa1) and ($pericleslysa1 isnot "")>><p><<print $pericleslysa1>> <<if (def $pericleslyse4) and ($pericleslyse4 isnot "")>><p><<print $pericleslyse4>>(Aristophanes, <em>Lysistrata</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $pericleslysa4) and ($pericleslysa4 isnot "")>><p><<print
