Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copypericless"> <<if (def $pericleslyse1) and ($pericleslyse1 isnot "")>><p>Aristophanes, <em>Lysistrata</em>, in Perry, <em>Sources of the Western Tradition, Volume 1: from Ancient Times to the Enlightenment, Eighth Edition</em> (Boston: Wadsworth, 201</p><</if>> <<if (def $periclessoce1) and ($gtmgte1 isnot "")>> <p>Plato, <em>Apology</em>, transl. Walter Hamilton, in Bernard Knox, ed., <em>The Norton Book of Classical Literature</em> (New York: Norton, 1993)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $periclesfoe1) and ($periclesfoe1 isnot "")>><p>Thucydides, <em>History of the Peloponnesian War,</em> transl. R. Crawley, Internet Classics Archive, https://classics.mit.edu/Thucydides/pelopwar.2.second.html, accessed [date] </p><</if>> <<if (def $pericleswe1) and ($pericleswe1 isnot "")>><p>John Warry, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> (Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2002)</p><</if>> <<if (def $periclesnte1) and ($periclesnte1 isnot "")>><p>Mary Nichols, <em>Thucydides and the Pursuit of Freedom</em> (New York: Cornell University Press, 2015)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyPers()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Portal |Greece]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<if $periclesExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Pericles]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The Battles of Salamis and Thermopylae:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ1" "A">>were unable to thwart Persia's conquest of Greece.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ1" "B">>convinced Alexander the Great to end his expansion into the east.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ1" "C">>are now believed to be legends with little basis in historical fact.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "pericles-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($periclesExploreQ1 is "A") and ($periclesExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $periclesExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Pericles]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Pericles]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $periclesExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Pericles]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In the Classical Period, a Greek polis was ruled by:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ2" "A">>a theocracy.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ2" "B">>the votes of all people.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$periclesExploreQ2" "C">>a constitution.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "pericles-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($periclesExploreQ2 is "C") and ($periclesExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $periclesExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Pericles]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Pericles]]</p> <</if>><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Spartacus' romantic partner</h1> <p>Italy, 73 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "spartacus-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "spartacus-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>It's nearly midsummer and the night is warm, even high on the peak of Mount Vesuvius. Spartacus and his captains sit around the dying fire. They've been here for hours, roasting quail, talking, arguing. A decision must be made. Spartacus wants to lead the slave army north and across the Alps, out of Rome. After all, the legions are busy with Mithridates in the East and Sertorius in the West. The mountain passes are all but deserted. But the others are delirious with victory and plunder. Camped here on Vesuvius, surrounded by <<linkappend "the richest farmland in Italy,">><<include "spartacus-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> your slave army grows bigger and richer every day. The original farmers of Campania were the citizen soldiers who built Rome generations ago. But most are long gone, crowded out by rich patricians who live in the city. Now it's just slaves and plunder in every direction.</p> <p>You hear Crixus say (again) that the longer we stay, the stronger we get. He’s not wrong, but you know Spartacus wants to leave. You watch his face in the firelight, and see the memories marching behind his eyes. Back home in Thrace, he fought for the legions. <<linkappend "Romans know the worth of Thracian cavalry, of great horsemen like Spartacus.">><<include "spartacus-link2">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> And Spartacus knows the worth of the legions. The fugitive gladiators and laborers camped down below fight like demons, and last week, they got lucky and caught a small Roman force by surprise and scored an easy victory. Now they think they're invincible. But a real legion would roll right over them like a wave up a sandy beach - effortless and inexorable - before marching back to Rome, nailing slaves to crosses along the Appian Way as an example to the rest. Crixus falls silent at last, and Spartacus' eyes focus again as others chorus agreement: Stay and fight on! Every slave in Italy will be with us by fall! And it's almost harvest time... </p> <p>From the edge of the firelight, you silently watch their faces as they argue back and forth. They attack and deflect and position and strategize, just like they used to do <<linkappend "in the arena for the entertainment of the crowd.">><<include "spartacus-link3">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> They’re using words this time, not blades, but the outcome of this skirmish is life and death nonetheless. Isn’t it always, for slaves of Rome? There’s a moment of silence, and a wolf howls nearby. They all freeze and you feel, rather than see, their gazes slide toward you. Another howl. It’s a sign. Vesuvius is sacred, a place of power. The wolf is sacred to Rome. You are a Thracian priestess, <<linkappend "a Bacchanate who serves Dionysus.">><<include "Spartacus-link4">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> These men are lethal killers, but they fear your power. You rise in one smooth, swift movement, and spin, circling the fire, moving rhythmically. Your long robe swirls, your hair flies out. The vines tattooed along your arms seem to slither in the leaping firelight. The snake coiled around your arm bobs its head in the air. No one speaks as you spin and chant, moving slowly around the circle. The circuit complete, you sink down again in your place just within the circle of light now, closer behind Spartacus than you were before. The mood lightens. They won't decide anything now. Tomorrow. And later tonight, when you and Spartacus are alone, you will tell him what to do.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Lots of vocabulary and expressions have come down to us from the Romans. I'm sure you've heard expressions like, "Time flies," (from <em>tempus volat</em>), or "Between a rock and a hard place" (from <em>a fronte pricipicium, a tergo lupi</em>, "A cliff ahead, wolves behind"). These living relics of Rome shouldn't surprise us, since Roman texts and the Latin language have served as common ground for writers from the Middle Ages to the Victorian Era. For centuries, educated people in the West learned Latin, becoming familiar with classic works of Virgil and Cicero and Ovid along the way.</p> <p>So how about the verb "decimate?" Have you ever heard something like, "That team decimated our junior varsity." The way people tend to use the word today is a bit anachronistic. They usually use it to mean "crushed, destroyed, annihilated," while it really meant "to remove 10%." Decimation was a punishment meted out to insubordinate or rebellious legions. They would be required to kill every 10th man. So, it really only meant a 10% loss, but we tend to use it today to mean something more like a major or total destruction.</p> <hr> <p>Does it bug you when people use terms with a historically specific origin, like "decimate," in a way that doesn't match their historical meaning?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Seriously, no. It's nice to know the historical meaning, but I would not lose sleep over this. First world problem.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>>Totally fair.<<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Yes. Words have power because people agree on what they mean. If people use words imprecisely, they lose their utility.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>That makes sense. But also, the meaning of words does change constantly and the world does not end. Maybe languages are dynamic systems of signification?<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey (score +2).</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Hollywood loves gladiators, for obvious reasons. The Romans would totally understand. What I don't understand is why Hollywood consistently decides to get the "thumbs up or thumbs down" thing wrong. You know, when a victorious gladiator has fought his opponent into the ground but hasn't killed them yet, the victor looks up at the patron of the games for the signal to kill the vanquished or let them go. This is where Hollywood goes all sideways on us. In the movies, "thumbs down" means "Death!" ... which makes no sense at all if you think about the logistics of what's going on there.</p> <p><img src="images/spartacus.jpg" alt="gladiators fighting in the arena" width="80%"></p> <p>(Above: From the classic film <em>Spartacus</em> in 19??)</p> <p>To the Romans, thumbs down meant "no," as in, "stop," as in, "don't kill the person you've just defeated." This makes all kinds of sense (of course it does, right?), because the thumbing person is talking to the gladiator who's victorious, so they're giving a simple "green light or red light" message. Thumbs up is for go: "Kill!" Thumbs down is red for stop: "Stop." Easy. Why Hollywood consistently mangles this is beyond my meagre understanding. They're pretty good at what they do, so there must be a reason for it. I'm just not in on the secret, and that's fine.</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"> </div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>The stakes could hardly be higher. Death (a good one if you're unreasonably lucky) on one hand, and freedom on the other. What does Spartacus decide to do? Why?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How does it go? Do you win your freedom? How and where? Do you build a new society? Or does Rome win, as usual?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>If you have children or other family to care for</li> <li>Your network of relationships within the community of fugitive slaves</li> <li>Your experience in slavery</li> <li>Your physical aptitudes and limitations</li> <li>Your knowledge and skills</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Rome: Republic to Empire |Rome1]]</li> </ul> </footer><<if $rome1Combat1 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Rome1]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Presentism Poltergeist!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: "presentism..."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ1" "A">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ1" "B">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ1" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "rome1-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($rome1CombatQ1 is "B") and ($rome1CombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $rome1Combat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Presentism Poltergeist and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Rome1]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Presentism Poltergeist. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Rome1]]</p> <</if>> <<if $rome1Combat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Rome1]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: (some dumb circular logic)</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$rome1CombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "rome1-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if $rome1CombatQ2 is "A">> <<set $rome1Combat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Rome1]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Rome1]]</p> <</if>><<if $spartacusExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Spartacus]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Roman religious practices can best be described as:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ1" "A">>diverse and eclectic.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ1" "B">>narrow and exclusive.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ1" "C">>separate from politics.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "spartacus-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($spartacusExploreQ1 is "A") and ($spartacusExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $spartacusExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Spartacus]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Spartacus]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $spartacusExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Spartacus]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>A pilum:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ2" "A">>served for one year before entering the senate.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ2" "B">>proved useless after it was adopted by the Roman legions.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$spartacusExploreQ2" "C">>was designed to disable an enemy's shield.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "spartacus-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($spartacusExploreQ2 is "C") and ($gspartacusExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $spartacusExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Spartacus]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Spartacus]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <h1>Interesting things about Gladiators</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The World History Encyclopedia has <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/gladiator/" target="_blank">a wonderful page about Roman gladiators</a>, with lots of good information and some interesting primary source images. (Note: that primary source material can count as your "primary source" for this assignment, even though it's in a secondary source).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The experience of being a gladiator, and how it would shape Spartacus' and his army's outlook, motives, skillsets</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the rebels' force compared to the Roman authorities and legions</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprse1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprsa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprse2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprsa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "sprse3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprsa3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprse4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprsa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Spartacus Scenario |Spartacus]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Strauss, <em>The Spartacus War</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vwskneZ2wgMzljVzvzgYvpaIRg7sQDKl/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from leading classicist Barry Strauss's book, <em>The Spartacus War,</em> breathes life into the enigmatic character of Spartacus, parsing the scant evidence to build a remarkably detailed portrait of the gladiator whose slave rebellion defeated legions threatened Rome itself.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The life of a gladiator</li> <li>Spartacus' background, outlook, motivations</li> <li>The context of the intial uprising at Capua</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprbse1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprbsa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprbse2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprbsa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the C. H. Oldfather, in James M. Brophy et al., eds., <em>Perspectives from the Past: Primary Sources in Western Civilization, Volume 1: From the Ancient Near East through the Age of Absolutism,</em> Fourth Edition (New York: Norton, 2009), pp. 225 - 227.</p><</if>> <<if (def $sprbse1) and ($sprbse1 isnot "")>><p>Barry Strauss, <em>The Spartacus War</em> (New York: Simon and Schuster, 2009)</p><</if>> <<if (def $sprtradee1) and ($sprtradee1 isnot "")>><p>Keith Bradley, "'The Regular, Daily Traffic in Slaves': Roman History and Contemporary History," <em>The Classical Journal</em> 87, No. 2 (1991): 125 - 138. </p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpySprs()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire |Rome1]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Plutarch, <em>Lives</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The primary source text with the most detail about Spartacus' rebellion is Plutarch's <em>Lives</em>. Although Plutarch was writing in Greece and over a century after Spartacus' death, he used sources now lost (such as Sallust). You can <a href="https://www.livius.org/sources/content/plutarch/plutarchs-crassus/plutarch-on-spartacus/">find Plutarch's account of Spartacus here.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Roman attitudes toward slaves and the uprising</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the slave army and the Roman forces</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "sprpe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpa3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprpa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Spartacus Scenario |Spartacus]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Sicilian slave revolts</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In the first century CE, the Greek historian Diodorus Siculus wrote a massive "universal history" focused on Rome. He included <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1cD45AslLbO-vBm-ZwyGetjymqw-Qdk5N/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this account </a> of a large slave uprising in Sicily in 135 BCE. It's an interesting comparison with the events of Spartacus' rebellion.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Roman attitudes toward slaves and the uprising</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the slave army and the Roman forces</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprda4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Spartacus Scenario |Spartacus]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $alexExplore1 to "">> <<set $alexExplore2 to "">> <<set $cannaeExplore1 to "">> <<set $cannaeExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="hellenistichero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Hellenistic World</h1> <p>The conquests of Alexander the Great reshaped the ancient West, creating a degree of cultural and economic unity founded on the intellectual, technological, and military acheivements of the Greeks. As Alexander's successors squabbled in the east, a new power was rising in the west: Rome.</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/greek-combat.jpg" alt="black figure pottery illustration of ancient Greek warriors fighting with shield and spear" width="80%">' "hellenistic-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[A philosopher in Alexandria |Alexandria]]</p> <p class="big">[[Attacking Rome |Cannae]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="link"> <p>Above: Marble bas relief (Rome, c. 30 BCE). <p><img src="images/gladiators-marble.jpg" alt="carving of gladiators in combat" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Marble bas relief (Rome, first century CE). <p><img src="images/gladiators-marble2.jpg" alt="carving of gladiators in combat" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Mosaic (North Africa, second century CE). <p><img src="images/gladiators-marble2.jpg" alt="mosaic of gladiators in combat" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Mosaic (Germany, second century CE). <p><img src="images/gladiators-trident.jpg" alt="mosaic of gladiators in combat" width="100%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Spartacus' female consort was Thracian, like himself. She was a priestess of Dionysus and had some role in leading the slave rebellion, making various prophecies about Spartacus' leadership. Bacchante rituals typically involved frenzied dancing, snakes, tattoos, a long staff topped with a pinecone, and long robes.</p> <p><img src="images/maenad2.jpg" alt="dancing figure" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/maenad-dance.jpg" alt="dancing figure" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/maenad-dance2.jpg" alt="dancing figure" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Maenads or Bacchante appear frequently on Greek and Roman art. It's interesting to think about the reasons for this (seeming) preference.</p> <p>It's interesting that Mount Vesuvius, where Spartacus and his army camped, was sacred to Dionysus. The fresco below, from a villa near Pompeii, shows Dionysus with his symbols, and Mount Vesuvius in the background.</p> <p><img src="images/dionysus-vesuvius.jpg" alt="figure wearing grape cloak, with attendant panther, near mountain with snake in foreground" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Rome: From Republic to Empire</p> <p><img src="images/rome1.jpg" alt="babies nursing from wolf" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire |Rome1]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><<set $adrianExplore1 to "">> <<set $adrianExplore2 to "">> <<set $askingExplore1 to "">> <<set $askingExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="rome2hero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Did Rome Fall?</h1> <p>Well, that's an impossible question. The story of Rome in late antiquity is not a linear "rise or fall" kind of narrative. It's more of a dynamic transformation So let's get know the Germanic tribes who will transform the Roman Empire into the kingdoms of modern Europe: Franks in France, Anglo-Saxons in England, and so on. It's an apocalyptic landscape littered with the ruins of an empire: crumbling roads and bridges, the odd hoard of old imperial coins, a few glass jars - the remnants of a great civilization that had fallen into memory, reminding everyone that life on earth is transitory and brief, that wealth and power are vain, and eternity awaits in heaven (or in that other place...).</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/greek-combat.jpg" alt="black figure pottery illustration of ancient Greek warriors fighting with shield and spear" width="80%">' "rome2-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[A barbarian |Barbarian]]</p> <p class="big">[[An Anglo-Saxon king |AS-king]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><<set $defenceExplore1 to "">> <<set $defenceExplore2 to "">> <<set $hastingsExplore1 to "">> <<set $hastingsExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="vikingshero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Viking Age</h1> <p>Key developments of the early medieval period include the birth of Islam, the Vikings, the unification (and conquest) of England, and the emergence of modern France and the Holy Roman Empire under Charlemagne. Let's focus on Vikings!</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-viking.jpg" alt="illuminated manuscript illustration of ship full of warriors with spears and shields" width="80%">' "viking-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[A Viking defence plan |Defence]]</p> <p class="big">[[The Norman Conquest of England |Hastings]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><<set $elExplore1 to "">> <<set $elExplore2 to "">> <<set $hattinExplore1 to "">> <<set $hattinExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="knightshero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Age of Knights</h1> <p>A long time ago, historian Lynn White penned this oft-quoted remark about medieval knights: "Antiquity imagined the centaur; the early Middle Ages made him master of Europe." In the most basic sense, a knight is a dude on a horse. The French word for "knght," <em>chivalier</em>, simply means "horseman." But, obviously there's a lot more to being a knight than riding a horse. What about chivalry, tournaments, castles, courtly love and damsels (in distress?), King Arthur and Camelot, the crusades in the Holy Land? So much to explore!</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-knights.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of knights jousting" width="80%">' "knights-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[The richest woman in Europe |Eleanor]]</p> <p class="big">[[King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><<set $forExplore1 to "">> <<set $forExplore2 to "">> <<set $loveExplore1 to "">> <<set $loveExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="peashero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Medieval Peasants</h1> <p>Let's get our hands dirty with the medieval peasants! Were they, as the aristocracy believed, phenomenally dumb and bestial, caked with mud and hardly sentient? Of course not! The common folk of medieval society were a widely diverse and dynamic group of individuals and communities, often real weilding wealth and power. It's really no surprise that the nobility felt threatened by the commons - a fear manifested in their efforts to construct an elevated code of chivalry to define their own class, alongside a debased image of peasants as barely human.</p> </div> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-peas.jpg" alt="medieval infantry in battle" width="80%">' "peas-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[A forester in Germany |Forester]]</p> <p class="big">[[At a midsummer bonfire |Love]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <p>Please enter the password: <<textbox "$Password" "" "Enter">></p> </div> </div><<set $witchExplore1 to "">> <<set $witchExplore2 to "">> <<set $artExplore1 to "">> <<set $artExplore2 to "">> <header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <div class="container"> <div class="renhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>The Renaissance</h1> <p>In renaissance Europe, the brilliance of new art and science, and even a new map of the world, forms a striking contrast with the dark, apocalyptic landscape of witch hunts, religious persecution, failed states, and incessant war.</p> </div> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Combat!</h2> <p>Defeat a hostile mob to boost your score and win loot! Or skip combat and scroll down to move on through this time travel portal.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/combat-ren.jpg" alt="knights and landsknecht in battle" width="80%">' "ren-combat1">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="container scenarios"> <div class="row"> <h2>Role Play Scenarios</h2> <p class="center">To move through this time travel portal, select a role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="row transbox"> <p class="big">[[In an English witch hunt |Witch]]</p> <p class="big">[[An African artist in Italy |Artist]]</p> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> </ul> </footer><<if $pompeiiExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Pompeii]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The Rubicon and Pomerium were:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ1" "A">>boundaries a Roman general could not cross with his army.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ1" "B">>special offices held by plebians during the republican period.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ1" "C">>punishments inflicted upon rebellious slaves.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "pompeii-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($pompeiiExploreQ1 is "A") and ($pompeiiExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $pompeiiExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Bow">><<set $bow to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Pompeii]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |Pompeii]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $pompeiiExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Pompeii]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Which list places the Roman emperors in chronological order from earliest to latest?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ2" "A">>Constantine, Augustus, Trajan</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ2" "B">>Augustus, Constantine, Trajan</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$pompeiiExploreQ2" "C">>Augustus, Trajan, Constantine</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "pompeii-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($pompeiiExploreQ2 is "C") and ($pompeiiExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $pompeiiExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Potion">><<set $potion to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Pompeii]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Pompeii]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>This fresco decorated the wall of a house near Pompeii in the first century BCE. From the <a href="https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/cubi/hd_cubi.htm" target="_blank">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>.</p> <p><img src="images/fresco-lyre" alt="woman plays kithara" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Here are a couple of examples of interior decorating in Roman villas.</p> <p><img src="images/pompeii-vettii" alt="room with walls brightly painted with many scenes" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A "picture gallery" style room from a house in Pompeii (House of the Vettii), from <a href="https://www.pompeiiinpictures.com/pompeiiinpictures/R6/6%2015%2001%20exedra%20ne%20p2.htm" target="_blank">Pompeii in Pictures</a></p> <hr> <p><img src="images/mosaic-nile" alt="tile mosaic of busy Nile River scene" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: A tile mosaic from a house near Rome c. 100 BCE. Nile scenes like this were very common. From <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/image/8268/nile-mosaic-of-palestrina/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a>.</p> <hr> <p><img src="images/fresco-banquet" alt="man and woman recline on couches while feasting" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A fresco from a house near Rome c. 50 BCE. Scenes of leisure and feasting were common. From <a href=https://www.worldhistory.org/image/14139/roman-fresco-of-a-banquet-scene-herculaneum/" target="_blank">World History Encyclopedia</a>.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The great colosseum in Rome was built in the 70s CE</p> <img src="images/colosseum.jpg" alt="ruins of the colliseum"> <p>Image from Cole and Symes, <em>Western Civilizations, Volume One, Sixth Brief Edition</em> (New York: Norton, 2020)</p> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are besieging the city of Rome</h1> <p>Rome, 215 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "cannae-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "cannae-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p><em>Note: This role play scenario is set in an alternative version of history. In reality, Hannibal's stunning victory at Cannae (216 BCE) was bootless because he failed to follow up, which enabled the Romans to regroup, rally their supporters, and oust Hannibal by forcing him to return home to defend Carthage. I have re-imagined this bit of history. Instead of post-Cannae paralysis, Hannibal lunges for Rome itself (kind of like Pyrrhus did, in the century before). This is the setting for this role play scenario.</em></p> <p>You are a Carthaginian engineer in the army of Hannibal. He has teamed up with Celts in the north and the Numidians in the south. Your army has defeated legion after legion in northern Italy and dirven the Romans back to the city itself. The walls are 30 feet tall and 13 feet thick. You have a leading role in planning and carrying out the siege.</p> <p>You're just an engineer, but as you plan the minutiae of your siege machinery and tactics, you're know you need to think about the bigger picture of this war too. For instance, there are the Italians. For days, <<linkappend "busily working">><<include cannae-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> amid the excitement and energy of a victorious camp, you've been oppressed by a strong sense that you've forgotten something. Like you forgot to get dressed and you're walking around naked. Or forgot to put away your scrolls and they're blowing away in the wind. And suddenly, while calculating the length of a ballista's main shaft, you looked up and swore out loud. It's the Italians. That's what has been nagging at your mind.</p> <p>So, Hannibal has brilliantly smashed every legion he's met across the peninsula, but the Italians themselves are still out there. Your army killed 50,000 Romans at Cannae last year. But does that mean you've conquered the land? Are the Italians really subdued? <<linkappend "Will they support their ally, Rome? Or will they embrace Hannibal as a liberator?">><<include cannae-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> You force your mind back to the ballista design problem. You spend the rest of the day crafting your engines of death, but your mind keeps returning to this problem of Rome's allies... </p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Ever hear of a Pyrrhic victory? Just before the Punic Wars, a Hellenistic general called Pyrrhus gave the Romans a very hard time indeed (a bit like Hannibal would do soon after Pyrrhus). History remembers Pyrrhus for his victory over the Romans at the Battle of Asculum in 279 BCE. He won, but lost so many troops that the victory was strategically worse than useless. He had to quit and go home. So if someone says, "I got it done, but it was a Pyrrhic victory," they mean that their victory was so costly that the whole endeavor was more of a failure than a success.</p> <hr> <p>Did you already know all that?</p> <p id="zrespA."><<link "Yep.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Sorry.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "No, it was new.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Awesome. It's fun to pick up new tid-bits.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>When Napoleon Bonaparte rose to power in the wake of the French Revolution, he appropriated Roman aesthetics and symbolism to represent his new regime. He was a military dictator (the first modern dictator in every sense). He had absolute power. But, given what happened to the last absolute ruler of France, Napoleon prudently strove to present himself as a man of the people whose mandate to rule sprang from democratic elections and the consent of the governed. Like the American founding fathers, Napoleon turned to republican Rome for well-known symbols of republican government: eagles, columns, "legions," and such. Laurel wreaths instead of crowns, etc.</p> <p>One of the most famous portraits of the great Bonaparte links back to the Second Punic War, when Carthaginian general Hannibal Barca famously crossed the Alps with his army, including war elephants. If you look closely, you can see Hannibal's name scratched into the rocks of this Alpine pass, alongside Charlemagne's and Napoleon's.</p> <p><img src="images/david-napoleon.jpg" alt="Napoleon on horseback pointing" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Jacques Louis David, "Napoleon Crossing the Alps" (1801)</p> <hr> <p>So, what is Charlemagne's name doing on the rocks?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Just for fun, because he was an important French ruler.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>No, there's a lot more to it than that.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "To lay claim to Germany.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Ok, this is going to sound crazy, but we're talking about Napoleon here, so crazy is on the table. First, Charlemagne was known as the founder of the Carolingian Empire, which became the Holy Roman Empire, which included France and Germany and other odd bits of Europe, sanctioned by the Pope after Charlemagne crossed the Alps to save him from raucous barbarians called Lombards, whom we will meet soon. Napoleon was hoping to do something similar, only bigger (of course).<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What kinds of machines will you built to besiege Rome? Why? How will you use them? How do you imagine the Romans will defend their city?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What do you expect will happen during or after the siege? What will the Italians do? The surviving Romans? What about the successor kingdoms in Greece, Egypt, and the Levant? What about mighty Carthage? Your southern friends in Numidia? The unruly Celts in the North?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Tools, technology, supplies available to you</li> <li>Typical siege machinery, strategies in the Hellenistic period</li> <li>Anticipate some defence moves from the Romans. It would never do to underestimate that crew...</li> <li>The bigger picture of international realtions around the Mediterranean.</li> <li>If Rome falls, what will take its place?</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Livy: Cannae and Zama |punic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Punic Wars |warry-hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[A podcast... |bastards]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-c]]</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Hellenistic World</p> <p><img src="images/greece1b.jpg" alt="ruins of circular columned temple" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copyalex"> <<if (def $alexepe1) and ($alexepe1 isnot Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copyalexs"> <<if (def $alexepe1) and ($alexepe1 isnot "")>><p>Epicurus, "Principal Doctrines," transl. P. E. Matheson, in James M.
