Philip Vellacott, in Bernard Knox, ed., <em>The Norton Book of Classical Literature</em> (New York: Norton, 1993)</p><</if>> <<if (def $alexsexe1) and ($alexsexe2 isnot "")>><p>Thomas Hubbard, ed., <em>Homosexuality in Greece and Rome: A Sourcebook of Basic Documents</em> (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2003)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyAlex()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a philosopher</h1> <p>Alexandria, c. 200 BCE</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "alex-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4 "> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "alex-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>You recline on your couch in second-century BCE Alexandria, in a cloud of sweet music and savory aromas. This <<linkappend "symposium-style dinner party">><<include "alex-link1">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> has become a kind of weekly ritual for your group of philosophical comrades. You’ve spent the week, as usual, drifting contentedly around the schools and library, lost in contemplation and study, composing a new philosophical treatise and antcipating the counter-arguments of your scholarly rivals.</p> <p>All your life, you’ve been fascinated by knowledge and ideas. Alexandria is a paradise. You’ve dabbled in physics, medicine, mathematics, poetics, ontology and metaphysics. Lately, you’ve been thinking more about politics. You’ve even begun writing a short treatise on the purpose of life.</p> <p>This evening, while <<linkappend "enjoying the conversation, the food, and the entertainment,">><<include alex-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> you voice some of your new ideas about human virtue, and what it means to live a good life. Your best friend and longtime romantic partner heckles you mercilessly, meeting all your theories with the declaration that since our minds do not exist after death, this whole question is a waste of time - and therefore not virtuous. You accuse him of being reductionist and intellectually lazy. He accuses you of being unrealistic and sophistical, wasting your time on an academic farce with no purpose beyond stroking your own ego and averting boredom.</p> <p>This argument can, and actually does, go on and on between the two of you eternally. They are a devoted adherent to Epicureanism. While you're not exactly <em>against</em> the teachings of Epicurius, you think the philosophy incomplete and naive. You yourself find Zeno's Stoicism more elegant and fulfilling. So, there's really no way the two of you will ever settle this debate on the purpose or value of human life. Still, it's not a bad way to spend the evening. Again.</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>The Victorians created some loveable and obdurately naive representations of Ancient Greek sexuality. Zeus repeatedly "married" or "befriended" humans (you know what really happened there...). The great Archaic Era poet, Sappho of Lesbos ran a school for girls (in fact, her poetry expresses erotic love between women). Victorian notions of sexuality were rigidly, almost pathologically binary, and they were desperate to fit ancient Greek literature into that framework.</p> <p><img src="images/alma-tadema-sappho.jpg" alt="women in Greek dress in a theater listen to young man playing a lyre" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Lawrence Alma-Tadema, "Sappho and Alcaeus" (1881)</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What are some features of your ideal political system?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How do you respond to your partner's criticism that there really is no good system of government because power corrupts?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your personality, upbringing, education, socio-economic status</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Epicureanism |epicurus</li> <li>[[Stoicism |epictetus]]</li> <li>[[People |theophrastus]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Homosexuality in Ancient Greece |homosexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="link"> <p>The conquests of Alexander the Great and the successor states they established, amplified the expansion of Hellenistic culture begun with Greek colonial expansion in the Archaic Period. Today, ruins of Hellenistic architecture like the hippodrome and theater below survive throughout the Middle East, North Africa, and the whole Mediterranean region.</p> <p>Greek colonial expansion:</p> <p><img src="images/map-greek-colonies.jpg" alt="map of Greek coastal expansion around Mediterranean" width="100%"></p> <p>The Hellenistic "successor states" which filled in Alexander's Empire in the third century BCE</p> <p><img src="images/map-successors.jpg" alt="map of Greek coastal expansion around Mediterranean" width="100%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The Spartan system depended on the active role of Spartan women. Stories, artwork, laws, and religious ceremonies reflect the Spartans' respect for the role of women in their unique society. For instance, Spartan women were encouraged to be physically strong by exercising and playing sports, in order (in Spartan logic) to be physically strong and produce strong boys to fill the ranks of the Spartan army. Compared with women elsewhere in Greece, Spartan women enjoyed compratively higher status and more freedom - partly because the men were totally devoted to armed service and barred from ordinary civic pursuits like business and trade. And, well, <em>someone</em> has to run the country while the men are training and fighting, so Spartan women wound up moving more freely in public life than other Greek women, who were more confined to the domestic sphere. One story in Herodotus' History tells how a Persian emissary was offering Sparta's king bribes, striving to bring Sparta into the Persian hegemony. During the meeting, the king's daughter said, "Father, this visitor is going to corrupt you if you don't get up and leave." The king took her advice.</p> <p><img src="images/spartan-woman.jpg" alt = "sculpture of woman in dress running" width="80%"></p> <p>Bronze figure of a running girl from Sparta, c. 520 BCE. Image from the <a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/G_1876-0510-1" target="_blank">British Museum.</a></p> </div><div class="link"> map of hannibal's victories and famous "you do not know how to use it" quote, </div><div class="link"> <p>An egineer preparing for a siege like this might have been designing and building ballistas, catapults, battering rams, siege engines. They would be using math and scrolls to design each machine, finding building materials and labor, and overseeing construction.</p> images with captions </div><<if $hellenisticCombat1 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Hellenistic]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Presentism Poltergeist!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: Some presentism</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ1" "A">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ1" "B">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hellenisticCombatQ1" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "hellenistic-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($hellenisticCombatQ1 is "B") and ($hellenisticCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $hellenisticCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Alexander the Great's military successes did NOT result from:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ2" "A">>his army's high morale.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ2" "B">>innovative tactics.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$alexExploreQ2" "C">>his army's numerical superiority.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "alex-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($alexExploreQ2 is "C") and ($alexExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $alexExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In the Roman republic, plebeians were:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ1" "A">>The common people</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ1" "B">>The aristocracy and ruling elite</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ1" "C">>Italian allies who were not Roman citizens</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "cannae-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if $cannaeExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Cannae]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>In the Roman republic, the ________ represented the voice of the aristocracy?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ2" "A">>tribune</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ2" "B">>assembly</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$cannaeExploreQ2" "C">>senate</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "cannae-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($cannaeExploreQ1 is "A") and ($cannaeExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $cannaeExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Cannae]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Cannae]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Cannae]]</p> <</if>><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a barbarian boy</h1> <p>Germania, 411</p> </div> <div class="container centerl"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "barb-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "barb-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>You stalk down to the shore of the great river and pause for a moment to draw a deep breath before casting your hook far out into the current. Too far. This is the worst place for fishing. And it's right next to the Roman road where anyone might see you - fishing like a lowborn commoner. You put up your hood and scowl, blinking mist-drops from your eyelashes and feeling the cold seep into your toes. You've always loved fishing, even though your kin have been chiefs in this land for hundreds of years and your friends call you a <em>ceorl</em> for this odd habit.</p> <p>Fishing was just an excuse to get out of the house. Your parents were arguing again, about you again, and you felt like your head was about to burst. When they do this, you usually flee with sword and shield to the fort to spar with your friends. But it's Sunday and nobody will be there. You cast again, still scowling, but feeling better by the moment, watching the waves rise and swirl, listening to the cadence of the river's rush, deafening against the silence of a foggy morning. Nearby, <<linkappend "the great fortress of Vindobona">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include barb-link1>><</linkappend>> looms through the mist, dark and massive above the river.</p> <p>Feeling minuscule beside the walls, you hear your parents' voices in your head: "Nobody builds like that any more. Where would we even get the stone?" You are so tired of hearing about "the good old days" when the power of Rome was real, when there was drinkable wine, fine cloth, clear glass, good iron tools and swords, a library, a real bath house, coins worth their face value. When people could travel a good, straight Roman road that didn't rattle a cart to tatters, shelter safety behind strong Roman walls, and find justice from a Roman magistrate. The days when people stayed and fought for the land of their ancestors instead of fleeing west every time the a horde of screaming savages appeared on the horizon... And on and on it goes. You shake your head to silence this rehearsal of their eternal, aimless grumbling. Who cares about yesterday? Old men. Not you. You want to know about tomorrow.</p> <p>But this is what your parents were arguing about. Your mother wants you to spend a year or two at Vindobona learning to read and write, to navigate the imperial bureaucracy, building on your family's connections as members of the local elite. She knows the bishop and the legion's commissar, and could get you a place as a clerk for either one. The old imperial system is still the path to power, she says, as it was for her father in the auxiliaries and her brothers who serve the Roman magistrate, and her cousins in the church.</p> <p>You father wants you to focus on learning his trade and running the farm. He's a smith. He says a smith's family will never go hungry or lose their seat in the council as long as men need swords and shields, shovels and chains. Forget Rome. It's done. Mind the smithy and run the farm, and look to your own defences.</p> <p>You cast your line again - bootlessly, you know, but it doesn't matter. You're feeling a bit better. The rising sun has wrapped Vindobona in a nimbus of golden fog. You wish you were in the training yard with a blunted sword in your hand, dodging and thrusting. When you fight, all these doubts disappear and nothing can stand in your way. You're the best of the young men in the Vindobona auxiliary corps. It feels good and right. You want to be great general <<linkappend "like Fritigund or Alaric or Stilicho.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include barb-link3>><</linkappend>> The smithy is as dull as the scriptorium. But where do you really belong? Is the exultation you feel in the training yard boyish play? Are your parents right? Smith or scribe? Or soething else?</p> <p>Still scowling, you cast again and wonder, for the hundredth time, what your future holds.</p> </div> <hr> <<linkappend <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Our English language comes from the family of Germanic languages spoken by the barbarian tribes. It takes shape as "English" in the early Middle Ages. When we look at these early English texts, it's fun to recognize early versions of words we still use today. But appearances can be deceiving. Sometimes, we think we recognize an ancestor of a modern English word, but it is actually unrelated - what linguists call a "false cognate." The old fashioned expression, "God speed!" is a great example. It looks like it means something like, "May God speed you on your journey." But instead, we find that the Old English word, <em>sped</em> meant "money," not "speed." The old expression, "God speed!" was originally a say of wishing someone good luck and good fortune: Something like, "May your venture be profitable." A similar example might be the old-timey phrase, "Wassail!" We generally think of this as a kind of toast, probably connecting to ale, which was a popular drink in medieval times. Maybe you've heard of a wassail cup. Well, people often did drink ale, but that's not the root of the word "wassail." Instead, it is a contraction of the Old English phrase, "Wæs ðu hæl!" meaning, "May you have health!" or "To your good health!"</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>When the Renaissance erupted across Europe and brought light to the "dark" Middle Ages, people decided that medieval architecture was hiddeous, lumpy, dark, clumsy. They began building in a new style in emulation of Rome and Greece: clean lines, pillars, lots of light, arches, domes, order, harmony, <em>symmetry</em>. To them, medieval architecture represented barbarism and ignorance. They were going to put all that behind them and revive the grand and glorious style of Roman times. Who had ended Rome? Well, the barbarian tribes, the most notorious of whom were some sort of Goth: Visigoth, Ostrogoth, Goth. So Renaissance revisionists (let's call them that!) started calling medieval architecture "gothic" as a pejorative term. To them, "gothic" meant "barbarian, savage, ugly, dark", in opposition to Rome's legacy of civilization, beauty, and culture.</p> <p>A few centuries later, people (mostly young women) started reading and writing ghost stories about vampires and haunted castles, and the aesthetic was very medieval: ruined abbeys and vaulted naves and stained glass. These thematic and aesthetic associations with medieval architecture earned the genre the name "gothic novel." And from there, you can pretty much pick up the connection to the "goth look" we're familiar with today.</p> <p><img src="images/salisbury-cathedral.jpg" alt="gothic cathedral exterior" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Salisbury Cathedral in England (c. 1250) is a beautiful example of the gothic style.</p> <p><img src="images/alphonso-psalter.jpg" alt="illuminated manuscript" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Renaissance "moderns" applied the term "gothic" to medieval scripts too, like this psalter from England, c. 1300.</p> <hr> <p>In 500 years, how do you think people will view our own early 21st-century West?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "As a kind of golden age they can hardly imagine. The end of a long stretch of western ascendancy when people in the West enjoyed unparalleled luxury and freedom.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>This seems like a reasonable guess to me. Most western populations today enjoy a higher standard of living and more freedom than most people have in human history. Maybe it has been an anomaly. Or maybe it has set a new and higher standard for the future. But what about the non-western people of the world?<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "As a dark age of oppression and injustice, when the ruling elite used new technologies and global capitalism to weild unprecedented power over the masses and destroy global natural resources for profit.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>I wonder how this will turn out for all of us. New technologies have always posed risks as well as benefits. The historical record suggests that the vast majority of human societies have been divided by strata of rich and poor, powerful and weak. But does that mean it should always be this way? How much can new technologies change these "eternal" aspects of human society? Wait and see?<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>text</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>text</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>item</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> |tacitus]]</li> <li>[[Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> |jordanes]]</li> <li>[[Barbarian law |law]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <li>[[About the Roman legions in the fourth century CE |halsall]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Cwichelm, King of Wessex</h1> <p>Anglo-Saxon England, c. 640</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "asking-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "asking-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>The great fire roars, washing the hall with heat and golden light. Torches dance in the shadowy corners and alcoves. The laughter and loud voices rise up to the tall, timbered roof. You breathe deeply, smelling the meat and bread and woodsmoke, <<linkappend "savoring these hall joys - the fruits and the seeds of victory.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link1>><</linkappend>> From your high seat above the mead benches, you watch in silence. The young men posturing and boasting, testing their prestige and the mettle of their comrades, nettling and heckling, hoping for a fight. The older men sit calmly on the benches, like great stones in the river, worn smooth by the storm of swords and spears.</p> <p>All is as it should be. You watch your daughter and your wife move gracefully down the hall, <<linkappend "filling mead horns,">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link3>><</linkappend>> exchanging quiet words with the warriors. You note with approval the way they navigate the hierarchies and subtle currents of enmity or friendship that unite the war band. Your daughter gives a fine twist of gold, a pendant, to your oldest friend and stands in conversation with him for a long time. Next in her path is her uncle’s son, Osric, an insolent youth whose mother’s family has been pushing him into competition with your own sons. Fortunately, he’s as strong as a newborn lamb. He won’t last long, but she’s right to make him wait, to let the hall see her making him wait. She talks with your old friend for a very long time and refills his horn twice, smiling sweetly, laughing softly, beautiful and gold-adorned. You see Osric struggling for calm, trying not to hear her or look at her … and failing miserably. The boy’s incapable of anything. That’s good.</p> <p>Your eldest son, Cenwalh, sees what’s happening. He raises his voice and calls down the table to the Osric: “Hey, Osric! I know you didn’t really kill that Scottish goat thief! Or his friends. I saw them yesterday…” Your daughter quietly moves toward Osric and tries to fill his mead horn, but has to apologize because her cup has run dry. You can’t completely suppress a grin behind your beard. She leaves to fetch more as the two youths begin to argue. When Osric tries to stand up, you nod to the old man at your feet. He’s ready. He plucks the strings of his harp and a surprisingly deep, penetrating voice issues from his bony frame. He speaks: <<linkappend '“Listen! We have heard of the Spear-Danes, long ago, of the royal princes’ deeds of glory…”'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link4>><</linkappend>> The hall falls silent. Totally silent. Their eyes shine in the firelight as they forget, for a time, their own petty quarrels, lost in the tales of old.</p> <p>Now you can relax and think. Your wife, a Mercian princess, is Christian. You are not. She has a priest who holds mass for her and the Christians in her retinue, and a few in your own. Over the years, the pope, has sent you gifts, rich treasures, trappings of power bearing the signs of Roman imperium. Your daughter has converted, following her mother's example. <<linkappend "Should you join them?">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link5>><</linkappend>> Other kings have, in Kent and Northumbria. Massive stone churches have risen in their kingdoms. Preists record their laws and gifts in books that will last forever. Forever? <<linkappend "Nothing is forever. Fate goes as it will.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include asking-link2>><</linkappend>> This hall is strong. Your sons are strong. The warband is as united as any warband can be. What can the Roman Christ do for your kingdom, or for you?</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>This is where English is born - as a language and as a national identity. When the Roman legions withdrew from their province of Britannia early in the fifth century, the native Celtic Britons were attacked by their warlike Gaelic-speaking neighbors in Scotland and Ireland. After centuries of Roman rule, they weren't used to fending for themselves. So they called in Germanic mercenaries from the continent: the Angles, Saxons, and Jutes. These mercenaries quickly realized that instead of fighting for their Briton bosse. <em>The Anglo-Saxon Chronicle's</em> entry for the year 443 explains it this way: "King Vortigern [a British king] gave them land to the south-east of this land on condition that they fought against the Picts. They then fought against the picts and had victory wherever they came. Then they sent to Angel; ordered them to send more aid and to be told of the worthlessness of the Britons and of the excellence of the land." The old "Why buy the cow when you can get the milk for free?" situation? Over the next few centuries, an <em>Angla-lond</em> took shape, inhabited by an <em>Anglisc</em> people. The native Celtic-speaking Britons were pushed to the western fringes in Wales and Cornwall (and please don't make the mistake of calling one of them English ... not a way to make friends). So, this is why the language we are speaking here today is a Germanic one.</p> <p>By the way, our modern English language preserves traces of Germanic paganism we use every day: Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. Those English names come from the old gods: Sun, Moon, Tyr, Woden, Thor, Frig. So that explains the "d" in Wednesday: "Woden's Day." What happened to Saturday? I think the Romans got that one (Saturn).</p> <hr> <p>Did you already know the story of that weird "d" in Wednesday?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Yes, everyone knows about that.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Ok, sorry. I'm boring.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "No! It makes sense now!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><hr>Cool. Etymology is fun.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>I have disappointing news. We have fallen in with some bad company in this branch of our time travel journey. Very bad. Our fellow travelers are Nazis. Adolf Hitler's fascination with an an "Aryan" master race led him to celebrate the early medieval history of Germanic peoples. This is why he loved Wagner's operas about early Germanic legends like Sigurd and the valkyries. You know how the bad guys in the old Indiana Jones movies are always Nazi archaeologists? Well, that's pretty realistic. The Nazi regime did support scholars scholars whose research focused on this corner of history. Ever since, white supremacist psychos have emulated Hitler's passion for Germanic history, especially Norse myth and legend. It has left a sickly aura of death and racist fanaticism over this part of the historical landscape. It's an unfortunate reality. So, let's do our best to avoid these traveling companions, and carry on exploring early Germanic history without them. It's a fascinating place. Let's not let a bunch of evil Nazis and their ignorant toadies spoil it for us, eh?</p> <p><img src="images/nazi-prop.jpg" alt="nazi propaganda posters" width="100%"></p> <p>Nazi propaganda drew heavily on the themes and aesthetic of Hitler's ideas of a White master race. As he put it in <em>Mein Kampf</em>: "Everything we admire on this earth today—science and art, technology and inventions—is only the creative product of a few peoples and originally perhaps one race [the Aryans]." It's just so boring. Let's leave this group in the dust and move on.</p> <hr> <p>Have you ever encountered this history appropriated by icky racists?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Lucky you. That's good to hear.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Oh, for sure.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>It is so frustrating! This is such exciting terrain in our historical landscape. I hope that with the passage of time, these icky associations will fade. We'll see.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>Do you convert to Christianity? Do you encourage or support the Church? Or not?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How do people in your kingdom and warband respond? How does it impact your family's position or the security of your kingdom?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Political factors including kin rivalries and relationships with neighboring kingdoms</li> <li>Economic factors such as the prosperity of your kingdom and its trade relations with its neighbors</li> <li>Your wife's priest and his relationships with others in your political circle and the community more widely</li> <li>People's pagan practices and the stance of pagan religious leaders regarding this new religion</li> </ul> <hr> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Converting the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms |bede]]</li> <li>[[King Hrothgar |hrothgar]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Sutton Hoo ship burial |suttonhoo]]</li> <li>[[About the arrival of Christianity in Anglo-Saxon England |naismith]]</li> <li>[[What we can and can't know about Germanic paganism |orton]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Did Rome Fall?</p> <p><img src="images/rome2.jpg" alt="aqueduct" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and Green, <em>Language and History in the Early Germanic World</em> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1998)</p><</if>> <<if (def $adrianwe1) and ($adrianwe1 isnot "")>><p>John Warry, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> (Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2002)</p><</if>> <<if (def $adrianme1) and ($adrianme1 isnot "")>><p>James Lacey and Williamson Murray, <em>Moment of Battle: The Twenty Clashes that Changed the World</em> (New York: Bantam Books, 2013)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyBarbs()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Rome: From Republic to Empire</p> <p><img src="images/rome1.jpg" alt="babies nursing from wolf" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copyasking"> <<if (def $askingbedee1) and ($askingbedee1 isnot "")>><p><<print $askingbedee1>> (Bede, <em>History</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $askingbedea1) and ($askingbedea1 isnot "")>><p><<print $askingbedea1>> (Bede, <em>History</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $askingbedee2) and ($askingbedee2 isnot "")>><p><<print $askingbedee2>> (Bede, <em>History</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $askingbedea2) and ($askingbedea2 isnot "")>><p><<print $askingbedea2>> (Bede, <em>History</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $askingbedee3) and ($askingbedee3 isnot "")>><p><<print $askingbedee3>> (Bede, <em>History</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $askingbedea3) and ($askingbedea3 isnot "")>><p><<print $askingbedea3>> (Bede, <em>History</em>)</p> <</if>> <<if (def $askingbedee4) and ($askingbedee4 isnot "")>><p><<print $askingbedee4>> (Bede, <em>History</em>)</p> [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Barbarian]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The term "dark ages" refers to:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ1" "A">>The period between the fall of Rome and the early Middle Ages. It's also known as late antiquity or the sub-Roman period. Historians don't like the label very much.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ1" "B">>Historians use the term "dark ages" to classify periods of intense violence when people's everyday lives were exceptionally difficult.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ1" "C">>It's a useful label because it can be properly used to classify the entire medieval period, which was a time of cultural and technological stagnation.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "barb-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($barbExploreQ1 is "A") and ($barbExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $barbExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Correct. "The Dark Ages" has been used so widely and imprecisely in popular culture that it has become problematic as a chronological label. It also has pejorative connotations, implying that the time period was bad in some way. It's just not a very useful phrse for historians, most of the time. Your score has increased by 2! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lyre">><<set $lyre to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |Barbarian]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Not quite. Try again? Or [[turn back |Barbarian]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $barbExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Barbarian]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Under Constantine:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ2" "A">>Christianity became the official state religion of Rome./label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ2" "B">>the Roman imperial government and the church merged into a single, nearly seamless administrative unit.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$barbExploreQ2" "C">>Christianity became legal in the Roman Empire.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "barb-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($barbExploreQ2 is "C") and ($barbExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $barbExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <ul> <li><<linkreplace "Treasure">><<set $treasure to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> </ul> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Barbarian]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Barbarian]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>map of migrations and location of vindobona</p> <p>image</p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Old English poetry revels in descriptions of "hall joys," with many poetic expressions for the hall, including mead hall, treasure hall, feast hall, gold hall. "Hall joys" are seen as one of the gifts a generous lord should give to his warband: music and songs, warmth, light, food and drink, a place at the benches with your comrades, gifts of treasure and valuable war gear. The high hall was also a safe, warm place to sleep (unless Grendel comes) in an otherwise cold and dangerous world. Here are a few examples:</p> <p>In <em>Beowulf</em>, Hrothgar's great hall Heorot epitomizes the motif of hall joys provided by a generous lord to his successful warband (although, the poet can't resist predicting its grim fate: destruction in future feuds): "Then to Hrothgar, success in battle was given, honor in war, so that his thanes served him eagerly, and the warband grew into a mighty troop. It came into Hrothgar's mind that he should have a hall built, a grand mead hall which men would tell of forever. Within, to young and old, he would share out all that God had given him (except the common land and the lives of men). Then I heard he commanded many people to work on building this best of royal halls, and he named it Heorot ("hart"). His words were trusted everywhere, and he did not lie when he boasted of what he would do: He gave out rings and treasure at the feast. The hall towered, high and horn-gabled. It awaited the cruel surges of hateful flames, when the furious sword-hate of son-in-law and father-in-law, arising from deadly hatred, would awaken - but that time had not yet come."</p> <p><img src="images/longhall1.jpg" alt="long timber hall" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: This reconstruction of a Viking Age long hall at Sagnlandet Lejre in Denmark resembles what an Anglo-Saxon ruler's hall would have looked like.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>text</p> Arian xpn and paganism Germanic boar helmet crests; Odin warrior ornament<p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>While Old English poets delighted in portraying "hall joys" of warmth and friendship and treasure and song, they frequently reflected on the transience of all such earthly delights. One of their favorite themes was the inexorability of fate, the fact that none of us can control what the future holds for us, and even great civilizations like Rome are eventually brought low by the power of fate and time. They saw Roman ruins all around them, seeming to prove the wisdom of this view. Here's an example of this them from the elegaic poem, <em>The Wanderer</em>, in which the speaker bemoans his status as an exile. "Hall joys" represent the opposite of miserable exile: "Where has the horse gone? Where has the man gone? Where have the treasure-givers gone? Where has the place of banquets gone? Where are the joys of the hall? Alas the gleaming cup! Alas the armoured warrior! Alas the prince's glory! How the time has passed away, grown dark under the helm of the night, as if it never were. There stands now in the track of the dear thane a wall, wondrously high, adorned with serpent-patterns. The might of ash-spears snatched away noble men, weapons greedy for carnage, notorious fate, and storms beat the stone-heaps, falling snowstorm binds the earth, winter's chaos, then the darkness comes, night-shadows spread gloom, sending from the north fierce hailstorms to the terror of men. All is hardship in the earthly kingdom; the operation of fate changes the world under the heavens. Here, wealth is transitory; here a friend is transitory; here a man is transitory; here a kinsman is transitory. All this earth's foundation will become empty." (Text and translation from Elaine Treharne, ed., <em>Old and Middle English c. 890 - c. 1450: An Anthology</em> (London: Blackwell, 2009).)<p> <p><img src="images/wanderer.jpg" alt="text from above" width="100%"></p> <p>If you know your <em>Lord of the Rings</em>, and you think this sounds like Theoden's speech at Helm's Deep ("Who am I, Gamil? Where is the horse? Where are the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?"), you are right. Tolkein lifted it exactly from this poem. The whole Kingdom of Rohan is inspired by Anglo-Saxon England. Below: Theoden at Helm's Deep.</p> <p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/xVEYcTyj1Do?si=-iEP_9JRB9kyOlxN" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe></p> </div><<if $askingExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |AS-king]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>Wergild was:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ1" "A">>a way to end a blood feud.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ1" "B">>the original werewolf legend.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ1" "C">>a core feature of Justinian's law code.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "asking-explore1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($askingExploreQ1 is "A") and ($askingExploreQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $askingExplore1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Armor">><<set $armor to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done, $PlayerName! Move on with the [[role play scenario. |AS-king]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. That's part of exploring. [[Turn back |AS-king]] to continue with the role play scenario.</p> <</if>><<if $askingExplore2 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |AS-king]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>As Roman power receded, the Germanic Franks ________ the Celtic inhabitants of Gaul.</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ2" "A">>were defeated by</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ2" "B">>conquered and displaced</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$askingExploreQ2" "C">>conquered and integrated with</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "asking-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($askingExploreQ2 is "C") and ($askingExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $askingExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Book">><<set $book to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Right! In contrast with the Germanic people who migrated to Roman Birtain, <em>conquering and displacing</em> the native Celtic Britons.</p> <p>A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |AS-king]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |AS-king]]</p> <</if>><div class="container"> <h1>Bede, <em>Ecclesiastical History</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Bede was an erudite and scholarly Northumbrian monk who wrote his monumental <em>History of the Church of the English People</em> around 730 . It is one of our most important primary sources for the history of Anglo-Saxon England, and it's full of marvelous stories. Well worth a read. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ErQlHyQoueSsjRZcFTumL5yUI6wT12u86yIUVdNUJBc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here are some excerpts relating to the conversion of the English kings.</a></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Important features of early Germanic religious belief and practice</li> <li>The nature of the surviving evidence about the history of early medieval Germanic paganism, and the debates about how to intepret it</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedee1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedea1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedee2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedea2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedee3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedea3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedee4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingbedea4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How people and groups made the decision to convert to Christianity or not</li> <li>What Christianity had to offer kings</li> <li>The relationship between Christianity and paganism, and what it meant to practice or "believe" in either system (or both)</li> <li>The limits and uncertainties in our knowledge about pre-Christian religion European religious beliefs and practices</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. This is a dense and detailed piece about a complex topic. Enjoy! (That was sarcasm there. Sorry. This article is a challenging read. In an uncharitable humor, one might almost say that it makes a fascinating subject as boring as possible. But perhaps this has great value? With early medieval Germanic paganism, the historiography is so complex, the sources so tenuous and interrelated and unstable, and the material so innately fascinating and alive ... "boring" has value here.)</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Important features of early Germanic religious belief and practice</li> <li>The nature of the surviving evidence about the history of early medieval Germanic paganism, and the debates about how to intepret it</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Anglo-Saxon King Scenario |AS-king]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>King Hrothgar in <em>Beowulf</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Old English poem, <em>Beowulf,</em> was composed c. 800, but survives only in a single manuscript copy from c. 1000 (which almost burned in a library fire, but was saved by the statue on top of it). The poem tells of many old Germanic heroes and legends, but principally follows the adventures of Beowulf: an unpromising youth who becomes a mighty warband leader, rips the arms off monsters with his bare hands, wins epic heaps of treasure, avenges his king's death, swims across the North Sea carrying the plundered weapons and armor of 30 slain enemies (no big deal), turns down an offer of kingship, becomes king later, and kills a dragon.</p> <p>Here's <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/15gPxrceFyfzSqHrVqODuI9jKbhw6pcRc/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=107960520722717944293&rtpof=true&sd=true" target="_blank">a synopsis of the whole poem</a>, in case that's of interest (seriously, what could <em>possibly</em> be more interesting??). The poet presents Hrothgar, king of the Danes, as the ideal king. Have a look at the text here: <a href="https://heorot.dk/beowulf-rede-text.html" target="_blank">(Old English and modern English side by side)</a>. No, don't read the whole thing (at lesat not right now). Read the parts about Hrothgar, listed below. Have fun with the Old English! See if you can recognize some of the words. The lines about Hrothgar are:</p> <ul> <li>Hrothgar is a good king: Lines 64 - 98</li> <li>Feast after Beowulf fights Grendel: Lines 837 - 1062</li> <li>Feast after Beowulf fights Grendel's Mother: Lines 1651 - 1962</li> <li>Beowulf tells his king, Hygelac, about his adventures in Denmark: Lines 1999 - 2031, 2101 - 2141</li> </ul> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Aspects of good kingship: What was a good king expected to do in Anglo-Saxon England?</li> <li>How did a king weild power? How did he motivate or direct various groups of people?</li> <li>What benefits might Christianity have offered an early Anglo-Saxon king?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div the arrival of Christianity in Anglo-Saxon England |naismith]]</li> <li>[[What we can and can't know about Germanic paganism |orton]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Anglo-Saxon King Scenario |AS-king]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Green, Language and History in the Germanic World</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>This book is old fashioned in some ways, harking back to the historiography of the mid twentieth century, but a steadfast classic. It's an excellent starting point for any exploration of the history of the Germanic societies of late antiquity and the early Middle Ages. <a href="" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from Green's <em>Language and History in the Early Germanic World</em> focuses on warfare, and <a href="" target="_blank">this one</a> is about trade between the Romans and the Germanic tribes.</p> <p>And here's a story, just for fun. At grad school in the UK, I heard from someone who had attended a presentation by D. H. Green. Green told how while traversing some Norman hedge country as a British officer in World War II, he suddenly came face to face with a German officer. They both drew their pistols and fired hastily at one another. They both missed. Grinning sheepishly, Green addressed his foe in excellent German: "I'm glad our men didn't see that." And they both turned around and went in opposite directions.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>item</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriange1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianga1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianga2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> |tacitus]]</li> <li>[[Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> |jordanes]]</li> <li>[[Barbarian law |law]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss"
