Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <li>[[About the Roman legions in the fourth century CE |halsall]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Roman Genocide</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In this series of "Behind the Bastards,"</a>, podcaster and journalist Robert Evans talks with historian Joe Kassabian about "Ancient Genocide and the War on Carthage:" <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/nz/podcast/part-one-ancient-genocide-and-the-war-on-carthage/id1373812661?i=1000564661837" target="_blank">Part I</a> and <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/ca/podcast/part-two-ancient-genocide-and-the-war-on-carthage/id1373812661?i=1000564948691" target="_blank">Part II.</a></p> <p>Be it known that this is not a particularly academic work, but it fact-checks very well, makes careful use of a variety of solid sources, and is generally well-informed and accurate. I think it's a fun and informative approach to the military, political, and economic systems of republican Rome. As such, it can enrich our understanding of the character in this role play scenario.</p> <p>Warning: There's some strong language and lewd humor, along with political views you might not agree with. This podcast tends to have a strong ideological bent, and I am not sharing it here to suggest that you should agree with the podcasters in their political views. I just think it can offer useful and accurate insights into Roman military, political, and economic history at the time of Rome's wars with Carthage. If it's not to your taste, it's totally fine to skip this one. It is <em>optional</em> content.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Prevailing attitudes toward violence in republican Rome (politically, militarily, and in daily life)</li> <li>Roman military traditions, strengths, and weaknesses</li> <li>The wider context of Rome's struggle with Carthage</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannbe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannba1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannbe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannba2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannbe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannpba3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannbe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannba4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Livy: Cannae and Zama |punic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Punic Wars |warry-hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[A podcast... |bastards]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-mdvictory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-c]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Attacking Rome Scenario |Cannae]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are King Harold Godwinson</h1> <p>England, c. 1066</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>It is September 30, 1066. You stand very still, at the very end of the labyrinth of tunnels under <<linkappend "York Minster.">><<include hastings-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>In the small, dark room, treasure is heaped up like a dragon, higher than your head. It glints in the torchlight, coils of torques and hack silver and coin, ring mail and swords and helmets seeming to heave and move. It took twelve men to carry the gold bar underneath it all. Harald had brought it with him his days leading the <<linkappend "Verangian guard in Byzantium.">><<include hastings-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> You can’t take your eyes off it. And it’s not greed. You have money. At any gathering, you’re always the richest one (kings not excepted). It was a long, long time ago when you stopped caring if people called you greedy or ambitious or selfish. You genuinely have no idea what it feels like to give a shit. Money is so fucking boring. But this isn’t money. This is power. This gold is <em>alive</em>, as if <<linkappend "the treasure had become the man himself,">><<include hastings-link3>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> as if the ghost of Harald Hardrada himself had risen from the mead benches of Valhalla to stand before you and stare you in the face - and you can’t look away.</p> <p>You clench your eyes shut and it hurts. You need to get some sleep. You let a long, slow expletive roll through your mind. Should you ask Harald what to do? Ha ha! What the hell. You open your eyes and they still can't look away from the glowing, pulsing hoard. You speak to it: “Harald, I just wrecked you. Hard. And that Irish king too. And my worthless fucking brother, may he rot in Hell forever. Wish I could do it again right now. So, why aren’t you dead? You’re still here. The skalds were singing about you in the camp just now. I heard them You're alive. Your gold should be alive like you. It should be up there in camp too, lighting up the night like your name, making men laugh and fight … and forget. But it is here in the dark with the dead. And here it stays, at least for now, because the Bastard has landed. They just told me.</p> <p>We have to march south. Now. Yesterday. Again! We just did this, like <em>just now</em> raced here 300 miles from London to wreck your shit. The Bastard will have dug in by now: motte and bailey, burning and raiding, scouting, planning, <em>always</em> with the fucking planning - endless contingencies in twisted perfection like the inlay on my sword hilt. He’s good. You know, <<linkappend "I was with him in Brittany a few years ago.">><<include hastings-link4>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> Raiding and hunting. My dogs are better, but he was good. Household knights, feudal levies, mercenaries, cavalry and archers, perfect timing, total control. He’s here now, and after my crown. What will I do, old man? Tell me, what will I do?”</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>The Norman Conquest of 1066 is when all of the lovely French enters our incredibly rich English language. For instance, it's why we say "cow" in the field (where the English peasants used the Old English word <em>cu</em>), but "beef" on our plate (where the Norman lords used the Norman French word <em>boef</em>).</p> <hr> <p>What other languages had a major impact on early English?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Latin">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Correct. As the language of the educated elite and the church, many Latin loanwords and expressions seeped into medieval English.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Old Norse">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><hr>That's right. When you get repeatedly wrecked (or more politely, "annexed" or "contacted") by the Vikings, your language bears a record of that trauma (or more politely, "cultural exchange").<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey (score +2).</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>The Norman Conquest of England is truly a turning point in history, especially for English-speaking people. Over the centuries, it has been represented and misrepresented in countless ways.</p> <p>So where to start? Well, let's pick Robin Hood. The Norman Conquest is often associated with the Robin Hood stories, which often tell of a rapacious and haughty Norman aristocracy mistreating a conquered population of Saxon commoners. Medieval people <em>loved</em> Robin Hood. However, his fan base was distinctly working class - the peasantry. They were basically drinking songs. And since peasants were illiterate, there are hardly any written sources about Robin Hood until later in the Middle Ages (centuries after the Norman Conquest with which he is so often associated today). But the earlier medieval sources do contain enough sporadic references to songs about Robin to makes it clear to historians that these stories were the medieval equivalent of the highest-rated Netflix series. But, oddly, the earliest recorded stories say nothing about the politics of Norman vs. Saxon, nothing about King Richard or Prince John, or even robbing the rich to give to the poor. People added those touches later. What seems to have made Robin Hood appealing to his medieval fan base was his talent for evading the authorities and making fools of them. He used peasant weapons (like a bow) and had peasant sidekicks (like a miller's son and a forest hermit). And his nemesis was the local sheriff - nothing about national politics or social justice. The vibe is generally "Somkey and the Bandit."</p> <p><img src="images/luttrell-archers.jpg" alt="archers target shooting" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Peasants practicing archery (Luttrell Psalter, England, c. 1330)</p> <p>So, was he real? Yep. But the "real" Robin Hood bore little resemblance to the guy in the stories medieval people loved so much. The "real, original" Robin Hood was a Saxon nobleman called Hereweard the Wake. In the years following the Norman Conquest of 1066, the Saxon Hereweard and his band of outlaws kept up a successful guerrilla resistance against the new Norman regime, working from a base hidden deep in the fens of eastern England (marsy, boggy wetlands). If there's any one person we can identify as the "real" Robin Hood, it's him.</p> <p>And so what? Does that mean the Robin Hood adored by medieval peasants is invalid or illegitimate in some way? Or the one Hollywood likes to show us today? I don't think so. It comes back to thinking carefully about the quesitons we ask of history. Instead of asking, "Was Robin Hood real?" or "Is this Robin Hood movie accurate?", maybe we should ask something like, "What did medeival people think of Robin Hood? What can those stories tell us about their lives and beliefs?" History can only tell us what we ask it.</p> <p><img src="images/robin-hood-film.jpg" alt="Robin Hood movie covers" width="100%"></p> <hr> <p>Which Robin Hood do you like best?</p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Russell Crowe in 2010">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespC"><<link "The fox in the Disney one">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>As you lead the forced march south, setting a crushing pace, making 40 miles a day with a brief stop in London to pull in fresh troops, what plans do you form for dealing with William at the coast? What orders do you issue as you travel? Is there a role for diplomacy as well as force? Can that treasure glowing in the bowels of York Minster do anything for you?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How does the battle go (if there is one)? What are the results for England and France? For your favorite person, Harold Godwinson? What would the ghost of old Harald Hardrada have to say?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>The political situation and various claimants to the English crown</li> <li>Military considerations: Strengths and weaknesses of the English and Norman forces</li> <li>Ideals of kingship and military leadership in Anglo-Saxon England</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Viking poetry |skaldic]]</li> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Age Portal |Viking]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are in a coastal Northumbrian village</h1> <p>Northumbria, England, c. 800</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "defence-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>Icy wind sweeps across the ocean, lifting white caps from the surface of the sea and cutting through your wool sleeves to sting your skin, goading you into a trot as you near the shelter of home.</p> <p>Inside the house, it's smoky and warm. As your eyes adjust to the dim light, you see the others are here already. The big benches lining the table in the center of your long hall are full. You toss your cloak <<linkappend "to a slave">><<include defence-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> and say, “The new dog had trouble moving the ewes and the new thralls are fools. Is everyone here?” Nobody speaks. Since last week’s Danish raid on the neighboring village, you’ve all been on edge, constantly scanning the horizon, jumping at the sound of a cry. You glance at the heap of blankets in the corner, where a couple of children sit close together, watching you with huge eyes. They were among the few to escape the raid and reach the safety of your village. Their parents were not so fortunate. You called this meeting to make a plan for when the Northmen come. Because they will. Your village is large, <<linkappend "stretching from the docks in the bay to the monastery on the hill.">><<include defence-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> You sit down on the bench in your usual place next to your two oldest sons, and accept a horn of mead from your wife. You nod at your father, old but still strong, at the head of the table. Let him get things started</p> </div> <hr> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Most of the time, Viking defence plans didn't work. Early in the Viking Age, the raiders won, carrying off captives for the slave trade and whatever treasure they could find. And around the tenth century, they started colonizing. Like the ancient Greeks, Vikings were highly successful seafaring colonizers. And like the Greeks, this habit created a wide diaspora of Viking cultural influence, including language change. They didn't always raid. They were traders first and foremost, and that involves communication. So Scandinavian loan words seeped into the langauages of the people they traded with and raided and pushed aside as colonizers. The modern English we speak today bears deep imprints from the Vikings, including the words egg, law, and knife.</p> <p>Where do you think our English word "slave" comes from?</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "From the Latin word <em>servus</em>. Literate people in the Middle Ages wrote in Latin.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>>So, that would make all kinds of sense. But Latin <em>servus</em> is not the ancestor of our English word <em>slave.</em> Instead, it comes from the word "Slav," as in the Slavic peoples of Eastern Europe who were the last Europeans to remain pagan, and therefore legally enslavable (since church policy forbad enslavement of fellow Christians).<<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link 'From the Old English <em>þeow</em>, meaning "slave."'>><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>Well, that's a great guess, since <em>þeow</em> is the most common Old English word for "slave." But it's not related to our modern Englith word <em>slave</em>, which actually comes from "Slav." The Slavic peoples of Eastern Europe were the last Europeans to remain pagan, and therefore legally enslavable (since church policy forbad enslavement of fellow Christians). So "Slav" evolved into our English word <em>slave</em>.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <div class="container link"> <div class="row"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Many people journeying through the history of the Viking Age (including the Vikings themselves, actually) are interested in the idea of female Viking warriors. One of the most popular characters in the Netflix show <em>Vikings</em> is a woman warrior (image below). How realistic is that?</p> <p><img src="images/viking-netflix.jpg" alt="woman warrior standing on battlefield" width="80%"></p> <p>Historians mostly (but far from unanimously) agree that there were no female Viking warriors. We base our knowledge of history on observable evidence and logic. We ask, "Based on the observable evidence as we currently have it, what is the <em>most probable</em> answer to this question?" And when we ask it that way, the answer is clearly, "No, there were no female Viking warriors as depicted in modern fictional accounts." Were women in Viking society capable of combat, and somewhat competent with weapons? That seems highly likely. Did they live the life of a Viking warrior as the men did? No. We say no because there is no evidence of such a thing. The Vikings wrote a lot about their Viking activities. They never mention a female warrior. They do frequently mention the idea of mythical and legendary female warriors (like valkyries). (Here's <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dEfdgeCWztW4hsu5U19ccV1tGocQr4Gu/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">an excellent scholarly article</a> about the textual evidence, if you're interested.) They were attracted by the idea of female warriors, just as we are today. But they never mention a real one.</p> <p>Nobody writing in the early Middle Ages mentions a real female Viking. It's the kind of thing the Vikings themselves probably would have mentioned, based on their interest in valkyries. It's the kind of thing their Christian haters would have mentioned, based on their zeal for demonizing Vikings (to a monkish chronicler, women fighting as men would be a excellent evidence of the Vikings' pagan depravity). Because of this lack of evidence, historians (mostly) give a negative answer to this question of Viking warrior women. But ... that could change, right? New evidence is discovered all the time. We'll see what the future holds.</p> <p>So, what about <a href="https://www.bbc.com/reel/video/p099hyk0/the-viking-warrior-who-turned-out-to-be-a-woman" target="_blank">the Viking Age Birka grave</a> in Sweden? In which female remains were found in a grave containing the burial goods of a warrior (sword, axe, horse, etc.)? <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FXZFpu1AngrN8SU1esKVQPyqv6SDgppd/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Some leading archaeologists</a> interpret this burial as evidence that Viking warrior women did exist, as represented in the Netflix show. However, others point to numerous problems with this interpretation (for instance, the sad fact that the Victorian Era archaeologists who collected the remains and mapped the site did a very shoddy job of it, so that there's no way to know if those female bones were truly buried in a "warrior grave." (If you're interested, <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1-1saIebK6NxfJWDe5WeJEB-64D3stB6g/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">here's an excellent recent article</a> about this very active and impassioned academic debate.) There are lots of Viking Age warrior graves containing male bones. The one exception at the Birka site may not really be an exception. (And there are <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ukl-8zLfnAW4B-XfgjcxCeK0mgLWsCGZ/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">intersex people buried with warrior goods</a> in early medieval Finland graves.) There's also the problem of cremation: Vikings often burned their dead rather than burying them, so it's possible that Viking women warriors were cremated instead of buried. But with no written evidence in favor, and the vast majority of the archaeological evidence against, it is reasonable to conclude that Viking warrior women are fictional. But not everyone agrees.</p> <p><img src="images/maud-valkyries.jpg" alt="valkyries riding horses in clouds" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Vikings, Victorians, and Netflix have all enjoyed the idea of Viking warrior women. Here's an exmple of the trend from 1890 England: "The Ride of the Valkyries" by William T. Maud.</p> <hr> <p>What's your opinion? Do you think there were Viking warrior women?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>This is also my interpretation of the evidence. There are people who disagree.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Absolutely.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Many people agree with you! The evidence does not fully disprove this, so it's a possibility.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>Describe the plans you come up with. How will you defend yourselves from the raid you know is coming?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How does this situation impact your community’s socioeconomic dynamics? What individuals or groups are empowered? Who loses status and who gains?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your family's socioeconomic and political status in the village</li> <li>Your skills, resources, tools</li> <li>The political structure of your community (such as its relationship with the monastery or the royal government</li> </ul> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Age Portal |Viking]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Viking Age</p> <p><img src="images/darkages.jpg" alt="helmet" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copydefence"> <<if (def $defde1) and ($defde1 isnot Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>A Viking raid c. 860</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Norman monk Dudo de Saint Quentain, writing his <em>History of the Normans</em> c. 1020, recorded <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IrD6FsboCIZdoL7yRTgeKXcWsoFX6LNy9qIiabWAlPY/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this story of a Viking raid</a> on an Italian town c. 860. </p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Techniques Vikings used when attacking a town</li> <li>Viking goals and strategies</li> <li>Potential biases in the chroniclers whose works tell us about the Vikings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defda4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Battle of Maldon (991)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>At the Battle of Maldon in eastern England (991), a large force of Vikings defeated a small English army. The story is told this way in the terse entries of the <em>Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</em> (a record kept up to date and in several versions in monasteries across England, and in vernacular Old English rather than clerical Latin): "Here Ipswich was raided. Very soon after that, ealdorman Byrhtnoth was killed at Maldon. And on that year it was decided to pay tax to Danes for the great terror which they made by the sea coast; that first [payment] was 10,000 pounds. Archbishop Sigerīc decided first on the matter."</p> <p>The story is told more fully in <a href="https://oldenglishpoetry.camden.rutgers.edu/battle-of-maldon/" target="_blank"><em>The Battle of Maldon</em></a>, an Old English poem probably composed shortly after the battle. The <em>Maldon</em>-poet presents the English leader, Byrhtnoth, as a brave hero but it also seems to criticize his bravado in intentionally allowing the Vikings to approach his army by crossing the causeway. (Here's the poem <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1p0oN5dpTNd0a9sDmGGZFKOAcDWc4ipvU/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">in Old English and Modern English</a>, in case you're interested in seeing the Old English version.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Viking goals and strategies</li> <li>Challenges and methods of defending against a Viking attack</li> <li>Military leadership in Anglo-Saxon England, especially the challenge of motivating people to fight the Vikings</li> <li>Values, identities, and ideas of masculinity in Anglo-Saxon England</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defme1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$defma1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$defme2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$defma2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$defme3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$defma3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$defme4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$defma4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Page, "A Most Vile People" </h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Textual sources like chronicles and histories provide crucial evidence about the Vikings. But who wrote these chronicles and histories? The Vikings' victims! (The Vikings did leave plenty of textual accounts of their activities abroad, but it's far outweighed by the volume written by angry monks in fear of Viking attacks.) Honestly though, after writing the above, I kind of randomly flipped through my dog-eared old copy of <em>Heimskringla</em>, and not kidding literally in under 30 seconds I found a Viking-authored account of "their activities abroad." It was as expected. Have a look (from the Saga of Magnus Barelegs): "During the winter King Magnus continued east to Vik. And when spring came he sailed south to Halland and harried there far and wide. He destroyed Viskar Dale and a number of other districts by fire. He made large booty [stop laughing, he means "took much plunder")] and then returned to his own kingdom. As Bjorn the Cripple-handed says in his Magnussdrapa: 'Far and wide the war-lord wasted Halland's homesteads - swift he followed the fleeing foe - with sword and fire. Burned the thane of Thronders thatched farms many in Visk Dale - soundly slept not women south there - and other shires.'" So yeah, the monkish chroniclers are hardly an unbiased voice, but they aren't all that different from Vikings' own version of events.</p> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1WnnH_ayZ2G4Gh9JPHGmxqSf8U2hN56z7/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this article,</a> R. I. Page tackles the problem of forming an objective, unbiased understanding of the Vikings when most of the written records were created by very anti-Viking people.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Features of typical Viking raids</li> <li>How people typically responded to a Viking raid</li> <li>The challenge of interpreting the evidence of clerical chroniclers as a source of information about Vikings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilee4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defvilea4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Brooks, "Weapons and Armor" </h1> <div class="container"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="" target="_blank">In this article</a>, Nicholas Brooks analyzes the historical realism of the weapons and armor in the poem, <em>The Battle of Maldon</em>. He shows that the poet's depictions were realistic and purposeful (for instance, reflecting the English defenders' chronic lack of decent helmets and armor, compared to the well-equipped Viking invaders).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Weapons and armor used by Vikings</li> <li>Wepons and armor used in Anglo-Saxon England</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defbe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defba1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defbe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defba2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defbe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defba3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defbe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defba4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[A Viking raid |dudo]]</li> <li>[[The Battle of Maldon |maldon]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Arms and armor at the Battle of Maldon |brooks]]</li> <li>[[Slave Raiding and Slave Trading |slave-raiding]]</li> <li>[[A Most Vile People |vile]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-d]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Viking Defence Scenario |Defence]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Pelteret, "Slave Raiding and Slave Trading" </h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Sure, Vikings would pick up treasure whenever they could. But how much treasure do you think they actually found in villages? Yeah, it wasn't common for ordinary folk to have chunks of silver and gold strewn around their houses (although, as shown by the hoards of coins found buried beneath the remains of burned Viking Age houses, people sometimes did keep caches of silver and gold buried under their floors). Really, the most common form of plunder picked up by the Vikings was human. The slave trade was a key sector of the early medieval economy, just as it had been in ancient times. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m7tq7ov_d4GHONiJWrVkrARe9vNUtjvR/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this article</a>, David Pelteret analyzes evidence about Viking slave-trading activity in Anglo-Saxon England.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The status and experiences of slaves in Anglo-Saxon England</li> <li>The methods of Viking slave raiders</li> <li>Ideas about how to defend against Viking slave raids</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defslavee1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defslavea1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defslavee2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$defslavea2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$vikingCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "viking-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($vikingCombatQ2 is "A") and ($vikingCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $vikingCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Tautology Troll and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Horse">><<set $horse to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Ring">><<set $ring to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>[[Onward! |Viking]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Tautology Troll. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Viking]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>As in Roman times, slavery was a common feature of early medieval society. The church prohibited enslavement of Christians, but of course this didn't stop the pagan Vikings. Slaves were a significant portion of the plunder taken by Viking raiders. Most of the goods traded to the Muslim world were humans. The slavers were typically pagan Vikings raiding western Europe or Christian Franks raiding the pagan Slavs.</p> <p><img src="images/ema-slave-value.jpg" alt="chart showing high value of slaves in the Islamic world compared to the Christian West" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Historian Michael McCormick's massive study, <em>The Origins of the European Economy: Communication and Commerce, AD 300 - 900</em> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2002), includes original archival scholarship on the early medieval slave trade. In this chart, McCormick provides a dramatic demonstration of the wide profit margin to be obtained by trading slaves from western Europe to the Islamic world.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Monasteries were basically Viking candy: Typically near a river or coast, full of treasure and beer, defended by monks rather than fighting men. The map below shows Viking, Magyar, and Muslim invasions in Europe, c. 800 - 1000 (from Bennett and Bardsley, <em>Medieval Europe: A Short History, Twelfth Edition</em> (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2020)</p> <p><img src="images/map-viking.jpg" alt="map of Europe" width="80%"></p> </div><<if $defenceExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. [[Continue with the role play scenario. |Hastings]] <<else>> <h1>Exploring is fun!</h1> <p>Here's an interesting question. It might be difficult, or it might be easy. What else would we expect from an epic adventure?</p> <div class="container gt-explore"> <div class="row transbox explore-spoils-cont"> <p>The medieval knight was possible because of the invention of:</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ2" "A">>horseshoes.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ2" "B">>the lance.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$hastingsExploreQ2" "C">>stirrups.</label></p> </div> <div class="row transbox" id="explore-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "How did you do?">><<replace "#explore-spoils">><<include "hastings-explore2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($hastingsExploreQ2 is "C") and ($hastingsExploreQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $hastingsExplore2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <hr> <p>Wise choice. Exploring can have its rewards. Your score has increased by 2. Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <p><<linkreplace "Shield">><<set $shield to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p><<linkreplace "Lance">><<set $lance to true>>\<</linkreplace>></p> <p>Well done! A successful quest completed! Carry on with [[the role play scenario. |Hastings]]</p> <<else>> <hr> <p>Looks like you've hit a dead end. It's all part of exploring. Time to move on with the [[role play scenario. |Hastings]]</p> <</if>><div class="link"> <p>Constantine, Danelaw and Yorvik</p> <p>York Minster</p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>harald hardrada verangian guard</p> <p>image</p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>legend of fafnir, beresrkrs, beowulf as aglaca</p> <p>images of treasure; image of sigurd slaying fafnir on rune stone</p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>godwin exiled (again) and was shipwrecked ironically enough and spent time as a guest in normandy, raiding and hunting, and norman sources say he promised to back william's claim (edward promised crown to a few people) battle often viewed as confrontation btwn old fashioned gmc shield wall style combat and new heavy cav knights of hma and lma, but really, normans were using both throuhgout med already and harold was using both up around york; truth in it but more nuanced than old fasioned free gmc "nation in arms" vs new norman-french feudalism and heavy cav knights; normans were cutting edge using combo while english were more reliant on old ways (but not dogmatically clinging to it since they did use it at york)</p> <p>images of Harold and William hunting together on BT; image of shield wall failing on BT</p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Skaldic Verse</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Vikings were great poets. (Maybe this is a surprise, like the Assyrians being great patrons of the arts?) Viking poetry typically praises an individual for adherence to a kind of Germanic heroic ethos, which is deeply embedded in the oral-traditional poetics of pre-Christian Germanic society. The Vikings' skaldic poetry and runic inscriptions take delight in ornate, elaborate kennings (metonymic expressions) based on pagan religion, myth, and legend. This poetry is a rich source of insight into early Germanic paganism, as well as Viking notions of leadership, warfare, and ideals of masculinity.</p> <p>Viking poetry is not what we expect in our post-romantic outlook today. It is not introspective or pensive or deeply contemplative. It is outward- rather than inward-facing. It is a public speech act with political force. And it's not easy to read. But we're doing it all wrong! It wasn't meant to be <em>read</em> at all, but to be spoken and heard and chanted and shouted. See how you do with these examples.</p> <ul> <li>The famous Viking skald Egill Skala-Grimssonr composed <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Qi7BH_pThjlYew-fRCiyf5gfBpjyHemS/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this poem</a> for the Viking king of York, Erik Blood Axe, as an apology to the king for having stayed a while at the rival court of the English king Aethelstan. He called the poem "Head Ransom;" apparently Erik was not amused at Egill's little fling at the English court. It's basically a standard classic skaldic poem: "oh king, you are a great warrior and your dudes are great warriors too and they love you and Odin loves you and you have done many great things like killing people and being generous with treasure." Text from S. Nordal, <em>Egils saga</em> (1933) and J. Carroll.</li> <li><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/106GeawWK5GQDx8Vg-VhPdKWc5Cg28on9/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">These verses</a> were composed by Viking poet Arnorr jarlaskald about Harald Hardrada's invasion of England in 1066. Text from G. Turville-Petre, <em>Skaldic Verse of the Scandinavian Middle Ages</em> (1951).</li> </ul> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Military leadership and ideals of masculinity in Viking Age England</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastske1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastska1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastske2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastska2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastske3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastska3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastske4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbska4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Viking poetry |skaldic]]</li> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Ring-giving in <em>Beowulf</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Old English poem, <em>Beowulf,</em> was composed c. 800, but survives only in a single manuscript copy from c. 1000 (which almost burned in a library fire, but was saved by the statue on top of it). The poem tells of many old Germanic heroes and legends, but principally follows the adventures of Beowulf: an unpromising youth who becomes a mighty warband leader, rips the arms off monsters with his bare hands, wins epic heaps of treasure, avenges his king's death, swims across the North Sea carrying the plundered weapons and armor of 30 slain enemies (no big deal), turns down an offer of kingship, becomes king later, and kills a dragon.</p> <p>Here's <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/15gPxrceFyfzSqHrVqODuI9jKbhw6pcRc/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=107960520722717944293&rtpof=true&sd=true" target="_blank">a synopsis of the whole poem</a>, in case that's of interest (seriously, what could <em>possibly</em> be more interesting??). A central theme is ring-giving: Basically, a ring-giver is a military leader who provides victory and tresaure to his warband. It's a concept that's built into the Old English poetic register, its oral-traditional tectonics and aesthetic, and is a very old part of early medieval Germanic culture. It's just all over the place in Old English poetry (and easily adapted to a Christian context, for instance, to conceptualize Christ as a generous and victorious warband leader leading his saints or disciples as his loyal warriors). This treasure was often military in nature: helmets, swords, armor. It was a token of the lord-retainer bond, both expressing and creating the warrior's obligation to provide loyal service to his lord. Have a look at the text here: <a href="https://heorot.dk/beowulf-rede-text.html" target="_blank">(Old English and modern English side by side)</a>. No, don't read the whole thing (at lesat not right now). Read the parts describing this ring-giving dynamic, listed below. Have fun with the Old English! See if you can recognize some of the words.</p> <ul> <li>Hrothgar is a good king (e.g., offering victory and generously sharing out treasure): Lines 64 - 98</li> <li>Wiglaf tells his timid (cowardly?) companions that their obligation to help Beowulf fight the dragon is represented by the gifts of weapons and armor Beowulf has given them: Lines 2596 - 2662</li> </ul> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The role of treasure in early medieval military leadership or kingship</li> <li>How a king should use treasure to motivate his followers</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastrga2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastrga4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Viking poetry |skaldic]]</li> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>William the Conqueror</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1kwMGLK4jETCb8SVyPXczcKmbuOUgJKea/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">THis wonderful chapter</a> from Michael Wood's lively book, <em>In Search of the Dark Ages</em> provides an in-depth analysis of the Battle of Hastings, focusing on the figure of William "the Bastard," Duke of Normandy, who defeated King Harold at the Battle of Hastings and became the first Norman French king of England. That event has long been viewed as a major turning point in history, at which the Battle of Hastings was an epic clash of cultures (old fashioned, nationalistic, democratic Anglo-Saxon vs. new, feudal, hierarchical Norman). This paradigm has numerous logical and methodological flaws, and is no longer espoused by modern historians. Still, it reverberates through much of the popular perceptions of the Norman Conquest, including the many re-tellings of the Robin Hood legends. So it's an interesting moment in the history of Western Civilization. Wood's chapter on William is a valuable source of well-researched detail and commentary.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the English and the Normans at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>Key moments at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>Turning points or contingencies that could have turned out differently or been handled differently by Harold</li> <li>The relative situations of Harold and William as claimants to the English throne before the Battle of Hastings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastwa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Bayeux Tapestry</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>After the Norman Conquest of 1066, Norman Archbishop Odo of Bayeux (participant in the Battle of Hastings) had a massive tapestry created, embroidered by English women. Across its 244 feet, the tapestry tells the story of the Norman Conquest of England, including incredible detail such as Halley's Comet, building the invasion fleet, the iconic (often misinterpreted) clash between the Anglo-Saxon shield wall and the Norman heavy cavalry, and of course, poor Harold getting shot in the eye (spoiler, sorry).</p> <p><a href="https://www.bayeuxmuseum.com/en/the-bayeux-tapestry/discover-the-bayeux-tapestry/explore-online/" target="_blank">At the Bayeux Museum here</a>, you can view the whole glorious tapestry and zoom in to see every stunning detail. Have fun! (Really, it's incredible.)</p> <p>Fun fact: It's not a tapestry (which is woven). It's an embroidery (the scene is stitched onto plain cloth). We should call it the Bayeux Un-Tapestry.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the English and the Normans at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>Key moments at the Battle of Hastings</li> <li>The relative situations of Harold and William as claimants to the English throne before the Battle of Hastings</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hastbte1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$hastbta1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$hastbte2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$hastbta2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the poetry |skaldic]]</li> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes?
