You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Viking Age</p> <p><img src="images/darkages.jpg" alt="helmet" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. Lee M. Hollander (Austin: University of Texas Press, 1964)</p><</if>> <<if (def $hastbte1) and ($hastbte1 isnot "")>><p>"Explore the Bayeux Tapestry Online," Bayeux Museum, https://www.bayeuxmuseum.com/en/the-bayeux-tapestry/discover-the-bayeux-tapestry/explore-online/, accessed [date]</p><</if>> <<if (def $hastwe1) and ($hastwe1 isnot "")>><p>Michael Wood, <em>In Search of the Dark Ages</em> (New York: Facts on File Publications, 1987)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyHasts()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Snorri Sturluson, <em>Heimskringla</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Snorri Sturlusson (1179 - 1241) was an Icelandic nobleman and poet (poetry and politics go together in the Viking world, remember?). He wrote a lot about Scandinavian history, myth, and legend. He's an MVP of medieval history, because without Snorri's works, we would know much, much less about early Germanic myth, legend, religion, and about the Vikings and their worldview and their poetry. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IVhbVnMLbf60llpgDtw0vjL6cOg8MXM8/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here, in his <em>History of the Kings of Norway</em></a>, (<em>Heimskringla</em>), Snorri includes the story of the last battle of old Harald Hardrada, or "Hard Ruler", (Snorri uses his proper name, Harald Sigurtharson). Harald was the archetypical amazingly successful Viking all the other VIkings wanted to be.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Military and political strengths and weaknesses of Harold Godwinson</li> <li>The wider international political and diplomatic situation of the contested English crown in 1066</li> <li>The nature of warfare and military leadership in northern Europe in 1066</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthke1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthka1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthke2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthka2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthke3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthka3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthke4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$hasthka4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Viking poetry |skaldic]]</li> <li>[[Ring-giving |rg]]</li> <li>[[The Bayeux Tapestry |bt]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Battle of Hastings |conquest]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Viking-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Viking Age |Viking]]</li> <li>[[Back: Battle of Hastings Scenario |Hastings]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are Eleanor of Aquitaine</h1> <p>France, c. 1170</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "el-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "el-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p><em>Note: In reimagining the historical figures in this role play scenario, I have altered the dates a bit. They all lived in the twelfth century, and were active in France and Germany during Twelfth Century Renaissance. However, the their careers did not intertwine as much as this (fictional!) role play scenario suggests. Just FYI. Here are the real dates:</em></p> <ul> <li>Eleanor of Aquitaine: 1122 - 1204</li> <li>Hildegard von Bingen: 1098 - 1179</li> <li>Bernard of Clairvaux: 1090 - 1153</li> <li>Heloise: 1092 - 1163</li> </ul> <p>And now, back to the role play scenario.</p> <p>Sweet music swells around you, rolling off the massive, vaulted ceiling and lifting you toward heaven. You close your eyes and let the tears flow as your soul mingles with God and his saints and eternity. When you're aware of reality again, the voices are gone, replaced by the soft scuffle of many feet on stone as the nuns move on to the next task in their busy day. You open your eyes to a hundred colors of light streaming through the stained glass. For the thousandth time, you thank God for leading you here. And for sending Hildegard to earth: You must write to her again and thank her for sending <<linkappend "her newest composition.">><<include el-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Your mouth curls into a wry smirk as you compare Hildegard's magic with the thin, discordant cacophony of King Louis’ court musicians. His royal halls were cramped and cold, stinking and crowded with ignorant fools - the knights with nothing to say but horses and dogs and killing. You and your ladies lost yourselves in song and story, in the world of King Arthur long ago, of Merlin and fairies and magic. A deluge of gold flowed from your hands into the purses of the minstrels and clerics who wrote and sang the songs. When you left the royal court at Paris and returned home to Poitiers, the best troubadours came too, following the flow of gold. For many, it was a homecoming. Since the days of your grandfather, Duke William X, Aquitaine has been a haven for troubadours and jongleurs and every wayward cleric bored with university life.</p> <p>You once heard a bastard son of your lover, Henry Plantagenet, decline a pre-packaged, high-status career in the church: “I prefer horses and dogs to books and priests.” The meat-headed fool. When they finally annulled your marriage to Louis, you broke free from men like Henry and his bastard. They tried to steal you back as you fled from Paris and marriage and queenship, homeward toward Poitiers. You rode dressed as a man but they still found you out ... it was close.</p> <p>From the safety of your mighty castle of Poitiers, surrounded by walls 15 feet thick and your own garrison, you wrote to Pope Eugenius: “I prefer books and priests to horses and dogs.” He let you establish a new monastic order. After all, you are the richest woman in Europe, with more land, castles, and knights than the king of France (your ex husband), and his arch-rival Duke Henry Plantagenet (one of your ex lovers) combined. You brought this vast inheritance to the Church as your dowry. The pope fell all over himself setting his seal to your new order’s charter, and he’s let you do as you please ever since.</p> <p>You move slowly through the cavernous space toward the scriptorium, deep in thought. You need to write a letter. Pope Eugene has asked Bernard of Clairvaux to call for a Third Crusade. You remember his sermon a decade ago when, at the pope's behest, Bernard preached at Vézelay, calling for the Second Crusade. The crowd went mad, roaring "Deus vult!" and even the soft eyes of <<linkappend "your husband, King Louis,">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include el-link2>><</linkappend>> blazed with maniacal fervor as he committed himself to the holy war. Bernard's success had come at a cost though, when the crusade's failure blackened his reputation. And now the pope wants him to do it again, and Bernard has written to you to ask your advice. You know he's probably written to Hildegard too, and you wonder what she will say. </p> <p>You exit the shadowy cloister arch and cross a sunny courtyard dappled with sunlight and shadow, alive with birdsong. You need to find Heloise before sitting down to write. She's here somewhere. <<linkappend "Heloise's learning far exceeds your own.">><<include el-link3>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> She’s famous for the depth of her knowledge, her rhetorical genius and mastery of dialectical logic. Her correspondence Abelard keeps her in practice. Heloise will be able to help you build your argument in the erudite, scholastic style Bernard will respect. Now, if you could only find her... </p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What is your monastic order like? What are its goals? What are some of its rules? How might your passion for chilvalric romance and the legends of King Arthur influence your monastic order's interpretation of Christianity and the monastic vocation, especially the role of women?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What is your advice to Bernard of Clairvaux regarding a prospective third crusade? What are the results?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your sense of identity, both as an aristocrat and as a woman</li> <li>Your experience of life at court, in marriage, and on crusade</li> </ul> <div class="container"> <div class="row center question"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>The Victorians absolutely loved the Middle Ages. They built in the gothic style that was becoming popular during Eleanor of Aquitaine's life. Probably the most famous example of this 19th-century gothic revival are the Houses of Parliament in London:</p> <img src="images/parliament.jpg" alt="houses of parliament" width="80%"> <p>They even <em>re</em>built old churches in the gothic style, whether the church was from that period or not (unfortunately erasing much fine romanesque and Anglo-Saxon architecture in their anachronistic zeal). As the children of Romanticism, Victorians were inclined to feel nostalgic for the simpler and more honest times of the Middle Ages, when (they imagined) people lived in harmony with nature and felt genuine passion for God (in contrast to their urbanizing, industrializing, machine-driven world). Victorian authors like Tennyson and Scott revived the old legends of King Arthur and his knights of Camelot. Artists of the Preraphaelite school did the same. Here are some notable (and splendid) examples.</p> <p>Waterhouse, "The Lady of Shalott" (1888)</p> <p><img src="images/waterhouse-shallot.jpg" alt="woman in a boat" width="80%"></p> <p>Draper, "Guinevere and Lancelot" (1895)</p> <p><img src="images/draper-guen.jpg" alt="women on a dias surrounded by flowers" width="80%"></p> <p>Dicksee, "La Belle Dame sans Merci" (c. 1900)</p> <p><img src="images/dicksee-dame.jpg" alt="woman rides warhorse as knight in full armor walks beside her" width="80%"></p> <p>Leighton, "God Speed" (1900)</p> <p><img src="images/leighton-godspeed.jpg" alt="woman addresses mounted knight" width="80%"></p> <p>Leighton, "The Accolade" (1901)</p> <p><img src="images/leighton-acolade.jpg" alt="woman dubs kneeling knight with sword" width="80%"></p> <hr> <p>Was there a "real" King Arthur?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Um ... that's a terrible question?">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Quite so. There was a real guy in fifth-century post-Roman England who did things like unite British resistance to Germanic invasion. His story later ossified as legend and then permutated into more legends. Was that guy "King Arthur?" There may be no valid answer that exact question.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Nah.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>Well, sort of... but there's more to it than a blanket negative. We'd miss quite a lot of interesting historical inquiry if we just go with a simple "no" here (though you're forgiven if you think that's not such a bad thing...).<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pope calls for crusade |crusade]]</li> <li>[[Codex Manesse |manesse]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Women and courtly romance |romance]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights Portal |Knights]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Age of Knights</p> <p><img src="images/hma.jpg" alt="knight" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copyel"> <<if (def $elmane1) and ($elmane1 isnot Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: Medieval Peasants</p> <p><img src="images/peasants.jpg" alt="shearing sheep and reaping wheat" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. Go write some history!</p> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>First: Save a screenshot</h2> <p><span class="bi">Important:</span> Save a screen shot of your score at the top of the page. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and secondary sources. <span class="bi">Use the copy button</span> to move this material into Canvas as the foundation of your role play assignment.</p> <p>If you want another look at the sources later, you can also find them in the Source Anthology on Canvas.</p> </div> <div class="row marginalia"> <div class="cite"> <div class="row copynotes" id="copyfor"> <<if (def $forbe1) and ($forbe1 isnot $forppa4>><p> (Goldberg, <em>Franks</em>)</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyFor()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copyfors"> <<if (def $forbe1) and ($forbe1 isnot "")>><p>“Books of the Hunt," Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104, Instructor: Queen, accessed [date]</p><</if>> <<if (def $forace1) and ($forace1 isnot "")>><p>"Hunting Accidents," Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104, Instructor: Queen, accessed [date]</p> <</if>> <<if (def $forgge1) and ($forgge1 isnot "")>><p><em>Sir Gawain and the Green Knight</em>, transl. James J. Wilhelm, in James J. Wilhelm, ed., <em>The Romance of Arthur: An Anthology of Medieval Texts in Translation</em> (New York: Garland, 1994)</p><</if>> <<if (def $forffe1) and ($forffe1 isnot "")>><p>Nicholas Orme, "Medieval Hunting: Fact and Fancy," in Barbara A. Hanawalt, ed., <em>Chaucer's England: Literature in Historical Context</em> (Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 1992), pp. 133 - 153.</p><</if>> <<if (def $forppe1) and ($forppe1 isnot "")>><p>Eric J. Goldberg, <em>In the Manner of the Franks: Hunting, Kingship, and Masculinity in Early Medieval Europe</em> (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2020).</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyFors()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Portal |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Hildegard of Bingen led a brilliant career as a church leader. A powerful player in twelfth century high politics, she corresponded with, negotiated with, debated, and occasionally chastized figures as powerful as popes and bishops, and the charismatic Cistercian Bernard of Clairvaux. She published widely on medicine, natural history, saints' lives, heresies, crusades, and contributed to the current debates of the twelfth-century academic scene. In her intellectual achievements, Hildegard stands alone. But the power she wielded as a woman in the medieval church was not anomalous. Though medieval society was patriarchal, many women acted with as much autonomy and wielded as much power as their male contemporaries. A career in the church could free women from some of the constraints and sources of inequality they would have faced in the secular world. (For instance, a couple of Merovingian princesses who resented being put into nunneries led the nuns in all-out military rebellions that were not unsuccessful (for a time...).</p> <p>Hildegard was a mystic and a visionary whose prophetic connection to God was acknowledged and legitimized by the pope. (I wonder if he ever regretted doing that, when he received some of her stinging rebukes, spoken as a prophet of God in the thundering style of Isaiah!) She wrote about her visions and the theological systems they inspired her to formulate, accompanying these texts with magnificent, complex illustrations, including the examples below.</p> <p><img src="images/hildegard-vision1" alt="circular composition of angels singing" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/hildegard-vision2" alt="abstract diagram of creation" width="80%"></p> <p>And when she got bored, Hildegard created her own secret language. So, the lady was basically a genius. We might call her a polymath, I guess? Today, Hildegard is most widely remembered for the music she composed. People continue to savor and to record it today. Here is her <a href="https://youtu.be/puAOTgq3Wkc?si=udVp1XgGycJL-Caw" target="_blank">"Columba aspexit"</a> (one of my favorites), and <a href="https://youtu.be/5TdkOE3-vMQ?si=F9Oln_bTx3j6kxAI" target="_blank">an antiphon,</a>, and <a href="https://youtu.be/zUlRIqu-74E?si=q8jEPiBCNOfyBRkz" target="_blank">"O ecclesia"</a> (also incredible, if you like this kind of thing).</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>What most people know about Heloise is her relationship with Abelard. As a young woman, Heloise was widely known for her intellectual ability. Abelard was an ambitious young monk with a promising career as a leading intellectual ahead of him. When Heloise's relatives let Abelard stay at their house in exchange for his tutoring services for Heloise, the pair became sexual partners. Heloise became pregnant but refused a traditional marriage with Abelard because it would end his brillian career as a scholar. Instead, they married in secret. Heloise's relatives became abusive and castrated Abelard (it's a miracle he survived this, considering medical care in twelfth-century Europe). Heloise and Abelard took monastic vows at separate establishments and each continued to flourish in their scholarly careers. Abelard in particular, became something of a celebrity, feuded with Bernard of Clairvaux (and other powerful people), and was convicted of heresy. This illustration (below)from a 15th-century French manuscript shows Heloise and Abelard in earnest conversation.</p> <p><img src="images/heloise-abelard.jpg" alt="man and woman talking" width="80%"></p> <p>The two exchanged letters throughout their lives. These letters, along with Abelard's autobiography called <em>The History of Calamaties</em>, have somehow survived through the centuries, and can tell us a good deal about the lives and outlook of the twelfth-century intellectual elite (male and female). Of the many memorable lines is one in which Heloise tells Abelard that women are better suited to monastic life than men, because women's bodies are naturally "wet" (according to the medieval science of bodies and "humors"), and monks drink a lot, so it's a perfect life for women. And here's Abelard recalling their early romance in his autobiography: "We exchanged more kisses than learned propositions. My hands returned more often to her bosom than to our books."</p> </div> <div class="container"> <h1>Pope Urban II's Call for Crusade</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In 1095, Pope Urban II began the crusades with <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1rCqitG0fRUtIUSXwNTG4_MSm7ay3VeBYyOeIKAIP90o/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this speech</a> at the Council of Clermont, calling for knights from western Europe to defend Byzantium from the advancing Muslim armies.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How the medieval elite understood the crusade movement</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elcre1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elcra1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elcre2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elcra2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elcra4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pope calls for crusade |crusade]]</li> <li>[[Codex Manesse |manesse]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Women and courtly romance |romance]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: Eleanor of Aquitaine |Eleanor]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Women and Arthurian Romance</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <p>The patronage of noblewomen (Eleanor of Aquitaine in particular) supported (and often directed) the poets and singers who composed the stories of Arthurian romance. We have the ladies of the court to thank for the splendid proliferation of these fantastical stories that have fueled creative writers for centuries - from Shakespeare's plays to <em>Lord of the Rings</em> to <em>Game of Thrones</em>. Without women like Eleanor of Aquitaine, we may never have known about these tales of Arthur and the knights of Camelot, of tournaments and quests, powerful queens and courtly love, magic and fairies, Merlin and Morgan le Fay. <a href="" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from Derek Pearsall's <em>Introduction to Arthurian Romance</em> explains the role of women in the production of medieval romance.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Aspects of Arthurian romance that were meaningful or appealing to noblewomen</li> <li>Ideas of gender and sexuality prevalent among the nobility, as reflected by this popular genre</li> <li>Ways in which aristocratic women wielded power at court</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elre1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elra1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elre2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elra2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the pope calls for crusade |crusade]]</li> <li>[[Codex Manesse |manesse]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: Eleanor of Aquitaine |Eleanor]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Medieval Noblewomen</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The remarkable Codex Manesse, created in Germany c. 1300, holds a treasury of medieval romance and courtly songs and poetry. It is also graced with numerous illuminated pages, depicting the high medieval nobility as they liked to imagine themselves, the height of chivalry. Have a look at these <a href="https://heidicon.ub.uni-heidelberg.de/search?p=243&ot=objekte&input=%7B%22query%22:%5B%7B%22class%22:%22QueryElementField%22,%22data%22:%7B%22field%22:%7B%22class%22:%22StringColumn%22,%22mask%22:%7B%22name%22:%22objekte_standard_maske%22%7D,%22field%22:%7B%22name%22:%22objekte.obj_sig%22%7D%7D,%22_ot_name%22:%22_objekte_standard_maske%22,%22data%22:%7B%22obj_sig%22:%22%5C%22cod.%20pal.%20germ.%20848%2C%5C%22%22,%22obj_sig:mode%22:%22fulltext%22,%22obj_sig:type%22:%22fulltext%22,%22obj_sig:unset%22:false%7D%7D%7D%5D%7D" target="_blank">illuminated pages</a> in their full, fantastical, digitized and zoomable glory.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Gender ideals among the high medieval aristocracy, especially roles and activities of women</li> <li>The chivalric ideals, court culture, and romance Eleanor of Aquitaine enjoyed so much during her life as patron of poets and singers</li> <li>Really, how different are the men and women? When are they depicted differently? How? What does this suggest about gender and sexuality among the medieval aristocracy? How can this help us understand Eleanor of Aquitaine's beliefs about gender and sexuality?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmane1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmana1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmane2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmana2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmane3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmana3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmane4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elmana4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pope calls for crusade |crusade]]</li> <li>[[Codex Manesse |manesse]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Women and courtly romance |romance]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: Eleanor of Aquitaine |Eleanor]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Punic Wars</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1djqzTjGXN4G21VxUlRhk8YoMwFTHx9rd/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">These sections</a> of John Warry's book, <em>Warfare in the Classical World</em> focus on siege warfare in the Hellenistic period, and Rome's wars with Carthage.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Siege tactics at the time of Pyrrhus' invasion of Italy</li> <li>Rome's and Pyrrhus' military, economic, and political strengths and weaknesses</li> <li>The importance of the context of Rome's struggle with Carthage</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Battles of Cannae and Zama</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Early in the first century CE, the Roman historian Livy produced a ponderous mass of scrolls known as his <em>History of Rome</em> (completed by Livy's death in 17 CE). In <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/10ni3IOU8lK-Qw69tCw5RgKHm7GofljDCbiw6qhlQqcU/edit?usp=sharing " target="_blank">Books 22 and 30</a>, he relates the history of the Rome's epic defeat at the Battle of Cannae in 216 BCE, and its success against Hannibal at the Battle of Zama in 202 BCE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The political, economic, ideological context of these battles</li> <li>Strategic and tactical options for the Romans and Carthaginians</li> <li>Rome's relationship with its allies</li> <li>The long-term significance of the battles in the evolution of a Roman political or national identity</li> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of Rome and Carthage</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannle2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$cannla2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How homosexual behaviors and relationships were viewed in the Hellenistic World</li> <li>The limits of our knowledge about homosexuality in the Hellenistic World, including past and present scholarly debates</li> <li>Homosexuality and ideals of masculinity in the Hellenistic World</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Alexandria Scenario |Alexandria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Theophrastus, <em>Characters</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Theophrastus was an influential Athenian philosopher, and successor to Aristotle in the school of philosophy (Lyceum) at Athens. In <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1DB8vD42mIHLN1mGOFF6rCnXDmHmLXFAQ/view?usp=sharing " target="_blank"><em>Characters</em> (c. 280 CE)</a>, Theophrastus descends from the rarified heights of metaphysics and science to discuss some of the types of people he commonly encounters. This is only an excerpt of the longer work, but it is representative: It includes no "good" characters, no females, and nobody from lower socio-economic strata. If you're interested, you can find the whole book with a full list of "characters" at <a href="https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/58242/pg58242-images.html" target="_blank">Project Gutenberg</a>.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How do Hellenistic philosophers and scholars interact? How do they judge each other?</li> <li>What kinds of people aren't represented here? Who is important, and who is invisible?</li> <li>How should people behave and live?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexthe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alextha1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexthe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alextha2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexthe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alextha3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alexthe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$alextha4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Epicureanism |epicurus</li> <li>[[Stoicism |epictetus]]</li> <li>[[People |theophrastus]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Homosexuality in Ancient Greece |homosexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Done collecting material?</h2> <p>Your notes from this source are saved. If you need more material, look through some more sources below. If you're done with your research and ready to write, move on to the Victory! page and end the game. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Alexandria Scenario |Alexandria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Stoicism</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1iikavu03o91FQArnXrgimkV_-Fc_t8rb/view?usp=sharing " target="_blank">This excerpt</a> from the <em>Enchiridion of Epictetus</em> captures the key tenets of Stoicism, which was a popular and influential philosophy in the Hellenistic and Roman era. Few texts by Stoicism's founder, Zeno of Citium, have survived, and the <em>Enchiridion</em> was written in the second century CE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How would Epicureans view death?</li> <li>How would the Epicurean view of death determine their views on virtue, the value of life, self, and honor?</li> <li>How should people behave and live?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. You'll find your notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Hellenistic-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Portal |Hellenistic]]</li> <li>[[Back: Alexandria Scenario |Alexandria]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>An African Boy is Enslaved</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-FmyX3SJaMUZIJEIMuplVz0Lpxl7ptp5Y2wJ9eMUIcc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This excerpt</a> from the autobiography of Olaudah Equiano was written about a century after our course ends. However, very, very few first-hand accounts of the experience of enslavement in the Atlantic slave trade have survived. Equiano's autobiography is precious indeed. Keep the chronological distance between this role play scenario (c. 1615) and Equiano's enslavement (c. 1770s) in mind as you approach this incredibly powerful, informative source.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The experience of enslavement in the Atlantic slave trade system</li> <li>The impact of the Atlantic slave trade on African societies, culture, communities, families, individuals</li> <li>Important dynamics in the development of antiblack racism in the early modern West</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. "Marginalia" boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: An African Artist |Artist]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Origins of Antiblack Racism</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TqwYOgGybGgpVzsFivwWja625I1ECp4B/view?usp=drive_link" target="_blank">This chapter</a> from David Brion Davis' wonderful book about the history of racial slavery in the Americas focuses on the development of antiblack racism in the age of the Atlantic slave trade.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. It's not an easy read, but you might enjoy its stimulating and incisive distillation of primary source data into (sometimes surprising) profound conclusions.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. "$arteltise4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$arteltisa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[An African boy is enslaved |equiano]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2>
