from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: An African Artist |Artist]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, a witch hunt is coming.</h1> <p>A rural village, c. 1600</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "witch-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "witch-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p><em>Note: The subject of this role play scenario is a real person. Thomasine Hall was raised in England in the early 1600s as a girl. As a teenager, they assumed a male gender identity, joined a mercenary company, and fought on the continent before immigrating to the Virginia colony as a male indentured servant.</em></p> <p><em>And now, back to the role play scenario ... </em></p> <hr> <p>A storm is coming. You felt it in the heavy air as you rode toward the village this evening. The willows and elms writhed and heaved in the wind like souls roiling in hellfire. The ripe wheat rippled across the fields, an eerie, luminous green beneath the dark clouds that rushed across the sky.</p> <p>The rain caught you on the road before you reached the clothier's house. Now, <<linkappend "your finely-embroiedered clothing">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include witch-link3>><</linkappend>> is spread out to dry around the hearth. You savor the warmth of the fire, idly rubbing your sword with an oilcloth, sitting quietly with your friend in the companionable silence of old friendship. He's a tailor as well as a clothier, and he's fascinated by the seed pearls on your new doublet, and the stuffing from your pantaloons - eviscerated and deflated now, their stuffing strewn across the hearth and steaming in the heat. He's sketching a new design on a scrap of paper, glancing at your finery for inspiration. A taste for fine cloth and fashion was what brought you together as children. You sip your ale and lean back against the wall, listening to the rain. It's good to be home, safe and warm, your horse fed and dry in the clother's barn. You should sleep, but you know this feeling of safety is an illusion. The storm outside is nothing compared to the storm that's rising in the village. You felt it as you rode through the market square this evening, not quite deserted in the twilight: the furtive glances, the timing of the silences, the muttering, the too-loud declarations of loyalty to a friend or to God.</p> <p>When you asked the clothier for the local news just now, he shook his head. The neighboring village had half its ripe corn trampled by mercenaries. It's nearly June. No time to try for a second harvest. <<linkappend "Some houses were burned and a few people died.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include witch-link4>><</linkappend>> Then, a few days ago, two women in your village gave birth to dead children. Your mother was at both births. She's been a widow for twenty years and lives quite comfortably on the outskirts of the village, hiring laborers to farm her few acres of arable, renting her pasture to neighbors. Everyone knows she has special knowledge and special powers. They come to her for help with illness or death or birth or any number of the inevitable pains and humiliations of life in a human body. She is one of the "wise folk" or "cunning folk." Every village has one or two.</p> <p>Your mother is the reason you came home. Filial duty. And you actually like the old crone. You always learn something from her stories, once you sort out what's real from what she imagined. It was good to see the miller, too, and a few others. You should leave now, but you're worried about your mother. In hard times, more is expected of people like her. The impossible is expected - like bringing stillborn babies to life. The families will need someone to blame. They want to avoid the appearance of guilt, of deserving such punishments from God. The village will need someone to blame, for the same reason. They will reach for order and justice in this senseless world where <<linkappend "innocent babies die before drawing a breath.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include witch-link1>><</linkappend>> They need someone to blame.</p> <p>Once they go looking for witches, they always find them. They'll be looking for anyone outside the usual, anyone different. And you are ... different. Your name is Thomas now, and you've spent the last decade in Germany and the Low Countries serving as a mercenary. But you grew up here as Thomasine in long hair and dresses, standing with the women in church, making lace and selling it in that market square. (You still make lace when you're short of cash - no uncommon occurrence in the life of a mercenary.) But to most people, you are a man. A few folk here, like your old friend, the clothier, remember you as a little girl. <<linkappend "They aren't bothered that you're different in this way.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include witch-link2>><</linkappend>> But that difference will be a deadly danger when they start looking for witches.</p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Etymologies are interesting. They can also be powerful. Sometimes people point to a word's origin or history as a persuasive, or even a conclusive, Q.E.D. case-closed piece of evidence in support of their argument or agenda. It's nothing new. Back in 1487 when the woman-hating (he was working through a bad breakup, actually) priest Heinrich Kramer and James Sprenger first published a book about how to find, torture, and kill witches (<em>Malleus Maleficarum</em>, or "The Hammer of the Witches"), they supported their argument that "women are often witches because women are evil" with false etymologies (and mis-quotations of the Bible, and all kinds of shoddy scholarship and bad logic that would be funny if the book hadn't helped kill and torture so many people). For instance, they pointed to the Latin word for woman, <em>femina</em>. "See!?" they said, "The very <em>word</em> "woman" comes from the words for "faith" (<em>fe</em>) and "less" (<em>minus</em>. So of course women are naturally faithless and evil. Ergo, women are witches! Q.E.D."</p> <hr> <p>"Weird" is an ordinary enough word, but there are witches in its history. We can find it way back in <em>Beowulf</em>, where Old English <em>wyrd</em> denoted "fate." Fate was important in these early Germanic societies, especially their ideas about masculinity and honor. As Beowulf himself explains it, "Fate will often save a man, if his courage holds." It's a kind of grim and stoic fatalism, a reliance on one's own courage in the face of irresistible and immutable fate.</p> <p>This is where the witches come in. Shakespeare's 1606 play, <em>Macbeth</em>, features witches who foretell the future. Shakespeare calls them "the 'weïrd' or 'weyard' sisters. Since "weird," like its ancestor Old English <em>wyrd</em> meant "fate or destiny," it makes sense to give this name to fortune-telling witches. Over the years, especially in the early nineteenth century when romanticism rekindled people's interest in Shakespeare, these weird sisters" transformed the meaning of the word in our language. People began using "weird" as we do today, to mean "odd," rather than in the Old English sense of "fate."</p> <p>Do you think the Englis noun "witch" is related to the English pronoun "which?"</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Negative. They're just homophones with no linguistic connection.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">>Just so. Like creek and creak or bare and bear, and many others.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Probably.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">>It does look that way, but in this case, they are not linguistically related, even though they sound the same. Lots of words are like that (for instance, piece and peace, or knot and not).<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What will you do? Stay in the village or leave? Why?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How will the nonbinary nature of your gender identity impact your situation in a rural village witch hunt?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your skills, knowledge, resources (such as money, weapons, transportation, status and social connections).</li> <li>Current social and economic conditions in your village (e.g., prosperity or hardship, stability or fragmentation).</li> </ul> <div class="container"> <div class="row center question"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>Dan Brown's mass market thriller, <em>The Da Vinci Code</em> was enjoyed by millions of readers and vieweres in the early 2000s. Its delicious tale of conspiracies involving the Templar Knights, the Holy Grail, and the Vatican popularized the (quite imaginary) idea that the Catholic Church orchestrated the early modern witch trials in a deliberate attempt to enforce the patriarchal order and oppress "free-thinking women" (in the words of Brown's fictional characters). This narrative fits so neatly into popular culture today, that it has had a significant impact on most people's understanding of the witch hunts, in spite of the fact that it has little relation to the historical record or the findings of historians. As we've learned in this class (I hope!), women were active as aggressors in witch hunts, and men were often victims. The man vs. woman dichotomy does not fit the historical record. But it certainly sells paperbacks and movies...</p> <p>It's interesting to see these dynamics at work. When an interpretation of history (usually a big-picture metanarrative yielding convenient and feel-good "lessons") meshes with prevailing popular beliefs, it sticks and has power, even when it is not accepted by the academic community.</p> <hr> <p>We still use the term "witch hunt" today, typically as a pejorative term for unjust, illogical, biased attacks. Do you remember hearing the term recently, maybe in the news?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Yes, definitely.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Me too.<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>I bet you will hear it soon, and now it will have deeper meaning since you know the historical background.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the role play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Images of witches |witch-images]]</li> <li>[[An English witch trial |scott]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Early modern masculinity |roper]]</li> <li>[[A non-binary person |thomasine]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance Portal |Renaissance]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you an artist</h1> <p>Florence, Italy, c. 1620</p> </div> <div class="container question center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "art-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "art-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p><<linkappend "You sit bowed over your papers and brushes, silent and motionless, deep in thought.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link1>><</linkappend>> You feel at home here in the busy workshop run by your friend, <<linkappend "Artemisia Gentileschi, at the court of the Grand Duchess Christina of Tuscany.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link4>><</linkappend>> It's a busy place, the sounds of creation almost deafening. All around you, people are grinding pigmants, mixing paints, cutting canvas, hammering frames, the clink of brushes on cups, and a ceaseless current of voices chattering, muttering, laughing, occasionally shouting a request to the servants whose feet are never still. It feels like the courtyard of your father's home on any day of the year: full of women hulling rice, weaving cloth, chasing children, washing and sweeping and chattering all the while. You sit and stare at your paper, white and unblemished. The workshop has the same busy, happy feel and the noise doesn't interrupt your ruminations as you think about your new project: How can I make them see that slavery is a sin? That Africans are people just like them?</p> <p>The idea has been growing in your mind since you've started attending some of the court meetings. The Grand Duchess Christina is the sun in a heliocentric system. Great minds are drawn to her court, and you relish the conversations and the controversy, the letters and treatises read aloud and debated for hours. They argue about everything from the stars to the scripture. Usually you love it. But last week they were talking about the Indians in the New World, asking if they really had souls. They started mapping out differences between the English, the French, the Germans, the Italians, between Florentines and Venitians, Sicilians and Romans. Soon, they were comparing Moors and Indians and Arabs and, inevitably, <<linkappend "Africans.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link2>><</linkappend>> Eyes began to slide your way, and people edged away from you until you were standing in an empty space and your face began to burn.</p> <p>Now, staring at the blank paper, your cheeks heat up again, remembering the feeling. You remember, too, hearing about how a Spanish priest condemned his own countrymen for their cruelty toward the Indians. You've seen some of those images, and <<linkappend "felt their power.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include art-link3>><</linkappend>> Protestant heretics have been doing the same, making woodcuts and pelting every city north of the Alps with evil caricatures of the pope and calls for reform. Those images, too, had power ... which means <em>you</em>, in this workshop, have power too.</p> <p>So what can you create to fight against that system whose grasp you felt in court? The "natural" system they are imagining, which will place some people in slavery and some in liberty? The system that suddenly made you feel like an alien in your own home? You hear Artemisia's voice and look up. Maybe she can help with this project. Or maybe it's something you will need to do alone.</p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>As we've seen in these "pet the zombie" interludes, language changes over time, carrying bits of history along with it. Then, that history-infused language fills up our heads, coloring our outlook on the world and even our feelings about ourselves and others. This is our last role play unit. We'll close the zombie petting zoo with profanity.</p> <p>Why do we use profanity? Swear words are like little explosions of emotion. That's their real purpose. And that's why their semantic content can be so malleable - "fuck" can mean sooooo many things, right? And it can be employed in so many different contexts. But what's the use of a word with so many meanings? Seems kind of pointless. Not quite. With swear words, it's the word's <em>energy</em> rather than its exact denotation (or even wider connotation) that has value as a means of communication.</p> <p>In the Renaissance, profanity began to change, keeping pace with people's changing worldview. Before the Renaissance, in the Middle Ages, people's worldview was profoundly religious. So medieval profanity had to be religious to carry a sting, to deliver the little emotional <em>zing</em> swear words have to deliver in order to "work." Walking into a fourteenth-century market town and yelling, "By God's wounds!" would have flattened the crowd. Horrified silence. But if you yelled "Fuck that shit!" in the same fourteenth-century town, people wouldn't bat an eye. Bodily functions were no big deal. Fuckbythenavel and Fuckbutter were actual medieval surnames. Gropecunt and Fuckingrove were place names of record. Because "fuck" and "cunt" weren't regarded as particularly strong language. Medieval people saw sex and death on the regular. They took kids to watch public executions. No big deal. But witches and heretics? <em>That's</em> a big deal and we will burn them as soon as we find them. So, it makes sense that medieval swear words relating to bodily functions didn't pack much of a punch. They were maybe a little <em>salty,</em> but not strong. Swear words relating to religion, though, were powerful. Blasphemy was an actual crime.</p> <p><em>Sidetrack: This is a little like the way kids' movies have changed in the last century. 1970s Warner Bros and Disney cheerfully included smoking, racism, and violence in kids' movies, but they would have flipped out at telling kids about same sex romantic relationships. In the 2020s, the opposite standards apply to kids' movies.</em></p> <p>Today in the 2020s, saying, "Oh my God!" goes unnoticed, but saying, "Oh, fuck!" will raise some eyebrows. You can probably say "damn" or "hell" at Christmas dinner, but not the "f word." It would have been <em>the reverse</em> for medieval people. For instance, in 1528 in the manuscript below, an English cleric recorded his opinion about his boss: "O d fuckin abbot." The cleric (a church officer!) was fine with writing the f-word, but drew the line at writing out "damn," because that was just going too far. "Fuck" was salty, "damn" was dirty. And, by the way, that particular abbot <em>did</em> have a reputation for literally fucking, so... </p> <p><img src="images/profanity.jpg" alt="manuscript page" width="80%"></p> <p>So, back to the Renaissance... By, 1600 when actors strode across Shakespeare's stage yelling things like, "S'blood!," (politely short for "God's blood"), viewers were shocked and titilated (just as we expect to be when we watch HBO). (Fun fact: This is the first word spoken on stage by Iago, the most evil of all evil Shakespeare villains!). In 1600, where our semester ends, blasphemy was still pretty strong language (still illegal, actually). People expected it at the playhouse, just like we expect f-bombs on HBO.</p> <p>So here comes the "undead history" feature: archaic profanity that just won't die. Ever heard someone say, "Darn!"? Well, it's a contraction of "'Tarnation!" which comes from "'Tarnal!" which was short for "By Eternal God!" And "Zounds!" is a short form of "By God's wounds!" We don't hear those too often today, but sometimes.</p> <p>Interested in the way our language continues to evolve today? Check out <a href="https://www.urbandictionary.com/" target="_blank">Urban Dictionary</a> and have fun!</p> <hr> <p>Which Shakespeare insult do you like best?</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>Not written yet...</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>Not written yet...</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>item</li> <li></li> </ul> <div class="container"> <div class="row center question"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>In the not-so-distant decade of the 1980s, someone named Joan Kelly was traveling this road through the history of the Renaissance. And as she traveled, admiring the spectacular art and the humanism, and marveling at the birth of science, she wondered, "What about the women?" In 1984, she published an article called "Did Women have a Renaissance?" and it tore through academia like a fire bomb. She answered her question with a definite, "no," and went on to radically reorient and reanimate scholarly approaches to medieval and renaissance history, as well as the entire (relatively young in 1984) field of women's history. It was one of those finger of God, <em>Deus ex Machina</em>, "Let there be light!" moments. A beautiful thing.</p> <p>Here's a representative quote from Kelly's landmark article: "All the advances of Renaissance Italy, its proto-capitalist economy, its states, and its humanistic culture, worked to mould the noblewoman into an aesthetic object: decorous, chaste and doubly dependent - on her husband as well as the prince." <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[An African boy is enslaved |equiano]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The origins of anti-black racism |bondage]]</li> <li>[[Gender and slavery |eltis]]</li> <li>[[European descriptions of African women |morgan]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance Portal |Renaissance]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are in love</h1> <p>A rural village, c. 1300</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "love-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "love-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>It's summer solstice. <<linkappend "The St John's Eve bonfire">><<include love-link1>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> roars up into heaven, loud and hot and glorious.</p> <p>You lounge in the shadows, avoiding the heat of the flames. The night is still warm, and you feel the urgency of its haste. <em>There's not much time.</em> Midsummer nights begin and end in a single breath. Carefully cradling a cup brimming with good mead, you watch the one you love. Jostling against their friends, laughing and singing, they dance around the roaring bonfire. They're like a spirit, like a flame. You take another drink, feeling miserable and excited at the same time, desperate to make something happen before dawn. <em>Not much time.</em> You've been in love with them for at least a year now, but barely exchanged a few words.</p> <p>You look away into the night and take another drink. <em>It's no good,</em> you think for the thousandth time. Even if you could manage to catch their attention somehow, then what? Lovers for a time? Or together forever? Impossible. Your families hate each other. The manor court rolls groan with the weight of your ancestors' names, taking each other to court for generations: property lines, insults and assaults, fraud, bad sales, theft, debt (on both sides), shirking boon work (again, on both sides). The parish church has heard an equally lengthy back-and-forth over the centuries: drunkenness, fornication, adultery, scolding, eating meat during Lent, blasphemy, witchcraft. It will never end. You sigh and let your chin drop onto your chest, resting your eyes from the blinding sight of your beloved. But you can still hear their voice: clear and exultant in song and laughter. Singing the night away.</p> <p>You take another drink and remember the <<linkappend "Easter play">><<include love-link2>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><</linkappend>> a few months ago. Their family played the Romans and Jews and devils, and your family played Christ and the disciples and the angels. The fight was epic, as usual. You run your fingers over the new scar on your forearm where one of their brothers "accidentally" stabbed all the way through and out the other side with the hard ash-wood tine of his pitchfork. You had played Jesus this year, and when they were nailing you to the cross, he sat his bare arse on your head (you take another drink, remembering ...). So, you grabbed the crown of thorns and stuck it in one of his hairy hams. And he "accidentally" stabbed you with the pitchfork, repeatedly. It was pretty much the same at the Christmas play. One year, the priests tried to split you up so there were some from each family on each side of the Easter play. A smile comes across you as you remember, and a chuckle bursts out. They'll never try that again. Another year, when your family made the Noah parade wagon in the mystery play, a bunch of them put rotten eggs on a hidden plank underneath, so when the wagon rolled through the market square, it left a trail of stench and broken eggs behind. And then there was the fight at the May Day Robin Hood play last month... You sigh and drink again.</p> <p>Your cup feels so light. The fire's rage is cooling. You look east and see a glow. <em>Not much time.</em> You get up and move toward the one you want.</p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Peasants may not have left much of a written record (except for the eternal neighborhood bickering preserved in manor court rolls). But they left traces in the words we use every day. Think about surnames, for instance. Many of our most common English names have their roots in the trades by which people were known in medieval times: Miller, Carter, Wheeler, Smith. There are also plenty of figures of speech from peasant life still in common use today. "Windfall," for instance: The forest was commonly owned by the lord, and peasants were not allowed to harvest forest resources (like wild game or timber) without permission. But when a storm blew down a huge tree, it was considered a common resource to be used by the village. The huge beams common in medieval buildings could only come from large, old trees. A "windfall" was when such a tree fell down, typically in a storm. It was a stroke of good luck for the community.</p> <p>You can see these huge beams, characteristic of medieval timber frame architecture, here on a barn and a a guildhall from fifteenth-century England</p> <p><img src="images/timberframe-barn.jpg" alt="timber frame interior" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/york-guildhall.jpg" alt="timber frame exterior" width="80%"></p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What do you say to your beloved? What are they like? Why do you love them?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>How will you achieve some kind of romantic union with this person? How will you deal with the family problem? Is marriage possible? Or desirable?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>item</li> <li></li> </ul> <div class="container"> <div class="row center question"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>History of the history</p> image caption <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="container"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Scenes from peasant life |life]]</li> <li>[[From Chaucer's <em>Canterbury Tales</em> |miller]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Peasant life and relationships |penifader]]</li> <li>[[Medieval sexuality |sexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are the king of Jerusalem</h1> <p>Near the Sea of Galillee, 1187</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "hattin-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "hattin-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>You're dreaming of rippling meadows, shady glens, rushing brooks, of the pennants on your father's castle spiraling idly on a breeze. Of deer silently browsing in the shadows, fairies dancing in a ring, peasant wenches singing to their geese on the river bank. <<linkappend "The Poitou of your youth is cool and green.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link1>><</linkappend>> It disappears in a blast of blazing sunlight and wind hot as dragon's breath. Someone has opened the tent flap and they are talking to you. You force yourself to sit up and open your eyes but it takes a few moments to will yourself to hear them as the hellish heat of Palestine crushes you. After a decade in Holy Land, you still have to struggle to function in the heat. King of Jerusalem? King of Hades.</p> <p>Slowly, you realize they are telling you that <<linkappend "Saladin has taken Tiberias.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<include hattin-link2>><</linkappend>> A deep bark of laughter escapes your chest before you choke it back and maintain your poise. Ah, what the hell. You laugh loud enough to wake the dead. Then, you send for the others and while you wait, drinking warm, dirty water and savoring every sip as if it were a cool riesling from the castle cellars of Poitiers, you think about your options.</p> <p>Gerard de Ridefort is a fanatic, <<linkappend "especially since Cresson.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link3>><</linkappend>> He's supported you so far because your interests aligned. He will want to attack. Raynald de Chatillon is as explosive. This whole thing is his fault, for breaking the truce you had negotiated with Saladin. He will want to attack. Raymond of Tripoli will want to ransom his wife. Perhaps ... She had held Tiberias with a small garrison, until now. The Hospitallers will want to do whatever the Templars don't want to do. And you, Gui de Lusignan, King of Jerusalem? What do you want to do? You want to go home. But you also want to be king of Jerusalem. You know it's suicidal folly to pursue Saladin toward Tiberias, into the hills at Hattin. That's obviously what he wants, for equally obvious reasons. He'll have the heights and the water, and you'll have no room to maneuver.</p> <p>He tried this four years ago and you refused to be tempted. You marched straight past his trap and returned safely to Jerusalem. But then Raynald and his Hospitaller allies accused you of cowardice and even of a secret alliance with Salain (as Raynald himself had been ...). They called it a failure and cowardice unworthy of a knight, and used the incident to depose you from the throne of Jerusalem. For a time. So. You set down the empty chalise and use these moments of solitude to think. As usual, Saladin has positioned you all <<linkappend "like pieces on a chess board.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link5>><</linkappend>> You know it is idiotic to attack him at Hattin. He knows you know this. But (as he also knows), the others - Raynald and Raymond and Gerard and the rest - want to see you fail. They will push you to take the bait and enter the jaws of the trap, even though they know it's a trap. They will accuse you of cowardice and treachery again, forcing you into a doomed battle, into the hell of Hattin. Saladin knows what you are thinking, what they will say. And he knows that you know he knows.</p> <p>Saladin outnumbers you, <<linkappend "but that's normal.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include hattin-link4>><</linkappend>> The problem is water. And your friends. They are a problem. You hear them arguing already as they near your tent. You close your eyes and savor one brief memory of home before the tent flap opens again.</p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Some silly etymology related to this era</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>So, what do you do?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What are some results of your choice? For yourself, for the crusades, for history more broadly?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>Your political situation, especially rivalries with other crusader leaders</li> <li>The military strengths and weaknesses of yourself and your enemy</li> <li>Your sense of self, identity, duty, as a crusader and as a knight</li> </ul> <div class="container"> <div class="row center question"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey (score +2).</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<replace "#travelers">> <p>There's a fun movie involving these individuals (Saladin, Imad al-Din, Gui de Lusignan, Balian of Ibelin, Sybilla and Baldwin of Jerusalem, Tiberias, Raymond of Tripoli, Raynald of Chatillon, etc.). <em>Kingdom of Heaven</em> (2005) offers historically accurate depictions of many aspects of crusade warfare. The film does take some creative liberties with the characters' biographies and the chronology of events. And of course, with an eye to profit, it tailors its narrative and thematic orientation to appeal to 21st-century consumers (e.g., romance, ideas of freedom and equality), detracting somewhat from its historical authenticity.</p> <p><img src="images/kingdom-heaven.jpg" alt="movie cover showing actors and title Kingdom of Heaven" width="50%"></p> <hr> <p>Have you seen this one?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "Yes!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>Great! It's a fun one, and not bad as far as historical accuracy goes (at least relating to crusade warfare).<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "No.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">>If you're interested in this corner of history, it's worth viewing.<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <div class="container"> <h2>Tips for Getting Started</h2> <<linkreplace "Click here to show tips and suggestions for approaching this role play assignment.">><<include tips>><</linkreplace>> </div> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Crusaders take Jerusalem |sack]]</li> <li>[[An ideal knight |warewic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Battle of Hattin in context |hattin]]</li> <li>[[Crusader warfare |crusader]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights Portal |Knights]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <h1>Imagining Witches</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Look through these images (and a few chunks of text) from early modern and renaissance-era depictions of witches.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vRgz4qPwGmrxPihvfA0w7ysMMUEsj7YbmSZFNDAPzCVgfxlTShPQEsZXq-FiiSIXcAl_tNISkqN_-uP/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="569" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: A Witch Trial |Witch]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>An English witch trial (1584)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> ] <p>Reginald Scott was a magistrate in Elizabethan England. In 1584 wrote <em>The Discoverie of Witchcraft</em> criticizing the illogical and unjust nature of witch trials. In <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/15-2frEYhQJHCf_1R9YATpk4-1ijuK4Z9f0Yd28DuCXQ/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this excerpt</a> from <em>Discoverie of Witchcraft</em>, Scott tells the story of one witch trial he encountered in the course of his duty as a magistrate.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The role of gender and power dynamics might impact a witch trial</li> <li>What motivated people to make witchcraft accusations</li> <li>How did people view witches?</li> <li>Who would be vulnerable to witchcraft accusations?</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchsca2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: A Witch Trial |Witch]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Roper, "Blood and Codpieces"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In the <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/135VoJTSMNVheuML-lA_Y0UD1vtLcN5Tz/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">"Blood and Codpieces"</a> chapter of her book, <em>Oedipus and the Devil: Witchcraft, Religion and Sexuality in Early Modern Europe</em>, Lyndal Roper analyzes ideas of masculinity in the gendered power structures of early modern civic society.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Typical behaviors and activities of men in early modern towns</li> <li>How early modern ideas of gender would shape people's sense of self and relationships with others</li> <li>Links between ideas of masculinity and witchcraft or evil</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchre1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchra1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchre2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchra2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchre3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchra3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchre4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchra4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Images of witches |witch-images]]</li> <li>[[An English witch trial |scott]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Early modern masculinity |roper]]</li> <li>[[A non-binary person |thomasine]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: A Witch Trial |Witch]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Medieval Hunting Books</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Hunting was a core component of aristocratic life and identity. It served various practical purposes (like honing horsemanship and battlefield skills) as well as serving to reinforce cultural and societal norms (like terrorizing the peasantry by riding around like maniacs on huge horses with packs of aggressive dogs). So they hunted <em>all the time</em>. They put it in their art and literature too. Couldn't get enough of it. In the later Middle Ages, some of them commissioned artists and writers to create books about it: hunting manuals known as "books of the hunt." Historians are quite pleased that they did this! Here are some excerpts from these fascinating (and often quite beautiful) books.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vRRY-TA4AouIRDlzOslgqHhq8M1-UsF-kAUAsxcmoqnXa6RlREap35eyFV9SBaw_N9HXemBWBeOPI9p/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="569" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How medieval aristocrats hunted</li> <li>The roles of huntsmen and foresters</li> <li>The purpose of hunting for aristocrats</li> <li>Sources of danger for medieval aristocrats and their huntsmen and foresters while hunting</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div of the Hunt |ms-hunts]]</li> <li>[[Hunting "accidents" |hunt-death]]</li> <li>[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight |gawain]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div |orme]]</li> <li>[[About peasants, poaching, and foresters in early medieval Europe |goldberg]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Hunting "Accidents"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Medieval chronicles are peppered with stories about hunting accidents that are obviously not accidental at all. Like, "Oh, sorry, I didn't see you there when I ran you through with that boar spear." Such power plays seem to have been commonplace when members of this power-hungry and militaristic aristocracy enjoyed blood sport in the forest. "Let's all go play with our war toys together!" is obviously a great way to open a space for settling differences of opinion or establishing a pecking order. And they didn't do it gently. The hunt was also an ideal setting for an assassination, especially if your target happened to be a member of the upper elite, like a king or a bishop, who rarely appeared outside his swarm of thuggish toadies. In a fast-paced woodland chase, anybody can become vulnerable for a moment. <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/10-xCaDHrHTLUC0UJPlRexjJtUzqbzty0Sn1fso9seO8/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">Here are a few examples</a> of various hunting "accidents" and all-out murders, from medieval chroniclers and historians.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How medieval aristocrats carried out political violence while hunting</li> <li>The roles of huntsmen and foresters in such events</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forace1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$foraca1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forace2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>From <em>Sir Gawain and the Green Knight</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>One of the finest surviving chivalric romances is <em>Sir Gawain and the Green Knight</em>, composed in England c. 1380. It contains three hunting episodes which you can find in <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1rx3CAGUKZzVeVioxhBSX1iCBKmeGHDCV/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this translation of the poem</a> at pages 33-39, 40-46, 47-53. Here's a guide to find other interesting events in the story, in case you feel like exploring the fantastical landscape of <em>Gawain</em> more extensively.</p> <ul> <li>Sir Gawain accepts the Green Knight's challenge at the feast in Camelot: Part I, Stanzas 3 - 20 (pages 5 - 16)</li> <li>Sir Gawain travels to Bercilak's castle: Part II, Stanzas 3 - 19, 23 - 24 (pages 18 - 29, 32-33)</li> <li>The deer hunt: Part III, Stanzas 1 - 9 (pages 33 - 39)</li> <li>The boar hunt: Part III, Stanzas 12 - 20 (pages 40 - 46)</li> <li>The fox hunt: Part III, Stanzas 23 - 31 (pages 47 - 53)</li> <li>Sir Gawain meets the Green Knight at the chapel: Part IV, Stanzas 9 - 20 (pages 60 - 67)</li> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Aristocratic hunting practices</li> <li>The roles of huntsmen and foresters in such events</li> <li>Sources of danger on a hunt</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Goldberg, "Peasants and Poaching"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Jl92j6Sq3weIrvTbNAlVHGomR7ej_h0_/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">In this chapter called "Peasants and Poaching"</a>, Eric Goldberg investigates the roles of peasants as hunters for their own gains, as well as their roles as huntsmen and foresters working for their feudal lords. The book's chronological focus is the early Middle Ages, and its geographical focus is France and Germany (pretty much, the Franks). It is one of my favorite books about medieval history. I hope you enjoy it too!</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How peasants used forest resources in early medieval Europe</li> <li>How the aristocracy strove to assert their authority and ownership over forest resources, and what that would have felt like for the peasants</li> <li>How we can view the forest as a locus of class conflict and resource competition, and how that struggle played out in early medieval Europe (If anyone out there hunts or fishes, I bet you'll be thinking that things haven't changed much here.)</li> <li>The role, experiences, and social and political position of huntsmen and foresters</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Peasant, church, and the nobility's attitudes toward hunting</li> <li>Peasant, church, and the nobility's typical hunting practices</li> <li>Sources of danger on a hunt</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forffe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forffa3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forffe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$forffa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Books
