|orme]]</li> <li>[[About peasants, poaching, and foresters in early medieval Europe |goldberg]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: Forester Scenario |Forester]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Scenes of Peasant Life</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Nobles may have sneered at the "lower orders" and regarded them as sub-human bovine clods, but they do seem to have been aware, on some level, that their entire economic system depended on the peasants. The nobility would have no castles or feasts without the 90% who did the actual work. This knowledge may have informed the late medieval aristocratic fad for decorating valuable manuscripts with lavish illustrations of the peasants. Noblemen wanted these illuminations to reflect their wealth and status, the prosperity of their rich estates. And they had (just?) enough sense to realize that peasants could not be left out of such narratives. Have a look at these examples of peasant scenes from psalters and books of hours in 14th to 15th-century England, France, and the Netherlands.</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/e/2PACX-1vS0tUmBRM_F8GqmZgm_a3s1lyaw3YP7xgsm7szLghma27tx0kpgs3ULoyCtlRoczB3YZCF7fBMuwP5K/embed?start=false&loop=false&delayms=3000" frameborder="0" width="960" height="569" allowfullscreen="true" mozallowfullscreen="true" webkitallowfullscreen="true"></iframe> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Typical everyday activities of peasants</li> <li>Tools and technology commonly used in peasant life</li> <li>Relationships, gender norms, community</li> <li>Peasant skills and knowledge</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovele1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovela1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovele2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovela2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovele3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovela3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovele4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lovela4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="container"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Scenes from peasant life |life]]</li> <li>[[From Chaucer's <em>Canterbury Tales</em> |miller]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Peasant life and relationships |penifader]]</li> <li>[[Medieval sexuality |sexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Misummer Bonfire Scenario |Love]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are besieged by the Assyrian army</h1> <p>Lachish, c. 800 BCE</p> </div> <p>The Assyrian army spreads like a lake of ants around the city of Lachish, smoke from its cooking fires rising up around you like the walls of a cage, wrapping you in a feeling of crushing, hopeless imprisonment. You focus on setting aside panic. The enemy is busy building siege engines and ramps and digging, raiding the countryside and practicing their maneuvers. More seem to arrive <<linkappend "every day.">><<include "Lachish-link1">><</linkappend>></p> <p>The city of Lachish is strong. But it’s also divided. Backed by the money and military of King Hezekiah at Jerusalem, the local elite have adopted the cult of Yaweh, pushing everyone to conform. Now the seething mass of death and destruction outside the walls has ignited the explosive resentments that divide the city’s population. Nomadic folk who fled into the city from the countryside have never had much good to say about city people - and vice versa. Slaves aren’t sure who’s scarier now - their masters or the Assyrians. Canaanites and Philistines, Egyptians and Hebrews have never trusted each other much (at all).</p> <p>Your family has lived in the area since the Great Flood. You come to the market here every week to trade wool and cheese and wild herbs and honey. You don’t hate the city like some of the other outsiders do, but your home is out there in the hills and your gods are not the great, unknowable Yaweh with his laws and scrolls and <<linkappend "priests and temple.">><</linkappend>></p> <p>One night, after drifting to sleep with your baby nestled under one arm, and your oldest son on the other side, you’re awakened by whispering voices. Your husband is sitting with a group of friends. One of them has just come back after spending a few days in the Assyrian camp. The city walls are strong, but most folk know how to find a way out when they want to. He’s heard what happens to cities who resist the empire. Wouldn’t it be better to surrender now, he says? It’s not our city, anyway. Silence, and then soft muttering. You can see some of their heads nodding in the dim moonlight. Your grip on the baby tightens, and it squirms, nuzzling for your breast. Your mind is racing.</p> <p>What do you say to your girlfriends the next morning? What do you say to your husband? What will you do?</p> <p>What happens to you and your family? What happens to Lachish and the Kingdom of Judah? Does the new cult of Yaweh flourish?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |lachis-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |lachish-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |lachish-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |lachish-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |lachish-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>In the Assyrian army</h1> <p>Mesopotamia, c. 800 BCE</p> </div> <p>You saw the smoke a day before arriving at the city. Now you see that it doesn’t rise from the city itself, but from the imperial camp coiled around its walls. The road to the camp is broad and well-traveled, busy with camels and horses. A ribbon of thick, riparian growth shows where a small river passes through the camp to skirt the city walls. You remember crossing the Euphrates a few weeks ago, the terror and awe, and then the feeling of relief and even pride. You’d never seen <<linkappend "anything like it.">><<include "Assyrian-link1">><</linkappend>> <p>You’d never seen anything more than your poor, small village with its low, mud huts and its herds of skinny goats until the army came a few months ago.</p> <p>They came to your village looking for taxes and conscripts for the imperial army. Some of the boys had fought and screamed. Some of their families had fought or tried to hide, and the rich ones had given everything they had to keep their sons home. And now here you are - not that you know where “here” is.</p> <p>You’re smart enough to realize that your life has almost no value to your commanders. You don’t necessarily want to go home (after all, it wasn’t much, and the sargeants here make a big show of executing deserters in memorably messy ways). Strangely, you value yourself. You have decided that you are more than meat to be fed into the imperial war machine. You want to survive. Maybe even move up in the world. <<linkappend "Power. Wealth. A future.">> <<include "Assyrian-link2">><</linkappend>> <p>There’s opportunity, as well as horroa and death, all around you here. What do you do?<p> <p>How will you achieve personal success here at this siege, and boost your status within the military?</p> <p>In ten years, what will your life be like? If you're still alive? Will you ever go home? Why?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |assyria-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |assyria-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |assyria-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |assyria-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |assyria-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Rewrite |ironage-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are a young Helot woman</h1> <p>Sparta, 465 BCE</p> </div> <p>You are a young Helot woman. It’s 465 BCE, and another Helot rebellion is raging <<linkappend "across the Peloponnesus.">><<include "Helot-link1">><</linkappend>></p> <p>Your people do this every couple of generations. It never works, but what the hell. What have you got to lose, really? As usual, Sparta’s allies have come trudging in to help the noble Spartans beat their slaves back into the ground. Again.</p> <p>But this time will be different. This time, the Helots have friends too. The moon looks monstrous as it floats up higher on the horizon - an angry red eye, leering through twisting columns and heavy layers of smoke. The Helots are burning the crops they’ve been growing for their masters. Occasionally the sound of screaming threads through the smoky air. You’re lying in the tall grass, your head resting in the curve of your lover’s arm. You feel so alive. Like you have never been alive before. Like his body is a portal to another world, and you have fallen through it. The world you left wasn’t real. This is the real world. You resist sleep, your eyes tracking the rise of the bloody orb of the moon. When the it reaches its zenith, you will meet with the Athenian rowers in the olive grove at the foot of this hill. Yesterday, Sparta sent Athens home when they came to help their “friends” crush the rebellion: “Thanks for coming, but <<linkappend "we don't want you here.">><<include "Helot-link2">><</linkappend>> So the Athenians sailed off over the horizon … and then looped back around to anchor here in the cove and send runners to find the Helot leaders. Your heart leaps as you think about what might happen now.</p> <p>You let yourself fantasize about a home without Spartans. A new polis will rise here. Your polis. What will its constitution be like? Which gods will it honor? What kinds of people will be free, and how free? Do you think about improving the situation of women? How will you repel Spartan attempts to regain control? (You know they’ll flee into the open arms of Persia, where they already have plenty of friends.)</p> <p>The Athenians don’t want women at the meeting. They say they gossip too much and will get everyone killed and should be at home. ("We don't <em>have</em> homes!" you want to scream at them.) What do you do? Do you leave quietly because you need revolution? Or do you stand your ground because you need this revolution?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |helot-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |helot-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |helot-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |helot-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |helot-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are Pericles</h1> <p>Athens, 465 BCE</p> </div> <p>You are Pericles, and you didn’t die of plague in 429 BCE. It is now 414, and as <em>strategos,</em> you have kept Athens mostly on top of this conflict with Sparta and her Peloponnesian League. Just barely. But now Persia has built Sparta a navy. Shit. Soooooo predictable. What are we going to do about those knuckle-dragging fascists?</p> <p>So, that’s a problem. But the worst threat is inside the gates. The young men of Athens are going mad, pent up behind the Long Walls, dying of plague and longing for a real fight. They follow Alcibiades like sheep. Glamorous, rich, impossibly beautiful Alcibiades. <<linkappend "Depraved, lecherous, rebellious Alcibiades.">><<include "Pericles-link1">><</linkappend>> He was your student, your protege, once upon a time. But you serve the people, Alcibiades serves himself alone. Along with Socrates and a gaggle of dirty comic playwrights, he is uprooting everything you're fighting for, everything Athens stands for. They mock the gods and the city itself, tearing at the solidarity you've been nurturing during these long, bitter years of war with Sparta, screaching for war while you work for peace.</p> <p>Alcibiades mesmerizes the peope, with his proud aristocratic disdain for democracy, his lavish, fashionable, party life, his rash calls for escalation against Sparta. His latest idea is <<linkappend "an attack on Sicily.">><<include "Pericles-link2">><</linkappend>> It's beyond idiotic. Utter madness - especially now that Sparta has its Persian-funded navy. But this is a democracy, and Alcibiades says whatever makes the crowd roar. They love him. Frankly, you’re not sure who is in charge any more - him or his worshipers.</p> <p>Tonight the city will gather to hear your annual funeral oration. You want to make this one count. You <em>need</em> to make it count, like that one at the beginning of the war that people still quote at symposia and the theater. What can you say this time to steer your city toward survival, and break the spell of Alcibiades?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |pericles-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |pericles-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |pericles-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |pericles-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |pericles-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Ancient Greece Rewrite |greece-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are a philosopher</h1> <p>Rome, 215 BCE</p> </div> <p><em>Note: This role play scenario is set in an alternative version of history. In reality, Hannibal's stunning victory at Cannae (216 BCE) was bootless because he failed to follow up, which enabled the Romans to regroup, rally their supporters, and oust Hannibal by forcing him to return home to defend Carthage. I have re-imagined this bit of history. Instead of post-Cannae paralysis, Hannibal lunges for Rome itself (kind of like Pyrrhus did, in the century before). This is the setting for this role play scenario.</em></p> <p>You are a Carthaginian engineer in the army of Hannibal. He has teamed up with Celts in the north and the Numidians in the south. Your army has defeated legion after legion in northern Italy and dirven the Romans back to the city itself. The walls are 30 feet tall and 13 feet thick. You have a leading role in planning and carrying out the siege.</p> <p>You're just an engineer, but as you plan the minutiae of your siege machinery and tactics, you're know you need to think about the bigger picture of this war too. For instance, there are the Italians. For days, <<linkappend "busily working">><<include cannae-link1>><</linkappend>> amid the excitement and energy of a victorious camp, you've been oppressed by a strong sense that you've forgotten something. Like you forgot to get dressed and you're walking around naked. Or forgot to put away your scrolls and they're blowing away in the wind. And suddenly, while calculating the length of a ballista's main shaft, you looked up and swore out loud. It's the Italians. That's what has been nagging at your mind.</p> <p>So, Hannibal has brilliantly smashed every legion he's met across the peninsula, but the Italians themselves are still out there. Your army killed 50,000 Romans at Cannae last year. But does that mean you've conquered the land? Are the Italians really subdued? <<linkappend "Will they support their ally, Rome? Or will they embrace Hannibal as a liberator?">><<include cannae-link2>><</linkappend>> You force your mind back to the ballista design problem. You spend the rest of the day crafting your engines of death, but your mind keeps returning to this problem of Rome's allies... </p> <p>What kinds of machines will you built to besiege Rome? Why? How will you use them? How do you imagine the Romans will defend their city?</p> <p>What do you expect will happen during or after the siege? What will the Italians do? The surviving Romans? What about the successor kingdoms in Greece, Egypt, and the Levant? What about mighty Carthage? Your southern friends in Numidia? The unruly Celts in the North?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |cannae-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |cannae-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |cannae-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |cannae-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |cannae-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are a philosopher</h1> <p>Alexandria, c. 200 BCE</p> </div> <p>You recline on your couch in second-century BCE Alexandria, in a cloud of sweet music and savory aromas. This <<linkappend "symposium-style dinner party">><<include "alex-link1">><</linkappend>> has become a kind of weekly ritual for your group of philosophical comrades. You’ve spent the week, as usual, drifting contentedly around the schools and library, lost in contemplation and study, composing a new philosophical treatise and antcipating the counter-arguments of your scholarly rivals.</p> <p>All your life, you’ve been fascinated by knowledge and ideas. Alexandria is a paradise. You’ve dabbled in physics, medicine, mathematics, poetics, ontology and metaphysics. Lately, you’ve been thinking more about politics. You’ve even begun writing a short treatise on the purpose of life.</p> <p>This evening, while <<linkappend "enjoying the conversation, the food, and the entertainment,">><<include alex-link2>><</linkappend>> you voice some of your new ideas about human virtue, and what it means to live a good life. Your best friend and longtime romantic partner heckles you mercilessly, meeting all your theories with the declaration that since our minds do not exist after death, this whole question is a waste of time - and therefore not virtuous. You accuse them of being reductionist and intellectually lazy. They accuse you of being unrealistic and sophistical, wasting your time on an academic farce with no purpose beyond stroking your own ego and averting boredom.</p> <p>This argument can, and actually does, go on and on between the two of you eternally. They are a devoted adherent to Epicureanism. While you're not exactly <em>against</em> the teachings of Epicurius, you think the philosophy incomplete and naive. You yourself find Zeno's Stoicism more elegant and fulfilling. So, there's really no way you will ever settle this debate on the purpose or value of human life. Still, it's not a bad way to spend the evening. Again.</p> <p>What are some features of your ideal political system?How do you respond to your partner's criticism that there really is no good system of government because power corrupts?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |alex-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |alex-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |alex-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |alex-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |alex-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Hellenistic World Rewrite |hellenistic-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are a wealthy Roman</h1> <p>Italy, 78 CE</p> </div> <p>The sounds of building ricochet through the air: sawing, hammering, chiseling, digging. In the background, the slow chant of slaves carrying blocks of stone. You edge away from the burning sun, into the shade of the newly-constructed, empty house. Seeing the new <em>domus</em> so complete, with walls and roof and windows, fills you with a delicious sense of contenment. You reach out and touch the nearest wall, then frown as you notice that some of the wet paint has stuck to your fingertips, smudging the foliar border framing a bright red frescoe of <<linkappend "a handsome woman playing a kithara.">><<include pompeii-link1>><</linkappend>> This will be the <em>triclinium</em>. The floor is bare and empty, waiting for a tile mosaic. Maybe a lively Nile River or dockyard scene there? And what about the other walls? You need to decide how to decorate the other walls and floors.</p> <p>You think of the frescoes and mosaics in your neighbor's house: <<linkappend "everything from stories of the gods to exotic African animals to flowers and fruit.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2">><</linkappend>> They're an old patrician family, though, and your parents were slaves. Well-educated, literate, and highly capable, your father was freed by his owner, an old senator. As a free man, your father prospered wthin the political and financial network of his former owner. You and your children remain fiercely loyal to the old senator's heirs, and you grow richer all the time. Still, your parents were nobody and you'll never have the power or prestige of your patrician neighbors - and they'll never let you forget it. But still, there's no reason a pleb as rich as you should live in a hovel. You sigh, moving slowly back outside and savouring again that feeling of contentment. The <em>domus</em> is all but done. What to paint on these walls?</p> <p>You look out toward Pompeii. Your home clings to the lovely slopes of Mount Vesuvius, just above the bustling town. It's 78 CE. Vespasian sits the imperial throne, carrying on the legacy of the Flavian dynasty. Life could hardly be better - if, of course, a person could live in a decent house... You glance around at the bare What would this world be without the majesty of the empire? There would be no wine, clean water, law and order, schools and plays and libraries and baths, and the <<linkappend "grand colosseum Vespasian has begun building in Rome.">><<include "Pompeii-link3">><</linkappend>></p> <p>That's it! Your walls will celebrate the beauty and splendor of Rome! Its heritage and power and everything it stands for. Everything <em>you</em> stand for. The patricians can look down their noses at you, but you are a true Roman. That's what will go on these new, blank walls.</p> <p>What are some of the scenes you tell the artist to depict on your walls? What will they celebrate or reflect?</p> <p>Do you think your remodel will impact your life in any real way? Your social status or economic status or the opportunities you encounter?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |pompeii-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |pompeii-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |pompeii-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |pompeii-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |pompeii-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are Spartacus' romantic partner</h1> <p>Italy, 73 BCE</p> </div> <p>It's nearly midsummer and the night is warm, even high on the peak of Mount Vesuvius. Spartacus and his captains sit around the dying fire. They've been here for hours, roasting quail, talking, arguing. A decision must be made. Spartacus wants to lead the slave army north and across the Alps, out of Rome. After all, the legions are busy with Mithridates in the East and Sertorius in the West. The mountain passes are all but deserted. But the others are delirious with victory and plunder. Camped here on Vesuvius, surrounded by <<linkappend "the richest farmland in Italy,">><<include "spartacus-link1">><</linkappend>> your slave army grows bigger and richer every day. The original farmers of Campania were the citizen soldiers who built Rome generations ago. But most are long gone, crowded out by rich patricians who live in the city. Now it's just slaves and plunder in every direction.</p> <p>You hear Crixus say (again) that the longer we stay, the stronger we get. He’s not wrong, but you know Spartacus wants to leave. You watch his face in the firelight, and see the memories marching behind his eyes. Back home in Thrace, he fought for the legions. <<linkappend "Romans know the worth of Thracian cavalry, of great horsemen like Spartacus.">>><</linkappend>> And Spartacus knows the worth of the legions. The fugitive gladiators and laborers camped down below fight like demons, and last week, they got lucky and caught a small Roman force by surprise and scored an easy victory. Now they think they're invincible. But a real legion would roll right over them like a wave up a sandy beach - effortless and inexorable - before marching back to Rome, nailing slaves to crosses along the Appian Way as an example to the rest. Crixus falls silent at last, and Spartacus' eyes focus again as others chorus agreement: Stay and fight on! Every slave in Italy will be with us by fall! And it's almost harvest time... </p> <p>From the edge of the firelight, you silently watch their faces as they argue back and forth. They attack and deflect and position and strategize, just like they used to do <<linkappend "in the arena for the entertainment of the crowd.">><<include "spartacus-link3">><</linkappend>> They’re using words this time, not blades, but the outcome of this skirmish is life and death nonetheless. Isn’t it always, for slaves of Rome? There’s a moment of silence, and a wolf howls nearby. They all freeze and you feel, rather than see, their gazes slide toward you. Another howl. It’s a sign. Vesuvius is sacred, a place of power. The wolf is sacred to Rome. You are a Thracian priestess, <<linkappend "a Bacchanate who serves Dionysus.">><<include "Spartacus-link4">><</linkappend>> These men are lethal killers, but they fear your power. You rise in one smooth, swift movement, and spin, circling the fire, moving rhythmically. Your long robe swirls, your hair flies out. The vines tattooed along your arms seem to slither in the leaping firelight. The snake coiled around your arm bobs its head in the air. No one speaks as you spin and chant, moving slowly around the circle. The circuit complete, you sink down again in your place just within the circle of light now, closer behind Spartacus than you were before. The mood lightens. They won't decide anything now. Tomorrow. And later tonight, when you and Spartacus are alone, you will tell him what to do.</p> <p>The stakes could hardly be higher. Death (a good one if you're unreasonably lucky) on one hand, and freedom on the other. What does Spartacus decide to do? Why?</p> <p>How does it go? Do you win your freedom? How and where? Do you build a new society? Or does Rome win, as usual?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |spartacus-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |spartacus-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |spartacus-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |spartacus-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |spartacus-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Rewrite |rome1-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are a barbarian</h1> <p>Danube frontier, c. 420</p> </div> <p>Scenario and prompts</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |barb-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |barb-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |barb-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |barb-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |barb-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall? rewrite |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are Cwichelm, King of Wessex</h1> <p>Anglo-Saxon England, 640</p> </div> <p>The great fire roars and crackles, washing the hall with heat and golden light. Torches dance in the shadowy corners and alcoves. The laughter and loud voices rise up to the tall, timbered roof. You breathe deeply, smelling the meat and bread and woodsmoke, <<linkappend "savoring these hall joys - the fruits and the seeds of victory.">><<include asking-link1>><</linkappend>> From your high seat above the mead benches, you watch in silence. The young men posturing and boasting, testing their prestige and the mettle of their comrades, nettling and heckling, hoping for a fight. The older men sit calmly on the benches, like great stones in the river, worn smooth by the storm of swords and spears.</p> <p>All is as it should be. You watch your daughter and your wife move gracefully down the hall, <<linkappend "filling mead horns,">><<include asking-link3>><</linkappend>> exchanging quiet words with the warriors. You note with approval the way they navigate the hierarchies and subtle currents of enmity or friendship that unite the war band. Your daughter gives a fine twist of gold, a pendant, to your oldest friend and stands in conversation with him for a long time. Next in her path is her uncle’s son, Osric, an insolent youth whose mother’s family has been pushing him into competition with your own sons. Fortunately, he’s as strong as a newborn lamb. He won’t last long, but she’s right to make him wait, to let the hall see her making him wait. She talks with your old friend for a very long time and refills his horn twice, smiling sweetly, laughing softly, beautiful and gold-adorned. You see Osric struggling for calm, trying not to hear her or look at her … and failing miserably. The boy’s incapable of anything. That’s good.</p> <p>Your eldest son, Cenwalh, sees what’s happening. He raises his voice and calls down the table to the Osric: “Hey, Osric! I know you didn’t really kill that Scottish goat thief! Or his friends. I saw them yesterday…” Your daughter quietly moves toward Osric and tries to fill his mead horn, but has to apologize because her cup has run dry. You can’t completely suppress a grin behind your beard. She leaves to fetch more as the two youths begin to argue. When Osric tries to stand up, you nod to the old man at your feet. He’s ready. He plucks the strings of his harp and a surprisingly deep, penetrating voice issues from his bony frame. He speaks: <<linkappend '“Listen! We have heard of the Spear-Danes, long ago, of the royal princes’ deeds of glory…”'>><<include asking-link4>><</linkappend>> The hall falls silent. Totally silent. Their eyes shine in the firelight as they forget, for a time, their own petty quarrels, lost in the tales of old.</p> <p>Now you can relax and think. Your wife, a Mercian princess, is Christian. You are not. She has a priest who holds mass for her and the Christians in her retinue, and a few in your own. Over the years, the pope, has sent you gifts, rich treasures, trappings of power bearing the signs of Roman imperium. Your daughter has converted, following her mother's example. Should you join them? Other kings have, in Kent and Northumbria. Massive stone churches have risen in their kingdoms. Preists record their laws and gifts in books that will last forever. Forever? <<linkappend "Nothing is forever. Fate goes as it will.">><<include asking-link2>><</linkappend>> This hall is strong. Your sons are strong. The warband is as united as any warband can be. What can the Roman Christ do for your kingdom, or for you?</p> <p>Do you convert to Christianity? Do you encourage or support the Church? Or not? How do people in your kingdom and warband respond? How does it impact your family's position or the security of your kingdom?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |asking-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |asking-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |asking-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |asking-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |asking-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome fall? rewrite |rome2-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are at a coastal Northumbrian village</h1> <p>Anglo-Saxon England, c .800</p> </div> <p>Icy wind sweeps across the ocean, lifting white caps from the surface of the sea and cutting through your wool sleeves to sting your skin, goading you into a trot as you near the shelter of home.</p> <p>Inside the house, it's smoky and warm. As your eyes adjust to the dim light, you see the others are here already. The big benches lining the table in the center of your long hall are full. You toss your cloak <<linkappend "to a slave">><<include defence-link1>><</linkappend>> and say, “The new dog had trouble moving the ewes and the new thralls are fools. Is everyone here?” Nobody speaks. Since last week’s Danish raid on the neighboring village, you’ve all been on edge, constantly scanning the horizon, jumping at the sound of a cry. You glance at the heap of blankets in the corner, where a couple of children sit close together, watching you with huge eyes. They were among the few to escape the raid and reach the safety of your village. Their parents were not so fortunate. You called this meeting to make a plan for when the Northmen come. Because they will. Your village is large, <<linkappend "stretching from the docks in the bay to the monastery on the hill.">><<include defence-link2>><</linkappend>> You sit down on the bench in your usual place next to your two oldest sons, and accept a horn of mead from your wife. You nod at your father, old but still strong, at the head of the table. Let him get things started.</p> <p>Describe the plans you come up with. How will you defend yourselves from the raid you know is coming? How does this situation impact your community’s socioeconomic dynamics? What individuals or groups are empowered? Who loses status and who gains?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |defence-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |defence-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |defence-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |defence-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |defence-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Age Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are King Harold Godwinson</h1> <p>England, 1066</p> </div> <p>It is September 30, 1066. You stand very still, at the very end of the labyrinth of tunnels under <<linkappend "York Minster.">><<include hastings-link1>><</linkappend>></p> <p>In the small, dark room, treasure is heaped up like a dragon, higher than your head. It glints in the torchlight, coils of torques and hack silver and coin, ring mail and swords and helmets seeming to heave and move. It took twelve men to carry the gold bar underneath it all. Harald had brought it with him his days leading the <<linkappend "Verangian guard in Byzantium.">><<include hastings-link2>><</linkappend>> You can’t take your eyes off it. And it’s not greed. You have money. At any gathering, you’re always the richest one (kings not excepted). It was a long, long time ago when you stopped caring if people called you greedy or ambitious or selfish. You genuinely have no idea what it feels like to give a shit. Money is so fucking boring. But this isn’t money. This is power. This gold is <em>alive</em>, as if <<linkappend "the treasure had become the man himself,">><<include hastings-link3>><</linkappend>> as if the ghost of Harald Hardrada himself had risen from the mead benches of Valhalla to stand before you and stare you in the face - and you can’t look away.</p> <p>You clench your eyes shut and it hurts. You need to get some sleep. You let a long, slow expletive roll through your mind. Should you ask Harald what to do? Ha ha! What the hell. You open your eyes and they still can't look away from the glowing, pulsing hoard. You speak to it: “Harald, I just wrecked you. Hard. And that Irish king too. And my worthless fucking brother, may he rot in Hell forever. Wish I could do it again right now. So, why aren’t you dead? You’re still here. The skalds were singing about you in the camp just now. I heard them You're alive. Your gold should be alive like you. It should be up there in camp too, lighting up the night like your name, making men laugh and fight … and forget. But it is here in the dark with the dead. And here it stays, at least for now, because the Bastard has landed. They just told me.</p> <p>We have to march south. Now. Yesterday. Again! We just did this, like <em>just now</em> raced here 300 miles from London to wreck your shit. The Bastard will have dug in by now: motte and bailey, burning and raiding, scouting, planning, <em>always</em> with the fucking planning - endless contingencies in twisted perfection like the inlay on my sword hilt. He’s good. You know, <<linkappend "I was with him in Brittany a few years ago.">><<include hastings-link4>><</linkappend>> Raiding and hunting. My dogs are better, but he was good. Household knights, feudal levies, mercenaries, cavalry and archers, perfect timing, total control. He’s here now, and after my crown. What will I do, old man? Tell me, what will I do?”</p> <p>As you lead the forced march south, setting a crushing pace, making 40 miles a day with a brief stop in London to pull in fresh troops, what plans do you form for dealing with William at the coast? What orders do you issue as you travel? Is there a role for diplomacy as well as force? Can that treasure glowing in the bowels of York Minster do anything for you?</p> <p>How does the battle go (if there is one)? What are the results for England and France? For your favorite person, Harold Godwinson? What would the ghost of old Harald Hardrada have to say?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |hastings-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |hastings-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |hastings-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |hastings-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |hastings-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Viking Age Rewrite |viking-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are Eleanor of Aquitaine</h1> <p>France, c. 1170</p> </div> <p><em>Note: In reimagining the historical figures in this role play scenario, I have altered the dates a bit. They all lived in the twelfth century, and were active in France and Germany during twelfth century renaissance. However, the their careers did not really intertwine as much as this (fictional!) role play scenario suggests. Just FYI. Here are the real dates (dates are important in a History class, right?):</em></p> <ul> <li>Eleanor of Aquitaine: 1122 - 1204</li> <li>Hildegard von Bingen: 1098 - 1179</li> <li>Bernard of Clairvaux: 1090 - 1153</li> <li>Heloise: 1092 - 1163</li> </ul> <p>And now, back to the role play scenario.</p> <p>Sweet music swells around you, rolling off the massive, vaulted ceiling and lifting you toward heaven. You close your eyes and let the tears flow as your soul mingles with God and his saints and eternity. When you're aware of reality again, the voices are gone, replaced by the soft scuffle of many feet on stone as the nuns move on to the next task in their busy day. You open your eyes to a hundred colors of light streaming through the stained glass. For the thousandth time, you thank God for leading you here. And for sending Hildegard to earth: You must write to her again and thank her for sending <<linkappend "her newest composition.">><<include el-link1>><</linkappend>></p> <p>Your mouth curls into a wry smirk as you compare Hildegard's magic with the thin, discordant cacophony of King Louis’ court musicians. His royal halls were cramped and cold, stinking and crowded with ignorant fools - the knights with nothing to say but horses and dogs and killing. You and your ladies lost yourselves in song and story, in the world of King Arthur long ago, of Merlin and fairies and magic. A deluge of gold flowed from your hands into the purses of the minstrels and clerics who wrote and sang the songs. When you left the royal court at Paris and returned home to Poitiers, the best troubadours came too, following the flow of gold. For many, it was a homecoming. Since the days of your grandfather, Duke William X, Aquitaine has been a haven for troubadours and jongleurs and every wayward cleric bored with university life.</p> <p>You once heard a bastard son of your lover, Henry Plantagenet, decline a pre-packaged, high-status career in the church: “I prefer horses and dogs to books and priests.” The meat-headed fool. When they finally annulled your marriage to Louis, you broke free from men like Henry and his bastard. They tried to steal you back as you fled from Paris and marriage and queenship, homeward toward Poitiers. You rode dressed as a man but they still found you out ... it was close.</p> <p>From the safety of your mighty castle of Poitiers, surrounded by walls 15 feet thick and your own garrison, you wrote to Pope Eugenius: “I prefer books and priests to horses and dogs.” He let you establish a new monastic order. After all, you are the richest woman in Europe, with more land, castles, and knights than the king of France (your ex husband), and his arch-rival Duke Henry Plantagenet (one of your ex lovers) combined. You brought this vast inheritance to the Church as your dowry. The pope fell all over himself setting his seal to your new order’s charter, and he’s let you do as you please ever since.</p> <p>You move slowly through the cavernous space toward the scriptorium, deep in thought. You need to write a letter. Pope Eugene has asked Bernard of Clairvaux to call for a Third Crusade. You remember his sermon a decade ago when, at the pope's behest, Bernard preached at Vézelay, calling for the Second Crusade. The crowd went mad, roaring "Deus vult!" and even the soft eyes of <<linkappend "your husband, King Louis,">><<include el-link2>><</linkappend>> blazed with maniacal fervor as he committed himself to the holy war. Bernard's success had come at a cost though, when the crusade's failure blackened his reputation. And now the pope wants him to do it again, and Bernard has written to you to ask your advice. You know he's probably written to Hildegard too, and you wonder what she will say. </p> <p>You exit the shadowy cloister arch and cross a sunny courtyard dappled with sunlight and shadow, alive with birdsong. You need to find Heloise before sitting down to write. She's here somewhere. <<linkappend "Heloise's learning far exceeds your own.">><<include el-link3>><</linkappend>> She’s famous for the depth of her knowledge, her rhetorical genius and mastery of dialectical logic. Her correspondence Abelard keeps her in practice. Heloise will be able to help you build your argument in the erudite, scholastic style Bernard will respect. Now, if you could only find her... </p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |eleanor-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |eleanor-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |eleanor-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |eleanor-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |eleanor-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are king of Jerusalem</h1> <p>The Holy Land, c. 1170</p> </div> <p>You are Gui de Lusignan about to get slaughtered by Saladin and lose the crusader states. This is not an unavoidable outcome. ... scenario and prompts not yet written ... </p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |hattin-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |hattin-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |hattin-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |hattin-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |hattin-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are a forester in the Black Forest</h1> <p>Swabia, Holy Roman Empire c. 1100</p> </div> <p>You wade through shadows, deep in the oldest part of the forest. At times, dapples of golden sunlight slide over you. Your are silent and slow, pausing often to listen. The cadence of your movements is that of a deer: step, pause, a few more steps, pause. It’s a pattern of sound that raises no alarm in an animal who hears it. With the wind in your face, you could stalk nearly within arms length of a great antlered stag this way. But you’re not hunting now. You are going to check a wolf trap. You take in the sound and feel and light of the forest only with the surface of your mind. Most of your thoughts wrestle and with a problem, like a mastiff worrying a meaty bone, turning it this way and that, chewing, biting, mauling it over and over. You’re digesting a plan, exploring contingencies, considering possibilities and fallbacks and timing and catastrophes.</p> <p>You have decided to kill <<linkappend "the margrave.">><<include for-link1>><</linkappend>> It shouldn't be a problem, really, and you’re not especially concerned about it. But a lifetime in the forest has taught you the necessity of planning ahead and being prepared. And the wisdom of waiting. Like all wild things, you wait well. Your father saw to that, raising you as a forester from your earliest days, just as his father had taught him, and his father before him, in a line back into the mists of legend. You know every tree and ravine and rookery, every wolf pack and the lair of every bear in these mountains. The forest may belong to the margrave today, but it will always belong to you and yours.</p> <p>Sunlight streams into a glade ahead. In the middle distance, your eyes pick out a straight, horizontal line, glaringly at odds with the soft blending and twining of every other shape. <em>Good</em>. It’s a thin flax cord you strung tight between two linden trees last week, and you're pleased to see it <<linkappend "still in place.">><<include for-link2>><</linkappend>> You duck under it carefully and look for the second, heavier rope that crosses the narrow game path up ahead. It’s not there, and you see a splash of blood, sticky and dark on the ferns. You stoop to feel it. You brush your fingers over the deep divots clawed into the earth of the trail. Wolf. You grin for a heartbeat before the fear washes over you. As usual. You stand up and pull an arrow from your quiver, fit its nock onto the string, and give a low, clear whistle. Your wolfhound appears at your side, almost silently. He follows close behind as you step forward, following the drops and splashes of blood. The pattern tells you the wolf is probably dead. Still, every nerve is strung tight, every sound makes you tense, but you relax when you see a still patch of dark grey under a tangle of roots. Your dog gives a low growl. But the wolf is dead.</p> <p>It's a big wolf, as high as your waist. Cold, but not yet stiff. You set to work, deftly stripping the pelt and folding it into a bundle. Fleas and ticks have moved from the skin - no longer warm with blood - to the surface of the fur. You ignore them. You need the pelt to show the margrave … <em>the margrave for now, anyway</em>. And the village expects to see the pelt too. You are keeper of the forest. You keep the forest safe from poachers, and you keep the village safe from the forest. You are the <em>luparius</em>, <<linkappend "the wolf hunter.">><<include for-link3>><</linkappend>> They say it was the great emperor Charlemagne who appointed your great, great, great grandfather as the first <em>luparii</em> and keeper of his royal forest here. Since then, your family has kept the forest and hunted the wolves and brought their pelts to the emperor or his margrave.</p> <p>But the priest and his friends at the monastery tell you that this margrave has chosen an anti-king to depose your emperor. The priest and monks don’t like the margrave or the anti-king (or the pope, you gather). They told you the margrave is a traitor who wants to make war on the emperor. But you’ve heard others at market day saying that the emperor is excommunicated, and we owe him no allegiance. That his bishops and monks are powerless to perform the sacraments. You think of your wife. She will have another child soon. What if she dies? Or the child dies? Will they be trapped forever in the cold nothing of purgatory because the priest can't bury them in the churchyard and say the blessing? It doesn't make sense. The priest and the monks say they can still give communion to the living and bless the dead. Those folk at the market say they can't. You don't understand it. But you do understand that the margrave is a traitor to the emperor. Maybe killing him will help.</p> <p>Making your slow return home, your dog at your heels and the fresh wolf pelt tied in a bundle on your back, your mind returns to its planning. The margrave will hunt here soon. You will attend the hunt, telling the huntsmen where to find what they want - fox, bear, boar, wolves, deer. How will you make sure the margrave doesn’t survive the day’s sport? And make sure you are never suspected?</p> <p>What is your plan for killing this guy? What are the results of your choices? For you, for your community, or for the broader sweep of history?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |forester-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |forester-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |forester-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |forester-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |forester-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are a mercenary</h1> <p>A rural village, c. 1600</p> </div> <p>Scenario and prompts not yet written ... </p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |witch-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |witch-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |witch-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |witch-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |witch-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are an artist</h1> <p>Florence, Italy, c. 1620</p> </div> <p>Scenario and prompts not yet written ... </p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |art-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |art-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |art-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |art-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |art-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><header> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> </ul> </header> <p><em>Reminder: Opening links on this page is optional. They can boost your game score a bit, but feel free to skip them.</em></p> <div class="container"> <div class="title-box"> <h1>$PlayerName, you are a forester in the Black Forest</h1> <p>Swabia, in the Holy Roman Empire, c. 1100</p> </div> <div class="container center"> <div class="row center"> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_annie-spratt_unsplash.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "for-explore1">><</link>> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <h2>Explore?</h2> <p>Open the doors to explore, or skip them and continue on with the role play scenario.</p> </div> <div class="col-md center"> <<link '<img src="images/door_lunar-sea-art_pixaby.jpg" alt="doorway" width="80%">' "for-explore2">><</link>> </div> </div> </div> <div class="scenario"> <p>You wade through shadows, deep in the oldest part of the forest. At times, dapples of golden sunlight slide over you. Your are silent and slow, pausing often to listen. The cadence of your movements is that of a deer: step, pause, a few more steps, pause. It’s a pattern of sound that raises no alarm in an animal who hears it. With the wind in your face, you could stalk nearly within arms length of a great antlered stag this way. But you’re not hunting now. You are going to check a wolf trap. You take in the sound and feel and light of the forest only with the surface of your mind. Most of your thoughts wrestle and with a problem, like a mastiff worrying a meaty bone, turning it this way and that, chewing, biting, mauling it over and over. You’re digesting a plan, exploring contingencies, considering possibilities and fallbacks and timing and catastrophes.</p> <p>You have decided to kill <<linkappend "the margrave.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include for-link1>><</linkappend>> It shouldn't be a problem, really, and you’re not especially concerned about it. But a lifetime in the forest has taught you the necessity of planning ahead and being prepared. And the wisdom of waiting. Like all wild things, you wait well. Your father saw to that, raising you as a forester from your earliest days, just as his father had taught him, and his father before him, in a line back into the mists of legend. You know every tree and ravine and rookery, every wolf pack and the lair of every bear in these mountains. The forest may belong to the margrave today, but it will always belong to you and yours.</p> <p>Sunlight streams into a glade ahead. In the middle distance, your eyes pick out a straight, horizontal line, glaringly at odds with the soft blending and twining of every other shape. <em>Good</em>. It’s a thin flax cord you strung tight between two linden trees last week, and you're pleased to see it <<linkappend "still in place.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include for-link2>><</linkappend>> You duck under it carefully and look for the second, heavier rope that crosses the narrow game path up ahead. It’s not there, and you see a splash of blood, sticky and dark on the ferns. You stoop to feel it. You brush your fingers over the deep divots clawed into the earth of the trail. Wolf. You grin for a heartbeat before the fear washes over you. As usual. You stand up and pull an arrow from your quiver, fit its nock onto the string, and give a low, clear whistle. Your wolfhound appears at your side, almost silently. He follows close behind as you step forward, following the drops and splashes of blood. The pattern tells you the wolf is probably dead. Still, every nerve is strung tight, every sound makes you tense, but you relax when you see a still patch of dark grey under a tangle of roots. Your dog gives a low growl. But the wolf is dead.</p> <p>It's a big wolf, taller than your belt. Cold, but not yet stiff. You set to work, deftly stripping the pelt and folding it into a bundle. Fleas and ticks have moved from the skin - no longer warm with blood - to the surface of the fur. You ignore them. You need the pelt to show the margrave … <em>the margrave for now, anyway</em>. And the village expects to see the pelt too. You are keeper of the forest. You keep the forest safe from poachers, and you keep the village safe from the forest. You are the <em>luparius</em>, <<linkappend "the wolf hunter.">><<set $Score to $Score + 2>><<include for-link3>><</linkappend>> They say it was the great emperor Charlemagne who appointed your great, great, great grandfather as the first <em>luparii</em> and keeper of his royal forest here. Since then, your family has kept the forest and hunted the wolves and brought their pelts to the emperor or his margrave.</p> <p>But the priest and his friends at the monastery tell you that this margrave has chosen an anti-king to depose your emperor. The priest and monks don’t like the margrave or the anti-king (or the pope, you gather). They told you the margrave is a traitor who wants to make war on the emperor. But you’ve heard others at market day saying that the emperor is excommunicated, and we owe him no allegiance. That his bishops and monks are powerless to perform the sacraments. You think of your wife. She will have another child soon. What if she dies? Or the child dies? Will they be trapped forever in the cold nothing of purgatory because the priest can't bury them in the churchyard and say the blessing? It doesn't make sense. The priest and the monks say they can still give communion to the living and bless the dead. Those folk at the market say they can't. You don't understand it. But you do understand that the margrave is a traitor to the emperor. Maybe killing him will help.</p> <p>This new margrave got your best dog killed, too. Ignored your advice. Let his own huntsmen go after a bad-tempered boar after you told them not to. The boar is still out here somewhere, but not all the margrave's dogs, nor your own. The dog with you now is one of old Blade's granddaughters. Blade had been your father's dog before. He died as a hound should, but the margrave and his huntsmen treated you like a lowborn serf. Who knows what they'll do next, and who will pay the cost of their folly?</p>. <p>Making your slow return home, your dog at your heels and the fresh wolf pelt tied in a bundle on your back, your mind returns to its planning. The margrave will hunt here soon. You will attend the hunt, telling the huntsmen where to find what they want - fox, bear, boar, wolves, deer. How will you make sure the margrave doesn’t survive the day’s sport? And make sure you are never suspected?</p> </div> <div class="container center question"> <div class="row"> <h2>Pet the Zombie</h2> <p>History is the ultimate undead: Dead (sometimes <em>long</em> dead) but still alive, all around us, in our heads shaping our thoughts and feelings. You can't escape. Embrace the horror. Pet the zombie.</p> <<link '<img src="images/zombie.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration skeletons talking to people" width="50%">'>><<replace "#zombie">> <hr> <p>Medieval people enjoyed a rich world of forest legends. Today, their stories continue to enthrall us (and to enrich film producers and streaming services). They told of werewolves and witches, wild men ("wodewose") and green men and outlaws like Robin Hood.</p> <p><img src="images/greenmen.jpg" alt="carvings of foliar heads" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: The "green man" motif (thematically linked to the medieval "wild man" or "wodewose") appears frequently in ornamental woodwork crafted by peasant artisans. These "buttons" on English cathedral vaulting and misericords from the pews are medieval examples.</p> <p>There were legends of a "wild hunt," that told of a supernatural hunter or hunting party pursuing human quarry (often a woman) through the forest. A twelfth-century entry from the <em>Anglo-Saxon Chronicle</em> reports that, "many men both saw and heard a great number of huntsmen hunting. The huntsmen were black, huge, and hideous, and rode on black horses and on black he-goats, and their hounds were jet black, with eyes like saucers." Among other things, the "wild hunt" motif probably encapsulates peasants' feelings about the aristocratic hunters who marauded through the forests on a regular basis, heavily armed and thuggish. (The nobility had their own constellation of forest folklore, involving things like faeries and dragons and unicorns.)</p> <p><img src="images/unicorn.jpg" alt="woman with lion and unicorn" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: This scene from the famous unicorn tapestries (Paris, c. 1500) reflects aristocratic ideas about forest magic and legend.</p> <hr> <p>Question</p> <p id="zrespA"><<link "Response A">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespA">><</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="zrespB"><<link "Response B">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#zrespB">><</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="zombie"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>OK, $PlayerName, it's decision time!</h2> <p>Here's what you need to figure out:</p> <ol> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 1: </span>What is your plan for killing this guy?</li> <li><span class="bi">Role Play Assignment Prompt 2: </span>What are the results of your choices? For you, for your community, or for the broader sweep of history?</li> </ol> <p>Here are some of the factors that might shape your choices and the impact they will have.</p> <ul> <li>item</li> <li></li> </ul> <div class="container"> <div class="row center question"> <h2>Fellow Travelers</h2> <p>Many others have traveled this path through history before us. Ask these time travel pilgrims how they fared on the journey.</p> <<link '<img src="images/chaucer-pilgrims.jpg" alt="manuscript illustration of horsemen talking" width="50%">'>><<replace "#travelers">> <hr> <p>If you're enjoying this time travel journey through marvelous and magical world of medieval forest legend, you have plenty of company (like me). Many have traveled this path before us, and shaped the woodland vista we're enjoying right now. Fairy tales like Hansel and Gretel, Red Ridinghood, or Beauty and the Beast heavily influence what we're seeing here. The first people to commit these oral traditional narratives to writing as "fairy tales" were Madame d'Aulnoy and Charles Perrault in 17th-century France, and the Grimm Brothers in early 19th-century Germany. In each case, these writers took an active role in shaping the stories for their own purposes. More recently, Disney and Pixar have taken their turn, making the stories palatable to 20th- and 21st-century consumers, and profitable for themselves.</p> <p><img src="images/fairy-tale-movies.jpg" alt="movie covers" width="80%"></p> <p>But we are historians here! Have these fellow travelers ruined the view for us? Are our attitudes to the fairy tales so hopelessly muddled by all these previous re-tellings that the stories have no value to us as historians? When we look at actual medieval sources, we find very strong parallels with the fairy tales motifs. It's clear that they preserve elements of medieval folklore. But how can we find those medieval elements amid the untidy jumble of additions made by antiquarians and entertainers in the modern era? Should we even try? Well, that depends on who you ask.</p> <hr> <p>What do you think? Do the European fairy tales have value as primary sources about medieval history?</p> <p id="trespA"><<link "No way. They are far too compromised, and we have other, more legitimate primary sources from the actual Middle Ages. We should rely on those instead.">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespA">>This is probably correct (although not everyone agrees). The fairy tales, as we have them today, do contain elements of medieval folklore and reflect peasant beliefs and lifestyles. <em>However,</em> the earliest texts we have are from the later seventeenth century. The Middle Ages properly ends c. 1500. If our texts were oral traditional poetry, like Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em>, or Germanic verse like <em>Beowulf</em> or skaldic poetry, that wouldn't be much of a problem, because the tectonics of oral traditional poetics are designed to resist change over time. Those complex systems of meter and aural effect work to preserve pre-textual literature intact over long periods of time. <em>Beowulf</em> survives only in a single 11th-century manuscript, but its linguistic features reflect a far earlier idiom of English, and for that and various other reasons, most scholars view it as a copy of an earlier, 8th-century poem. Thanks to methodologies developed by historical linguists and anthropologists and literary scholars of oral traditional poetics, we have the tools to use complex, composite texts like this judiciously and fruitfully. But these fairy tales are just simple prose. Nothing to preserve their content from significant permutations over the centuries. So I think you are right here: They are not very valuable (if at all) as primary sources about the Middle Ages, even though they clearly do reflect some commonplaces of medieval life and belief systems (like forests are dangerous and wolves are scary and nobody likes stepmothers).<</replace>><</link>></p> <p id="trespB"><<link "Yes, please!">><<set $Score to $Score +2>><<replace "#trespB">><hr>While some scholars feel the same, the consensus among historians is more in the opposite direction: We cannot use the fairy tales as primary sources about medieval history. The fairy tales, as we have them today, do contain elements of medieval folklore and reflect peasant beliefs and lifestyles. <em>However,</em> the earliest texts we have are from the later seventeenth century. They change a good deal over time. The Middle Ages properly ends c. 1500, so texts from the late 17th century, 18th, and early 19th century can't tell us much (reliably) about medieval people. If these texts were oral traditional poetry, like Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em>, or Germanic verse like <em>Beowulf</em> or skaldic poetry, that wouldn't be much of a problem, because the tectonics of oral traditional poetics are designed to resist change over time. Those complex systems of meter and aural effect work to preserve pre-textual literature intact over long periods of time. <em>Beowulf</em> survives only in a single 11th-century manuscript, but its linguistic features reflect a far earlier idiom of English, and for that and various other reasons, most scholars view it as a copy of an earlier, 8th-century poem. Thanks to methodologies developed by historical linguists and anthropologists and literary scholars of oral traditional poetics, we have the tools to use complex, composite texts like this judiciously and fruitfully. But these fairy tales are just simple prose. Nothing to preserve their content from significant permutations over the centuries. So I think you are right here: They are not very valuable (if at all) as primary sources about the Middle Ages, even though they clearly do reflect some commonplaces of medieval life and belief systems (like forests are dangerous and wolves are scary and nobody likes stepmothers). If we did try to use them this way, our yield would be thin and unstable and poor quality. Sadly. Now, if we use the fairy tales to tell us about Renaissance and Early Modern periods, that's a whole different question, with a much more positive answer!<</replace>><</link>></p> <</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="row" id="travelers"></div> </div> <hr> <h2>Marginalia: Building your Role Play Response</h2> <p>As you decide what to do, why, and what might result, <span class="bi">you need to find supporting evidence </span> from the primary and secondary sources listed below. With each source, you will find a <span class="bi">"Marginalia" panel </span>where you can enter quotes and details from the source, along with notes about your own ideas and analysis. These notes will print on the "Victory!" screen at the end of the game, where you can copy and paste them into the Role Play response as the foundation of your submission.</p> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Books of the Hunt |ms-hunts]]</li> <li>[[Hunting "accidents" |hunt-death]]</li> <li>[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight |gawain]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About hunting in the Middle Ages |orme]]</li> <li>[[About peasants, poaching, and foresters in early medieval Europe |goldberg]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-f]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> </div> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Portals |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <h1>The Battle of Hattin in Context</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Battle of Hattin may be viewed as a turning point in history. It ensured the loss of the crusader kingdom of Jerusalem, and triggered the next wave of (unsuccessful) crusades. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1eFvpcDEFMiRwpzpGeOJqfxQl6zGr2Kk3/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This section</a> of the <em>Cambridge Atlas of Military History: The Middle Ages</em>, takes a close look at the battle and its significance for the First and Second Crusades.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Strengths and weaknesses of the crusader and Muslim forces at the Battle of Hattin</li> <li>Motivations and outcomes of the decisions made by Gui de Lusignan and the other crusader leaders</li> <li>Weapons and armor used by both sides in the battle</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Crusaders</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fihNdu1Ak3pBjTlnSlNmwuxSxrRRfPaF/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This chapter</a> of the <em>Cambridge History of War</em> offers a close and scholarly examination of the motivations and methods of the crusaders, including details about the nature of crusade warfare. It provides a rich sense of the wider political, ideological, economic, and military context of the Battle of Hattin, as well as reflections on the historical significance of the crusades more broadly.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Typical features of crusade warfare (e.g., weapons, tactics, strategy, advantages and disadvantages when facing Muslim armies)</li> <li>The kinds of concerns that would have shaped Gui de Lusignan's decisions and outlook at the Battle of Hattin</li> <li>How a different outcome of the Battle of Hattin might have altered the course of the history of the crusades</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source.
