enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Crusaders Sack Jerusalem</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In 1087, the First Crusade achieved captured Jerusalem, beginning the process of founding crusader states in the Holy Land (where the rest of the crusades would be fought ... and, without exception, lost). The bloody fall of Jerusalem in 1099 stands as one of the most shameful episodes in the history of the West. Eyewitnesses frequently describe blood covering their feet and their horses' legs from the victorious crusaders' slaughter of civilians. Historians have explained it in various ways, from deliberate, methodical genocide to berserk religious fervor. French cleric and historian Fulcher of Charters was present, and wrote <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1F6Zsb7oSacBFDlLZXb1YjUlgfUJwQ-NBFH0Nwon-U5Y/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this account of the fall of Jerusalem in 1099</a> in his history of the first crusade, <em>Deeds of the French on the Journey to Jerusalem</em>.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Crusader siege and battle tactics and technologies</li> <li>Crusader attitudes toward Muslims</li> <li>Challenges facing the crusaders in their attempt to conquer the Holy Land</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knje1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knja1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knje2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knja2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knje3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knja3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knje4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$knja4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Crusaders take Jerusalem |sack]]</li> <li>[[An ideal knight |warewic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Battle of Hattin in context |hattin]]</li> <li>[[Crusader warfare |crusader]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Gui de Lusignan grew up in the lap of luxury. His family, the House of Lusignan, had a well-earned reputation for defying authority, waging petty wars, and doing whenever pleased them, in (often violent) defiance of royal commands. Several found themselves - like Gui here - commanding crusader armies, and even kingdoms, in the Holy Land. At home in Poitou (France), they spent their days hunting, or in tournaments, or raiding. They enjoyed a vibrant court culture including troubadours who sang and wrote a wide variety of chivalric literature. These included cultured and courtly <em>chansons de geste,</em> ("songs of deeds") full of heroic quests, tournaments, epic battles, true love and fair maidens and fairies in enchanted forests. They also included utterly trashy, scattalogical tales called <em>fabliaux</em>, featuring dirty jokes and sexual assault of peasant women. Such was the life of the medieval male aristocracy.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p><img src="images/hattin-map.jpg" alt="map of the crusader states with Hattin circled" width="100%"></p> <p>This map shows the location of the crusader states at the time of the Battle of Hattin (1187), and the location of Hattin and Tiberias (on the shores of "Lake Tiberias," better known as the Sea of Galilee).</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>In 1186, near the Kingdom of Jerusalem, 140 crusader knights, led by a group of Templars, met a force of Muslims numbering around 7,000. Ignoring a truce that had been agreed to between the two armies, the crusaders attacked, crying, "Christ is our life, and death is our reward!" Only four survived, one of whom was the Templar Grand Master, Gerard de Ridefort, who had ordered the charge. He was also among the leaders at Hattin. There again, he survived an otherwise bloody defeat for the crusaders.</p> <p>The graphic below represents the numerical disparity between the 140 crusaders and the 7,000 Muslims at the Springs of Cresson in 1186.</p> <p><img src="images/cresson.jpg" alt="pie chart showing few crusaders and majority of Muslims" width="80%"></p> </div><<if $knightsCombat1 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Knights]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Presentism Poltergeist!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: An example of presentism</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? [[Continue on. |Renaissance]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Here's your opponent. To win this fight, choose a good response to this creature's questionable statements about history.</h3> <img src="images/mobs/creeper1.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of demon with large ears" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says, "Gunpowder was the new technology that ended the medieval feudal system."</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Choose a response to this mob's hysterical history.</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ1" "A">>This statement has little meaning, since there was no feudal system.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ1" "B">>This is a gross oversimplification. Gunpowder is just a tool, and technology cannot be the sole driver for social and cultural change.</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ1" "C">>Gunpowder was a game-changer, sure. But this statement ignores other similarly or equally impactful technologies such as the printing press or the stern-post rudder.</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "ren-combat1-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if $renCombat2 is "done">> You already won this fight. [[Continue on. |Renaissance]] <<else>> <div class="container"> <div class="row center"> <div class = "col-3"> <h3>Oh no! It's a Tautology Troll!</h3> <img src="images/mobs/monster4.jpg" alt="manuscript illumination of monster with horns" width="100%"> </div> <div class="col-9"> <p>It says: "some dumb circular logic"</p> </div> </div> <hr> <div class="row center"> <p>Well ...? What's the best response to this statement?</p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ2" "A">>Correct response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ2" "B">>Incorrect response</label></p> <p><label><<radiobutton "$renCombatQ2" "C">>Incorrect response</label></p> </div> <div class="row" id="combat-spoils"> <div class="col-4"> </div> <div class="col-4 explore-link"> <<link "Victory or defeat?">><<replace "#combat-spoils">><<include "ren-combat2-spoils">><</replace>><</link>> </div> <div class="col-4"> </div> </div> </div> <</if>><<if ($renCombatQ2 is "A") and ($renCombatQ2 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat2 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Excellent choice! You have defeated the Presentism Poltergeist and boosted your score by 5! Choose loot for your inventory: </p> <li><<linkreplace "Chalice">><<set $chalice to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Helmet">><<set $helmet to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <p>[[Onward! |Renaissance]]</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated by the Presentism Poltergeist. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Renaissance]]</p> <</if>> <<if ($renCombatQ1 is "A") and ($renCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>I mean, it is perfectly sound to be skeptical or even dismissive of any statement about "the feudal system." This mob should certainly clean up its diction. But it is not wrong in its assertion that a medieval socio-economic and cultural paradigm, characterized by past historians and readily identifiable as (loosely) "feudal" <em>did</em> come to an end in the early modern or renaissance period. A major transition from "medieval" to "modern" did occur. Personally, "gunpowder" feels more problematic than "feudal" here. What does it even mean by "gunpowder?" As in, projectile weapons? As in, explosive? As in, massed infantry wielding matchlocks? Either way, this thing is sloppy with its speech. It loses this battle. Choose an item for your inventory and enjoy 5 points added to your score!</p> <li><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <p>[[Onward! |Renaissance]]</p> <<else if ($renCombatQ1 is "B") and ($renCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Nice work flagging technological determinism! This naughty mob. Technology is obviously a huge driver of change on many levels. However, historiographical agruments that technology is the sole direct cause of change are unsound at worst, unfashionable at best. Gunpowder undoubtedly catalyzed the transition from medieval to modern. But we would be miss much if we myopically fixated on gunpowder as the <em>only</em> (or even the main) cause.</p> <li><<linkreplace "Gold">><<set $gold to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <li><<linkreplace "Sword">><<set $sword to true>>\<</linkreplace>></li> <p>[[Onward! |Renaissance]]</p> <<else if ($renCombatQ1 is "C") and ($renCombatQ1 isnot "")>> <<set $renCombat1 to "done">> <<set $Score to $Score + 5>> <p>Agreed. This fellow is probably right to point to gunpowder as <em>one of</em> the most important technological catalysts for Europe's transition from medieval to modern. But others have a strong claim to rank among these late medieval technological MVPs as well.</p> <<else>> <p>You have been defeated. Better luck next time. [[Move on through this time travel portal. |Renaissance]]</p> <</if>> <div class="container"> <h1>An Ideal Knight</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Knights loved story time. They often quoted parts of their favorite stories, especailly the gross and bawdy ones with raunchy jokes. These stories were typically about guys like themselves (or as they liked to imagine themselves), so these stories are very useful to historians in telling us about how knights viewed themselves, what they wanted to be like, how they wanted others to see them <em>as knights</em>. Of course, these ideals of chivalry were just that - <em>ideals</em>. So these stories don't tell us a lot about what knights knew they <em>should</em> do, and a little bit about what knights <em>actually did</em> do. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JJySNOhF2p90RQvZCb1U0m1LM8g2SCTt/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">These excerpts</a> are from a very popular story about a knight called Gui de Warewic. This story was written c. 1200 and survives in many manuscripts and fragments throughout Europe (a testament to its popularity). Knights just loved this dude. Probably little boy knights had posters of Gui in their bedrooms (I'm imagining). Gui's adventures include fighting dragons and giants, fighting lots of other knights in tournaments, skirmishes, and battles, going on crusade, having fun with his guy friends, a super sweet bromance that's really the heart of the whole story, rescuing high-status women, falling in love with the local lord's daughter at his hometown, who refuses to return his love until he has proven himself to be the best knight in the world (but then, of course, she continually moves the goalpost on him, and they get together only very briefly and only at the very end of the story when he's almost dead). Anyway. They loved this stuff. Enjoy (if you can).</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>The chivalric ideal</li> <li>What knights liked to do, or wanted to be known to do</li> <li>How knights fought (weapons, tactics, codes of behavior or rules of war)</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwa3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$kngwa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Crusaders take Jerusalem |sack]]</li> <li>[[An ideal knight |warewic]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Battle of Hattin in context |hattin]]</li> <li>[[Crusader warfare |crusader]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-h]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: King of Jerusalem |Hattin]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>A margrave was basically a count or duke of a marcher county in the Holy Roman Empire, since Charlemagne. A marcher county was on "the marches," or the frontiers, so a margrave (English equivalent of "marcher lord") had to have a certain amount of competence as a military leader. Swabia, bordering troublesome old Lombardy, and near the rising power of the Italian states, was a marcher county.</p> <p><img src="images/hre1200.jpg" alt="map of central Europe" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: Map of the Holy Roman Empire, c. 1200.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Your trap is a bow trap. The hidden bow fires its arrow when an animal (ideally, a wolf) trips the cord at ground level. Royal law requires that a bow trap be protected by neck-level cords as well, across the path before and after the armed trap. This way, only something the height of a wolf could trigger the deadly bow.</p> <p><img src="images/stuttgart-bow.jpg" alt="man in cloak with drawn bow" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: A drawn bow in the Stuttgart Psalter (Germany, c. 820) shows the type of bow this forester probably used.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>st john's eve bonfire midsummer beltane</p> <p>image</p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>medieval plays</p> <p>image</p> <p>caption</p> </div><<if $witchExplore1 is "done">> This quest is complete. onclick="cpyArt()">Copy text</button> <p>List the sources you used. Use the "copy text" button to place these citations in a "Works Cited" section at the end of your role play response.</p> <div class="copynotes" id="copyarts"> <<if (def $arteqe1) and ($arteqe1 isnot "")>><p>Equiano, Olaudah.<em>Interesting Narrative</em>. In Cal Poly Humboldt, HIST 104, Instructor: Queen. Accessed [date]. https://canvas.humboldt.edu/courses/75559.</p><</if>> <<if (def $artdave1) and ($artdave1 isnot "")>><p>Davis, David Brion.<em>Inhuman Bondage: The Rise and Fall of Slavery in the New World</em>. New York: Oxford University Press, 2006.</p><</if>> <<if (def $arteltise1) and ($arteltise1 isnot "")>><p>Eltis, David. <em>The Rise of African Slavery in the Americas</em> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2000)</p><</if>> <<if (def $artme1) and ($artme1 isnot "")>><p>Morgan, Jennifer. "'Some Could Suckle over Their Shoulder': Male Travelers, Female Bodies." In In <em>Women's America: Refocusing the Past, Ninth Edition.</em> Edited by Linda K. Kerber, Hane Sherron De Hart, Cornelia Huhes Dayton, and Karissa Haugeberg, 11 - 20. New York: Norton, 2019.</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyArts()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Portal |Renaissance]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Popular beliefs about witches varied across space and time in the early modern West. Causing infant mortality was at the core of these beliefs. This widely-circulated engraving from late 16th-century Germany illustrates what witches typically did, according to popular belief.</p> <p><img src="images/binsfeld.jpg" alt="engraving of witches and demons" width="100%"></p> <p>caption</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Early modern communities' responses to nonbinary gender identities could be surprisingly nuanced. For instance, when Thomas Hall's nonbinary identity caused a kerfuffle in colonial Virginia in 1629, the General Court ruled that Hall could choose their gender identity for themselves, and that this might vary from day to day. The court's only stipulation was that Hall must dress according to their gender identity at any given time, so that the community understood how to treat them and what to expect of them at any given time.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>This is you.</p> <p><img src="images/carracci-portrait.jpg" alt="African woman holding a clock" width="100%"></p> <p>Italian painter Annibale Carracci created this portrait of an African woman holding a clock c. 1583. Its subject and original context continue to puzzle art historians.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Renaissance European depictions of Native American and African women typically commented on the differences with European gender norms, especially social mores surrounding clothing, manners, sexuality and marriage, and gendered division of labor. Gender norms were centrally embedded in developing western ideas of race.</p> <p><img src="debry-african-women.jpg" alt="sketches of African women" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Artist Theodor de Bry produced this engraving of African women in 1604. De Bry himself never traveled to the Americas, Africa, or Asia. Instead, he produced engraving plates based on the paintings and sketches of people who <em>had</em> been on European voyages to those places. Then, de Bry printed his engravings and sold many copies of books about European travels to the newly-discovered Americas, to Africa, and to Asia. His work exerted a powerful influence on Europeans' developing sense of "western" identity, and their ideas about other cultures around the world.</p> <p><img src="images/john-white-woman.jpg" alt="painting of Native American woman wearing skirt of animal skin" width="50%"></p> <p>Above: In 1585, English artist John White visited the Carolina coast with the ill-fated Roanoke expedition, and painted numerous images of the indigenous people he met there. Fortunately for historians, White chose to return to England with paintings like tihs one, while the other Roanoke settlers stayed behind and were eaten by aliens. (That's actually what happened. Just ask the internet.)</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The printing press was the machinery that powered much/most of the progressive, innovative, disruptive discourse of the Renaissance. It began when German Protestant reformers invented and used the printing press to disseminate the Bible in the vernacular, and their criticisms of the Catholic church. As the Renaissance progressed, people used the same technology to push other agendas. For instance, when Spanish friar De las Casas spoke out in opposition to Spain's brutal treatment of Native Americans, Protestants picked up his reports of Spanish attrocities and wove them into their imperialist narratives with a propaganda project remembered by historians as "The Black Legend." The Black Legend used De las Casas' humanitarian messages for their own purpose, to present a contrast bewteen Catholic Spain as a uniquely brutal, evil empire on one hand, and the more progressive, liberal ideology of Protestant regimes of Elizabethan England and the Dutch Republic. Of course, the sad reality is that Protestant and Catholic kingdoms alike represented doom and disease for Native Americans. But the printing press was a powerful weapon in the arsenal of Protestant reformers who wanted to demonize Catholicism.</p> <p><img src="images/blacklegend.jpg" alt="cutting off hands and feet" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: One of Theodor de Bry's graphic scenes of Spanish atrocities against Native Americans (1590s).</p> <p><img src="images/reformation-pope.jpg" alt="caricature of demonic figure holding staff with ego sum papa title" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: The image on the left is one of the earliest Protestant prints, from sixteenth-century Paris. The version on the right is a later adaptation of the same motif, depicting the pope as a monstrous, predatory demon. (Remember the Babylon symbolism from our very first role play unit? Here it is again! The tower of Babel on the pope's head links back to the old symbolism of Babylon, and represents the worldliness and corruption of the Catholic church.)</p> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Morgan, "Some Could Suckle over their Shoulder"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1L0Sw8XMHJNPv044Odgf6KMcPbhgvklAB/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this article from a U.S. Women's History textbook,</a> Jennifer Morgan investigates the language used by early modern European male travelers to describe indigenous American and African women, showing how these reports worked with European notions of gender in the development of racism in European society.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>item</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$artme1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$artma1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$artme2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$artma2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[An African boy is enslaved |equiano]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The origins of anti-black racism |bondage]]</li> <li>[[Gender and slavery |eltis]]</li> <li>[[European descriptions of African women |morgan]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: An African Artist |Artist]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <header class="center"> <ul> <li>Name: $PlayerName</li> <li>Score: $Score</li> <li>Loot: <<include "Inventory">></li> <li><p>Unit completed: The Age of Knights</p> <p><img src="images/hma.jpg" alt="knight" width="150px" height="100px"></p> </li> </ul> </header> </div> <div class="row victoryhero"> <div class="transbox-hero"> <h1>Victory!</h1> <p>$PlayerName, you are a time travel hero! Graff and Anne Curry, eds., <em>The Cambridge History of War: Volume 2, War and the Medieval World</em> (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2020), pp. 266 - 296.</p><</if>> </div> <button onclick="cpyKnightss()">Copy text</button> </div> </div> <h2>You're done! </h2> <p>Congratulations and good work! Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Age of Knights Portal |Knights]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="row"> <h1>Life as a Nun</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>To us today, the phrase "living like a nun" implies "boring, no fun, no sex, no gold or glory or fashion." As you might guess, this is very far from the truth for medieval women who chose to become "brides of Christ" and live in a monastery ("nunnery" or "abbey"). In fact, these women could wield immense power, and enjoy delights of intellect as well as body. <a href="https://www.worldhistory.org/article/1298/the-daily-life-of-medieval-nuns/" target="_blank">This informative article</a> from World History Encyclopedia gives us a glimpse into the (unexpectedly?) fascinating lives of medieval nuns.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>What Eleanor of Aquitaine's new monastic order might look like, in terms of its goals, daily life (its rules), and the kinds of women who would want to join</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elne1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elna1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elne2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elna2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elne3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elna3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elne4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$elna4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[The pope calls for crusade |crusade]]</li> <li>[[Codex Manesse |manesse]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Women and courtly romance |romance]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Knights-victory-e]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Age of Knights |Knights]]</li> <li>[[Back: Eleanor of Aquitaine |Eleanor]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>From Chaucer's <em>Canterbury Tales</em></h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Geoffrey Chaucer is often considered the father of English literature. He was active at the court of Richard II in England, turing tumultuous time of peasant rebellions, the Hundred Years' War, and dynastic conflict between rival aristocratic factions that would ultimately blossom into the Wars of the Roses between the houses of Lancaster, York, and Tudor. Not a boring time! Chaucer's best-known work is <em>The Canterbury Tales</em> (c. 1390), a frame narrative in which a group of pilgrims on a journey to the shrine of Saint Thomas Becket at Canterbury pass the time by telling stories. <a href="https://chaucer.fas.harvard.edu/pages/millers-prologue-and-tale" target="_blank">"The Miller's Tale"</a> is a bawdy, even scattalogical, story about a young wife, her old husband, and her two rival suitors. Maybe it's not what you'd expect from "the father of English literature" ... or maybe it is.</p> <p>Note that the story appears at the Harvard Chaucer website in alternating lines of Middle English and modern English translation. You can ignore the Middle English (or mess around with trying to understand it, just for fun). Here's a synopsis of the story to get you started, again from <a href="https://chaucer.fas.harvard.edu/pages/millers-tale-0" target="_blank">the Harvard Chaucer site</a>:</p> <p><em>"John, a rich old carpenter of Oxford has a young wife, the eighteen-year-old Alisoun, whom he guards carefully, for he is very jealous. He has a boarder, the clerk Nicholas, who makes advances to Alisoun; she quickly agrees and they determine to consummate the affair. Absolon, the parish clerk and village dandy, also lusts for Alisoun, but he woos her in vain, for Nicholas is there first. Nicholas tricks John into thinking that Noah's flood is coming again; John rigs up three kneading tubs, in which he, Nicholas, and Alisoun can float until the waters recede. When the flood is due, all three climb up into the tubs. John goes to sleep, Alisoun and Nicholas go back to the bedroom. They are interrupted by Absolon, who has come to woo Alisoun at the window. She promises him a kiss and puts her backside out the window. Absolon kisses it. He soon realizes his mistake. He gets a hot coulter (plow blade) from Gervase, the smith, and returns to ask for another kiss. Nicholas puts his backside out, Absolon strikes it with the red-hot coulter, Nicholas yells for water; the carpenter awakes and thinks the flood has come, cuts lose his tub and falls and breaks his arm. The neighbors rush in, and all are convinced old John is mad."</em></p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Marriage and community relationships</li> <li>Romance, courtship, and attitudes toward sex</li> <li>Religious practices and beliefs</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Scenes from peasant life |life]]</li> <li>[[From Chaucer's <em>Canterbury Tales</em> |miller]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Peasant life and relationships |penifader]]</li> <li>[[Medieval sexuality |sexuality]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Peasants-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants |Peasants]]</li> <li>[[Back: The Misummer Bonfire Scenario |Love]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Peasant Life</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Leading medievalist and feminist historian Judith M. Bennett wrote a wonderful microhistory about a 14th-century English peasant woman named Cecilia Penifader. In <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zVF-N3qWCA1GM6LVK9jzyWvKvxTZMr-_/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">this section</a>, Bennett takes on on a tour of a typical year in a medieval village. And in <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1k2HAmWDS3hwEEzPfBwIzP9sLSVejfVuq/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank"></a>, she covers relationships, marriage, and gender.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>How peasants lived, worked, and played in a typical year</li> <li>Relationships, especially overlapping networks and obligations among community, family, and marriage</li> <li>Religious practices and beliefs</li> <li>Medieval farming</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div Well done! They say history is written by the victors. Right now, that's you. You need to submit this in Canvas along with your written response.</p> <hr> <div class="row"> <h2>Second: Grab your marginalia</h2> <p>Below, you'll find the notes you saved from the primary and Now you're ready to write your Role Play response and submit it in Canvas. I hope you enjoyed your journey through history, and I look forward to discussing your ideas in class. Later in the week, be sure to check out everyone's role play responses here:</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Our History Rewrite]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Start |Portals]]</li> <li>[[Back: Peasants |Peasants]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Case of Thomas(ine) Hall</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>In 1629, an indentured servant called Hall recently arrived from England appeared in a Virginia courtroom. The problem? Hall's fellow colonists couldn't agree on whether Hall was male or female. Hall had been raised as a female and had female skills (like embroidery). But they had also fought as a mercenary in Europe (a male thing). Hall had sexual encounters with females. Hall sometimes dressed as a woman, and sometimes as a man. They had male and female skillsets. People felt quite confused, and the problem found its way to court and into the historical record. <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ux7EZ6q0UL6HltVPdG5wqKPIS0ckv7VL/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This article</a> examines the court case in which the Virginia authorities attempt to issue a verdict on Hall's gender identity and sexuality.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Seventeenth-century attitudes toward sexuality and gender</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchhe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$witchha4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Images of witches |witch-images]]</li> <li>[[An English witch trial |scott]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Early modern masculinity |roper]]</li> <li>[[A non-binary person |thomasine]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Renaissance-victory-w]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: The Renaissance |Renaissance]]</li> <li>[[Back: A Witch Trial |Witch]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>The symposium - the ancient Greek tradition of a dinner party centered around philosophical and literary debates - was one of the features of Hellenistic culture that spread with Alexander's conquests. The ceramic art below, from fifth-century BCE Athens, shows a symposium.</p> <p><img src="images/symposium.jpg" alt="ceramic art showing figures reclining and feasting" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Bradley, "The Regular, Daily Traffic in Slaves"</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zy2mKUHBgBtRMYGm1DbLytxI2akr24WD/view?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This wonderful article</a> provides details about slavery and the slave trade in everyday Roman life. It engages in a broad comparison between slavery in ancient Rome and slavery in the American South, with sustained commentary on the challenges posed and lessons suggested by these parallel histories.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>item</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$sprtradee1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$sprtradea1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$sprtradee2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$sprtradea2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "sprtradee3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$sprtradea3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$sprtradee4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$sprtradea4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Roman depictions of slavery |gladiators]]</li> <li>[[Plutarch's account of the rebellion |plutarch-spartacus]]</li> <li>[[A slave rebellion in Sicily |sicily-slaves]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Spartacus' rebellion |strauss]]</li> <li>[[The Roman slave trade |bradley]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook and class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome1-victory-s]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Rome: From Republic to Empire Portal |Rome1]]</li> <li>[[Back: Spartacus Scenario |Spartacus]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>Jealous of his hunting rights, Charlemagne used his royal power to kick the peasants out of the forests. His aggressive new legislation privatized the forests and criminalized various forms of hunting and trapping. The new laws even forbid peasants to defend themselves from predatory wolves, a task the emperor delegated to royal appointees called the <em>luparii</em>.</p> <p>Controling the wolf population was also a task of the local foresters. Foresters were appointed by the king or emperor to enforce forest laws, and they occupied an unusual place in medieval society. They were peasants, but they regularly interacted with the nobility and enjoyed special legal and economic privileges, like exemptions from court meetings and military service. They tended to be more competent with horses and weapons, and have a higher income than most peasants. The position tended to be hereditary. (Why do you think that would that be?).</p> <p>People were terrified of wolves (as reflected in oral traditional fairy tales like Red Riding Hood, or legends of werewolves). According to a learned 9th-century text based on Isidore of Seville's <em>Etymologies</em>, "With a greedy fury the wolf kills whatever it finds. … It is a ravenous beast eager for blood. Peasants say that a person loses his voice if a wolf sees him before he sees the wolf. For this reason people say when there is a sudden lull in a conversation, ‘Just like the wolf in the story…’ Wolves endure hunger for a long time, and after a long fast they devour everything.”</p> <p>In English, the term "wolf's head" was slang for "outlaw." Legally, everyone was required to kill or harm an outlaw if they could. That's what "outlaw" status meant, technically, and people felt the same way about wolves. It's hard to find any positive or sympathetic references to wolves from the Middle Ages. In the medieval French tales of Reynard the fox, the wolf represents the greedy and violent nobility, pitted against the smarller but resourceful fox (the peasants). (Although the Germanic motif of the beasts of battle and wolves' vague association with berserks could be seen as "positive" inasmuch as it's part of a common stock of traditional heroic themes and aesthetic.)</p> <p><img src="images/stuttgart-predators.jpg" alt="predators across a river from livestock" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: This image from the Stuttgart Psalter (Germany, c. 820) captures the peasants' attitude toward forest predators (boar, wolf, bear), who threaten their livestock.</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>As a teenager, Eleanor married the French king Louis VII, later known as Saint Louis (not to be confused with Louis the Pious, who was a very French king). Eleanor's Louis did become quite saintly. But he didn't start out that way. He wasn't the oldest son, and he was raised for a career in the church, while his elder brother was groomed for the throne. But his brother died in a hunting "accident" at the age of 15, and everyone except Louis heaved a sigh of relief because (the older brother seems to have been pure evil). But Louis was disappointed. He didn't want to be king! Yuck. He was totally into his church career and hated the sudden pivot toward a career of chivalry.</p> <p>Big surprise, Louis wasn't totally amazing at being king. And then he had a really bad experience. It happened when he went to war against some of his vassals at Eleanor's instigation. Her sister wanted to marry a dude who was already married, and Eleanor got Louis involved on her sister's side. Anyway, long story short, Louis finds himself on a hilltop just outside a town that's being sacked by his mercenaries. The mercenaries are everything on fire. The townsfolk are fleeing to the (stone) church for sanctuary and safety. But the wind shifts and the fires spread to the church. The wind is blowing toward the king on the hilltop. He can smell something like 1,500 people cooking, and he can hear them screaming. He's trying to send orders to stop it, but the flames don't listen, and neither does anyone else. This incident causes something to snap in the already emotionally battered young man's mind. What the chroniclers describe is what we would call PTSD. From then on, Louis starts living like an aescetic saint. Among other things, this means he's not going to beget a child. When he hears Bernard's call for holy crusade at Vessaly, it's like a rope thrown to a drowning man in a storm. He finally has something to live for: a martyr's death on holy crusade.</p> <p>Eleanor goes with Louis on crusade. It was a military disaster, but Eleanor seems to have enjoyed luxury and adventure on the trip, including (probably) an affair with Raymond, the French crusader king of Anthioch. (She asks to be left behind with Raymond, instead of going home with Louis. She doesn't get away with that, but when they get home from crusade, her marriage with Louis is annulled. This was fairly common for aristocratic marriages, because the rules were kind of impossible: Marriage was forbidden within 4 degrees of affinity. Since the noble houses of Europe were tangled together like a nest of snakes, most aristocratic marriages had some kind of technical impediment (usually involving consanguinity), and could be annulled if people wanted to do that.</p> <p><img src="images/eleanor-chinon.jpg" alt="fresco of medieval nobles on horseback" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Louis and Eleanor with other nobles on crusade (13th-century fresco from a chapel at Chinon, France).</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The motif of "the lady with the mead cup" was beloved by Old English poets. In <em>Beowulf</em>, for instance: "Wealhtheow went forth, Hrothgar’s queen, mindful of customs; Adorned with gold, she greeted the men in the hall, Then that courteous wife offered the full cup, First to the guardian of the East-Danes’ kingdom, Bid him be merry at his beer-drinking, Beloved by his people; with pleasure he received the feast and cup, victorious king. The lady of the Hemings then went about to young and old, gave each his portion of the precious cup … "</p> <p>And here's the theme in an Old English poem known as <em>Maxims I</em>, a collection of gnomic verses about "the way things are" in this world: "The woman must excel as one cherished among her people, and be buoyant of mood, keep confidences, be open-heartedly generous with horses and with treasures; in deliberation over the mead, in the presence of the troop of companions, she must always and everywhere greet first the chief of those princes and instantly offer the chalice to her lord’s hand, and she must know what is prudent for them both as rulers of the hall."</p> <p>In both of these examples (which are representative), we see that the women are more than waitresses. They take an active role in the political scene (an impression clearly and repeatedly reinforced by evidence outside of poetry (in chronicles and legal documents, for instance). A variety of evidence clearly shows that elite women were powerful players in the early medieval game of thrones.</p> <p>But "peace weaver" was one side of this coin. The other side was "inciter of violence." Ever wonder where the term "to egg someone on" comes from? It makes no sense, right? Well, it's not "egg" from our word "egg." It's from the Old Norse verb <em>eggja,</em> which means to "whet, to put an edge to a weapon," and the Old English noun <em>ecg</em>, "edge." Poetry, chronicles, and sagas from the early Germanic world frequently depict women as inciters of violence, "egging on" their menfolk by aggressively reminding them of revenge obligations or unsettled feuds. Like, "Get off the couch and go kill someone. Your list of people you're supposed to be killing is so long, why are you sitting here?"</p> <p>There's even an intriguing connection way back to Roman times, in the first-century account of Germanic tribes written by Tacitus. He notes that German women came to war with their men, not to fight in the front lines, but to yell at them from the sidelines and remind them of what would happen to their women if the other side was victorious. Here's what Tacitus says in <em>Germania</em> (c. 98): “Tradition says that armies already wavering and giving way have been rallied by women who, with earnest entreaties and bosoms laid bare, have vividly represented the horrors of captivity, which the Germans fear with such extreme dread on behalf of their women, that the strongest tie by which a state can be bound is the being required to give, among the number of hostages, maidens of noble birth. They even believe that the sex has a certain sanctity and prescience, and they do not despise their counsels, or make light of their answers.” Maybe the early medieval oral traditional poetry preserves something of these old gender norms recorded by Tacitus centuries earlier. Or maybe not. What do you think?</p> <p><img src="images/mead-cup.jpg" alt="silver female figures" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: These silver Viking Age ornaments present women carrying a horn or cup - a common motif that resonates with these depictions of women in the poetry.</p> <p>Below: Another example of this "lady with a mead cup" motif, from a memorial stone from Viking Age Sweden. In the top panel, Odin is shown on his eight-legged horse, Sleipnir, receiving a mead cup from a valkyrie.</p> <p><img src="images/gotland-odin.jpg" alt="painted stone carving of Viking ship and mythological figures" width="80%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>These are the famous opening lines of <em>Beowulf</em>. The poem was composed in the late 8th century, but survives only in a single manuscript from c. 1000. Here is the first page from that precious manuscript.</p> <p><img src="images/beowulf.jpg" alt="manuscript page" width="100%"></p> <p>Below: Here is what it might have sounded like.</p> <p><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/0zorjJzrrvA?si=Y0j69Yr9J8lMzYEU" title="YouTube video player" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen></iframe></p> </div><div class="container"> <h1>The Sutton Hoo Ship Burial</h1><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ss-tag"> <p>Secondary Source</p> </div> </div> <p>The eighth-century English poem <em>Beowulf</em> begins with a king's funeral, in which the king's body is put in a ship along with his treasure, and sent out to sea. Historians and archaeologists were ecstatic when the remains of just such a ship burial were unearthed. It was a bit like what happened to Homer's <em>Iliad</em> and <em>Odyssey</em> when archaeologists discovered the remains of the Trojan War. An epic poem long assumed to be fictional was suddenly granted a foundation in historical reality.</p> <p>The Sutton Hoo ship burial resembles the funeral in the poem (except that the ship and its contents were buried rather than launched out to sea). You can view and learn about the artifacts from this fascinating archaeological site at <a href="https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/death-and-memory/anglo-saxon-ship-burial-sutton-hoo" target="_blank">this page from the British Museum.</a> Note that this is another source that contains both primary and secondary material: The Sutton Hoo artifacts themselves are primary sources, while the information provided by the British Museum is secondary source material.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Symbols of kingship in early medieval England</li> <li>Forms of treasure used by the Anglo-Saxon elite</li> <li>Pre-Christian English ideas about the afterlife</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the role play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your role play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingshe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingsha1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingshe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingsha2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingshe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingsha3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingshe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$askingsha4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Converting the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms |bede]]</li> <li>[[King Hrothgar |hrothgar]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[The Sutton Hoo ship burial |suttonhoo]]</li> <li>[[About the arrival of Christianity in Anglo-Saxon England |naismith]]</li> <li>[[What we can and can't know about Germanic paganism |orton]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-k]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Anglo-Saxon King Scenario |AS-king]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> (c. 98 CE)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The Roman historian Tacitus wrote <em>Germania</em> c. 98 CE, describing the barbarian tribes in the province of Germania. Tacitus himself never visited the region, but drew on works such as Caesar's <em>Gallic Wars</em>, and Hellenistic histories by Strabo and Diodorus. While <em>Germania</em> has been foundational to our modern understanding of the barbarian tribes and the history of the Germanic peoples in late antiquity, the text is extremely problematic as a primary source. For one thing, Tacitus wrote with a clear ideological agenda: His presentation of Germanic society was designed partly as a critique of his own Roman society. He was not writing objectively or as a trained ethnographer or anthropologist. It is also problematic that Tacitus was writing c. 100 CE at the height of Roman power, but we tend to use this text as a source about the Germanic tribes c. 500 CE. It is so rich, and there aren't many others, so it's attractive to us as historians. But it also has numerous problems as a source.</p> <p>In <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jAoWq785AM6BPSCM09ASy60ZLOjgdv1RmwFecPEdoW0/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">these excerpts</a> from <em>Germania</em>, Tacitus discusses various aspects of Germanic society.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Beliefs and customs of barbarian society</li> <li>Everyday life, family and gender norms in barbarian society</li> <li>Military strengths and weaknesses of the barbarian tribes</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adriangete1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangeta1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangete2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangeta2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangete3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangeta3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangete4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangeta4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> |tacitus]]</li> <li>[[Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> |jordanes]]</li> <li>[[Barbarian law |law]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <li>[[About the Roman legions in the fourth century CE |halsall]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hattin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval
