"hattin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "hattin-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Knights Rewrite |knights-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="title-box"> <h1>You are in love</h1> <p>A rural village, c. 1300</p> </div> <p>It's summer solstice. <<linkappend "The St John's Eve bonfire">><<include love-link1>><</linkappend>> roars up into heaven, loud and hot and glorious.</p> <p>You lounge in the shadows, avoiding the heat of the flames. The night is still warm, and you feel the urgency of its haste. <em>There's not much time.</em> Midsummer nights begin and end in a single breath. Carefully cradling a cup brimming with good mead, you watch the one you love. Jostling against their friends, laughing and singing, they dance around the roaring bonfire. They're like a spirit, like a flame. You take another drink, feeling miserable and excited at the same time, desperate to make something happen before dawn. <em>Not much time.</em> You've been in love with them for at least a year now, but barely exchanged a few words.</p> <p>You look away into the night and take another drink. <em>It's no good,</em> you think for the thousandth time. Even if you could manage to catch their attention somehow, then what? Lovers for a time? Or together forever? Impossible. Your families hate each other. The manor court rolls groan with the weight of your ancestors' names, taking each other to court for generations: property lines, insults and assaults, fraud, bad sales, theft, debt (on both sides), shirking boon work (again, on both sides). The parish church has heard an equally lengthy back-and-forth over the centuries: drunkenness, fornication, adultery, scolding, eating meat during Lent, blasphemy, witchcraft. It will never end. You sigh and let your chin drop onto your chest, resting your eyes from the blinding sight of your beloved. But you can still hear their voice: clear and exultant in song and laughter. Singing the night away.</p> <p>You take another drink and remember the <<linkappend "Easter play">><<include love-link2>><</linkappend>> a few months ago. Their family played the Romans and Jews and devils, and your family played Christ and the disciples and the angels. The fight was epic, as usual. You run your fingers over the new scar on your forearm where one of their brothers "accidentally" stabbed all the way through and out the other side with the hard ash-wood tine of his pitchfork. You had played Jesus this year, and when they were nailing you to the cross, he sat his bare arse on your head (you take another drink, remembering ...). So, you grabbed the crown of thorns and stuck it in one of his hairy hams. And he "accidentally" stabbed you with the pitchfork, repeatedly. It was pretty much the same at the Christmas play. One year, the priests tried to split you up so there were some from each family on each side of the Easter play. A smile comes across you as you remember, and a chuckle bursts out. They'll never try that again. Another year, when your family made the Noah parade wagon in the mystery play, a bunch of them put rotten eggs on a hidden plank underneath, so when the wagon rolled through the market square, it left a trail of stench and broken eggs behind. And then there was the fight at the May Day Robin Hood play last month... You sigh and drink again.</p> <p>Your cup feels so light. The fire's rage is cooling. You look east and see a glow. <em>Not much time.</em> You get up and move toward the one you want.</p> <p>What do you say to your beloved? What are they like? Why do you love them? How will you achieve some kind of romantic union with this person? How will you deal with the family problem? Is marriage possible? Or desirable?</p> <hr> <ul class="nodot center"> <li>[[student1 choice |love-rewrite1]]</li> <li>[[student2 choice |love-rewrite2]]</li> <li>[[student3 choice |love-rewrite3]]</li> <li>[[student4 choice |love-rewrite4]]</li> <li>[[student5 choice |love-rewrite5]]</li> </ul> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "forester-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "forester-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "forester-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "forester-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "forester-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "love-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "love-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "love-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "love-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants Rewrite |peasants-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer>students' responses for this choice <p><<link "(Back to see other choices)" "love-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Medieval Peasants "art-rewrite">><</link>></p> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Renaissance Rewrite |renaissance-rewrite]]</li> <li>[[Back: Our History Rewrite |Our History Rewrite]]</li> </ul> </footer><div class="container"> <div class="row passageheader"> <ul> <li>[[Restart |Enter]]</li> <li>Western Civ I Role Play Game</li> <li>[[About]]</li> </ul> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> (c. 551)</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>Jordanes was an administrator and historian in sixth-century Constantinople. His <em>History of the Goths</em> is based on a now-lost work by Cassiodorus. <a href=&quot;https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ve-sZC-ak5kwMfjO-_wr-oQAGFbEjoRuiXQELxs2_Mc/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">This section</a> presents the Goths' perspectives on their situation under pressure from the Huns at the time of the Battle of Adrianople (378). </p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Germanic ideas of kingship and national identity</li> <li>Germanic perspectives on Rome and the Huns</li> <li>Military strengths and weaknesses of the barbarian tribes</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangete2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangeta2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangete3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangeta3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangete4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"<<textarea "$adriangeta4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> |tacitus]]</li> <li>[[Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> |jordanes]]</li> <li>[[Barbarian law |law]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <li>[[About the Roman legions in the fourth century CE |halsall]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Barbarian Law Codes</h1> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>These excerpts from the law codes compiled by early Germanic kings represent a fusion of barbarian traditions (such as wergild and trial by ordeal) and Roman law. Burgundian and Lombard ... links to be posted... </p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Beliefs and customs of barbarian society</li> <li>Everyday life, family and gender norms in barbarian society</li> <li>Dynamics of Roman and Germanic identities, traditions, societal and behavioral norms</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawe1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawa1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawe2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawa2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawe3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawa3" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Fourth set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawe4" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$adrianlawa4" "">></div> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> |tacitus]]</li> <li>[[Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> |jordanes]]</li> <li>[[Barbarian law |law]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <li>[[About the Roman legions in the fourth century CE |halsall]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="link"> <p>In this role play scenario, I have imagined Artemisia Gentileschi running a successful portrait workshop like that of Raphael in the sixteenth century. I've placed her at the court of Grand Duchess Christina of Tuscany. In the 1620s, Christina's court was a hub of intellectual discourse with visitors and correspondents like Galileo Galilei. It was also a girl power nexus, ruled by the well-educated Christina (whose mother, Catherine de Medici, Queen of France, was one of the most powerful women in renaissance Europe) and her daughter in law, Maria.</p> <p>In reality, Artemisia Gentileschi is one of the masters of baroque art. While she did become the first woman in the prestigious Florentine Academy of the Arts, her career suffered greatly from patriarchal forces of oppresssion during her lifetime. Her paintings include the scene below, depicting the biblical heroine Judith beheading Holofernes - a classic Old Testament story everyone would have known in 17th-century Italy. But not many people would have known about Artemisia. The painting below was rejected by its patron and hidden away. As a young woman, Artemisia was sexually assaulted by her painting tutor. During the ensuing trial, she was tortured. He was acquitted.</p> <p><img src="images/judith-gentileschi.jpg" alt="two women killing a man with a sword" width="100%"></p> <p>As a woman, Artemisia stood outside the networks of patronage and institutions that supported male artists like Caravaggio. His version of Judith and Holofernes, below, was much admired and his career flourished in spite of a lifestyle of (lethal) violence and continual debt.</p> <p><img src="images/judith-caravaggio.jpg" alt="woman killing a sleeping man with a sword while another woman looks on" width="100%"></p> </div>Fritigund, Alaric, Theodosius, Stilicho, Aetius<div class="link"> <p>Early seventeenth-century men's clothing was complex and ornate. The design aimed to emphasize the wearer's wealth and status with displays of opulence and costly materials such as rich dye, silk, fur, embroidery. This can be seen in the portrait of Sir Walter Raleigh and his son, below, created by an unknown artist c. 1602.</p> <p><img src="images/raleigh.jpg" alt="man and boy posing in fine seventeenth-century clothing" width="80%"></p> <p>We can see the intricacy of masculine dress in the image below as well. This baroque masterpiece by Dutch painter Rembrandt van Rijn, called <em>The Night Watch</em>, depicts the civic militia employed by a prosperous city to enforce law and order.</p> <p><img src="images/nightwatch.jpg" alt="men in bright clothing hold weapons, surrounded by dark crowd" width="100%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>The time of the European witch craze was also a time of nearly constant war, fought primarily by mercenary companies. They were notorious for profit-driven attacks on ordinary people. Villages were devastated by repeated waves of violence, diseaes, famine. In the engravings below, French artist Jacques Callot draws on his own experience of the Thirty Years' War. They were published in his 1633 series, "The Great Miseries of War."</p> <p><img src="images/callot1.jpg" alt="mercenaries raiding a farmhouse" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Mercenaries raiding a farmhouse. Callot's caption reads: "See the fair deeds of these bestial hearts. They look everywhere and nothing escapes their grasp. Here one tortures in search of gold. There another who's done it all before urges on his friends. And all of them together kidnap, rape, murder, and steal."</p> <p><img src="images/callot2.jpg" alt="mercenaries raiding a farmhouse" width="100%"></p> <p>Above: Mercenaries being executed by local authorities. Callot's caption reads: "In the end these hateful and damned thieves hang on this tree like bad fruits - showing that horrible crimes and dark acts are also tools of shame and revenge, that the fate of men so vicious is simply to prove (sooner or later) the justice of heaven."</p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Conversion involved a mixture of pagan and Christian practices and beliefs. For instance, popes were ready to make space for pagan festivals in the Christian calendar. They advised missionaries to keep pagan shrines intact, simply replacing the idols with a cross, and sacrifices with sacraments. Beowulf says, "Fate will often save a man if his courage holds," while another poet writing a life of Saint Andrew around the same time and in the same heroic-traditional style, uses the same familiar formulaic phrase to describe the saint's bravery in his battle with demons. He simply changes "Fate" (Old English, <em>wyrd</em>) to "God." Easy. The three artifacts from the seventh-century Germanic kingdoms illustrate this kind of religious and cultural syncretism.</p> <p>Below: "The Coppergate Helmet" from York features ornamental boar heads matching a description from <em>Beowulf,</em> which tells us that pagans believed the board heads would protect the wearer. The helmet is also decorated by a Christian prayer, "In the name of the Lord Jesus, Holy Spirit, and God ..."</p> <p><img src="images/york-helmet.jpg" alt="helmet with cheekplates" width="80%"></p> <p>Below: This ornament from Anglo-Saxon England depicts Odin, and closely resembles the figure of Christ as the warrior below it, on a funerary plaque from Francia. Poetic depictions of Christ often present him this way - as a warrior, fighting demons, surrounded by his loyal warband (the disciples).</p> <p><img src="images/woden-ornament.jpg" alt="ornament engraved with figure wielding spear" width="50%"></p> <p><img src="images/woden-funerary.jpg" alt="engraving of warrior with spear" width="50%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Crusader armies were typically vastly outnumbered by their Muslim opponents. However, their heavy cavalry was formidable. Muslim cavalry was lighter, relying primarily on bows rather than swords and lances. Muslim leaders like Saladin soon learned to develop their own form of heavy cavalry, modeled on that of "the Franks," as they called the crusaders. This scene from the Maciejowski Bible (France, c. 1240) conveys some sense of how physically overwhelming a crusader cavalry charge might be.</p> <p><img src="images/maciejowski-battle.jpg" alt="knights in battle" width="100%"></p> </div><div class="link"> <p>Saldin was highly respected for his mastery of strategy. Like the crusader elite and other Muslim leaders, Saladin made use of diplomacy, espionage, and secrete alliances with enemy players. It's no surprise that the game of chess was popular among the Christian and Muslim elite during the Middle Ages.</p> <p><img src="images/chess-christian-arab.jpg" alt="two men play chess" width="80%"></p> <p><img src="images/chess-spain.jpg" alt="two men play chess in a tent" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: These two images from 13th-century Spain show Christian and Muslim men playing chess with each other.</p> <p><img src="images/manesse-chess.jpg" alt="man and woman playing chess" width="80%"></p> <p>Above: German Margrave Otto IV of Brandenbur playing chess with a woman (Codex Manesse, c. 1300).</p> </div>Halsall chapter or video about late empire fortification or Hadrian's Wall <h2>The Sources</h2> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md ps" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Primary Sources</h2> <p>A primary source is an artifact from history, created during the time period you are studying.</p> <ul> <li>[[Tacitus, <em>Germania</em> |tacitus]]</li> <li>[[Jordanes, <em>History of the Goths</em> |jordanes]]</li> <li>[[Barbarian law |law]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[About the Germanic tribes |green]]</li> <li>[[About the Roman legions in the fourth century CE |halsall]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected enough material from the sources using the "Marginalia" boxes? Your Role Play response needs to utilize <span class="bi">at least one primary source and at least one secondary source.</span> If you have enough source material, move on to the Victory! screen and end the game. You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Rome2-victory-a]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Did Rome Fall? |Rome2]]</li> <li>[[Back: Barbarian Scenario |Barbarian]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div><div class="container"> <h1>Bible Storiesh</h1><div class="container"> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md ps-tag"> <p>Primary Source</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <p>The early books of the Hebrew Bible are rich historical sources, when they are used judiciously. It is a complex, composite text - far from a transparent window onto the past, but richly illuminating nonetheless. Have a look at <a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oJptUGRw4oS4-v99-qXiKLsLrcWiJQUJt2g8lUn0jkw/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank">these excerpts</a> from the oldest parts of the Bible, committed to text around 1,000 BCE.</p> <hr> <h2>How to use this source</h2> <p>This source might provide information or insights about your character's outlook, experiences, situation, or motivations. Look for ideas about:</p> <ul> <li>Daily life in ancient Israel and Judah</li> <li>Religious, cultural, and political views in Hebrew society</li> <li>A developing Hebrew national identity</li> <li>The Hebrews' relationship with neighboring groups</li> </ul> <p>In the "Marginalia" panel below, enter evidence (such as quotes or details) from the source. Pair each piece of evidence with analysis (idea or reflection) relating to the Role Play scenario. These will be collected for you and available at the end of the game, so that you can copy and paste them into your Role Play response in Canvas. </p> <div class="row marginalia"> <h2>Marginalia</h2> <p>This is where you will collect evidence and analysis from this source. The text you enter here will appear in the Victory! screen at the end of the game. (Note: You do not need to fill in all of the boxes. Use as many or as few as you need.)</p> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>First set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre1" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra1" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Second set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre2" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra2" "">></div> </div> <hr> <div class="row marginalia-box"> <h3>Third set of evidence & analysis</h3> <p>Enter evidence from the source (quote or detail):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfre3" "">></div> <p>Enter corresponding analysis (thoughts, reflections, ideas):</p> <div class="row"><<textarea "$lachfra3" "">></div> <li>[[Assyrian depictions of the siege |lachish-friezes]]</li> </ul> </div> </div> <div class="col-md ss" id="sourcedoorstext"> <div class="transbox sourcelist"> <h2>Secondary Sources</h2> <p>A secondary source is a present-day interpretation of history (like your textbook).</p> <ul> <li>[[Archaeological and artistic evidence |lachish-evidence]]</li> <li>[[Ancient Israel and Judah |miller-israel]]</li> <li>[[Assyrian siege warfare |lachish-sieges]]</li> <li>You can also use your textbook or class lectures.</li> </ul> </div> </div> <hr> <h2>All done?</h2> <p>Have you collected You will find your quotes and notes waiting for you there.</p> <div class="row"> <div class="col-md"> </div> <div class="col-md victory-link"> <p>[[Victory! |Iron-victory-l]]</p> </div> <div class="col-md"> </div> </div> <div class="row"> <footer> <ul> <li>[[Back: Iron Age Empires Portal |Iron]]</li> <li>[[Back: Lachish Scenario |Lachish]]</li> </ul> </footer> </div> </div>
